devise, and that so shortly as I can. In like manner you see that the term of
my here abode, will shortly be expired, and if we be once at the Court,
impossible it is for me to recover so good occasion, and peradventure she will
be married, or some other shall carry away the pray, after I have beaten the
bushe. The plot then of this maidens rape, was resolved upon, and the first
espied occasion taken. But the lover which feared least this heat of his
companio^s would cool, solicited them so much, as the execution was ordained
the following night: which they did, not so much for the pleasure of their
friend, to whom in such adventures they ought to deny all help, (since
friendeship ought not to pass, Sed (...) ad ar as, as Pericles the Athenian
said, so far as was sufferable by the laws of God) as for that they were of
nature of the self same tramp, which their passionate companion was, and would
have made no conscience to enterprise the same for themselves, although the
other had not told them his affections. These also be the fruits of unruled
youth, wherein only the verdure and greenness of the age bears greatest sway,
the will whereof reason can not restrain, which easily waltreth and tosseth
sooner to the carnal part, than to that which tends to the pasture and
co^tentation of the mind. The next night after, they. (...). came accompanied
with. v. or. vj. servants (so honest as their masters) in armure and weapons
well appointed to defend and hurt, that if any resistance were made, they might
be able to repel their adversaries. Thus about two of the clock in the night
repaired they to the Mill, the heavens having thrown their mantell over the
vaporous earth, and (...) her face with their veil obscure and dark, and yet
not such, but that the air was cloudy clear, and when no man doubted of so
great offe^se, and of such unhappy rape, they brake into the pore millers
house, between whose arms they took away his daughter dear, and almost dead
for fear, piteously began to cry for help, defending her self so well as she
could from these Thieves and Murderers. The desolate father, raging with no
less fury than the Hircanian Tigre, when her Faucons be killed or taken away,
ran first to one, and then to another, to let them from carrying of her away,
for whom they came. In the end the amorous rauisher of his daughter said unto
him: Father, Father, I advise thee to get thee hence if thou love thy life, for
thy force is too weak to resist so many, the least of whom is able to cool
this thy foolish heat and choler, for the which I would be sorry, for the great
love I bear unto thy daughter, who (I hope) before she depart my company, shall
have wherewith to be contented, and thou cause to pacify this immoderate rage
which in vain you yalpest forth against this troop. Ah false knave and thief,
(said the honest poor man) is it thou then, which by thine infamous
filthiness and insaciable knauerie, do dishonor the commendable fame of my
daughter, and by like means (...) the hoped years of me her poor unhappy
father, losing through thy wickedness, the staff and stay of mine old aged
life? Think thou Traitor that living till this day (for all my poverty) in
reputation of an honest man in mine old days, will become an unshamefast and
vile minister and Chapman of my daughters maidenhoode and virginity? No knave,
think not that I forget the wrong received of thee, for which by some means
or other, I will purchase just revenge either upon thee or thine. The Gentleman
caring little or nothing for the old man's words, having in hand his desired
spoil, commanded his men to march before with the maiden, leaving behind
the pore old man which thundered against them a thousand (...) and cursses,
threatening and reuiling them, by all the terms he could devise, desirous (as I
think) to have them turn back to kill him. But thereunto they gave so little
heed, as when he demanded to leave his daughter behind them: to whom the
amorouse courtier addressing himself, began to make much of her and kiss her,
and assayed by all means with pleasant words and many sweet promises to
comfort her: but yt pore wench knowing full well, that they went about to play
the butchers with her chastity and shamefastness, and to commit murder with
the flower of her virginity, (...) to cry so piteously with dolorous voice, as
she would have moved to compassion the hardest hearts that ever were, except the
same which craved nothing more tha^ the spoil of that his swetest enemy, who
her self detected and blasphemed her unhappy fate and constellation. When she
saw her virtue ready to be spoiled by one, who (not in marriage joined) went
about to violat and possess the same, and knew yt afterward he would vaunt
himself for the victory of such a precious price, Alas (said she) is it
possible that the sovereign justice of God can abide a mischief so great and
curssed, and that the voice of a pore wretched (...) maid cannot be heard in
the presence of the mighty Lord above? Why may not I now rather suffer death
than the infamy which I see to wander before mine eyes? O yt good old man my
dear and loving father, how far better had it been for thee to have slain
me with thy dagger, between the hands of these most wicked thieves, than to let
me go to be the enemies pray of my virtue and thy reputation. O happy a
hundred hundred times be ye, which have already passed the inevitable tract of
death when ye were in cradle, and I pore unhappy we^ch no less blessed had I
been if partaker of your joy, where now I rest alive to feel the smart and
anguish of that death more egre to support, than that which deuideth the body
and soul. The Gentleman offended with those complaints, began to threaten that
he would make her forget that her disordered behauioure, saying that she must
change an other tune, and that her plaints were to no purpose amongs them which
cared not, or yet were bent to stay upon those her womanishe tears,
lamentations and cries. The poor Maiden hearing that, and seeing that she
dysparckled her voice into the air in vain, began to hold her peace, which
caused the Lover to speak unto her these words: And what my wench? do you
think it now so (...) or strange, if the heat of love that I bear to you,
forces me to use such violence? Alas it is not malice or evil will that
causes me to do the same, it is love which ca^ not be enclosed, but must
needs manifest his force. Ah that you had felt, what I do suffer and endure
for love of you, I believe then you would not be so hard hearted, but have pity
upon the grief whereof you should have proved the vehemency. Whereunto the
maid answered nothing but tears and sighs, wringing her arms and hands, and
sometimes making warrevpon her fair hair. But all these feminine fashions
nothing moved this galla^t, and less removed his former desire to have her,
which he achieved in dispite of her teeth, so soon as he arrived at his own
house. The re^nant of the night they lay together, where he used her with all
such kind of flattering and loving speech, as a lover of long time a suter
could devise to do to her, whom at length he did possess. Now, all these
flattering follies tended only to make her his own, to keep her in his
Country house for his pleasure. She that for her age (as before is said) was
of condition sage, and of gentle mind, began subtilely to dissemble and feign
to take pleasure in that which was to her more bitter than any Aloes or wood
of Myrrha and more against her heart than remembrance of death, which still
she wished for remedy of her grief, and voluntarily would have killed her self
like a Lucrece, if the fear of God and dreadful loss of body and soul had
not turned her mind, and also hoped in God that the rauisher should repair
the fault which he had committed, and bear the penance for his temeritie,
whereof she was no whit deceived, as well ye shall perceive, by that which
immediately does follow.

Now whilst the rauisher (...) his pleasure with his rape, the miserable
father made the air to sound with his complaints, accusing fortune for
letting the whorish varlet so to pass, without doing him to feel the
lustiness of his age, and the force that yet reasted in his furrowed face, and
corpse withered with length of years. In the end knowing that his plaintes,
curses, and desire, were thrown forth in vain, perceiving also his force
unequal to deal with such an enemy, and to get again by violence his stolen
daughter, or to recover her by that means whereby she was taken away, he
determined the next day to go and complain to the Duke: and upon that
determination he laid him down to sleep under the trees, which joined to the
fountain, where sometimes the Courtier had talked with his daughter. And
seeing that the element began to show some bryghtnesse interpaled with colors
of White, Yealow and Red, signs preceding the rising of fresh Aurora, started
from his sleep, and took his way to Florence whither he came, upon the opening
of the City gates. Then going to the Palace of the Duke, he tarried until he
saw the Prince go forth to service. The good man seeing him of whom he
attended to receive succoure, favor and justice, began to freat and rage for
remembrance of his received wrong, and was ashamed to see himself in place not
accustomed: and albeit it grieved his heart with hardy speech to presume in
presence of so many, yet the just anger and desire of vengeance emboldned him
so much, as kneling upon his knees before the Majesty of the Duke, aloud he
spoke these words: Alas (my sovereign Lord) if ever your grace had pity upon
a desolate man, and full of despair, I humbly beseech the same that now you
do regard the misory which on every side assaileth me. Have pity upon the
poverty of that unfortunate old man against whom one has done such wrong, as
I hope by force of your virtue and accustomed justice, you will not leave a
sin so detestable without deserved punishment, for respect of mischiefs that
may ensue where such wickedness shall be dissembled and suffered without due
correction: Saying so, the great tears ran down his grislye beard, and by
reason of his interrupted sighs and continual sobbes, the panting of his
stomach might easily have been perceived all riueld for age, and Sunneburned
with heat and continual Country travail: and that which moved most the
standers by, was the ruefull look of the good old man, who casting his looks
here and there, beheld each one with his holow and dolorous eyes, in such wise
as if he had not spoken any word, his countenance would have moved the Lords
to have compassion upon his misery, and his tears were of such force, as the
Duke which was a wise man, and who measured things by reasons guide, provided
with wisdom, and foreseeing not without timely judgment, would know the cause
which made that man so to make his playnt, and notwithstanding assailed (with
what suspicion I know not) would not have him openly to tell his tale, but
leading the old man aside, he said unto him: My friend, (...) that grievous
faults and of great importance, ought grievously and openly to be punished,
yet it chances oftentimes, that he which in a heat and choler does
execution for the guilt, (although that justly after he has disgested his
rage, at leisure he repents his rigor and over sudden severity, (offense
being natural in man) may sometime (where slander is not evident) by mild and
merciful means forget the same without infringing or violating the holy and
civil constitutions of Lawmakers. I speak thus much because my heart does
throbbe that some of my house have done some filthy fault against thee or some
of thine. Now I would not that they openly should be slaundered, and yet less
pretend I to leave their faults unpunished, specially such as by offensive
crime the common peace is molested, wherein my desire is, that my people do
live. For which purpose God has constituted Princes and Potestates as
shepherds and guids of his (...), to the end that the (...) fury of the
vicious, might, not destroy, devour, and scatter the impotent (...) of no
valor if it be forsaken and left forlorn by the mighty arms of
Principalities and Monarchies. A singular modesty doubtless, and an incredible
example of clemency in him, whom his Citizens thought to be a Tyrant and
unjust usurper of a free Seigniorie, who so privily, and with such
familiarity, as the friend could wish of his companion, hearkened to the
cause of a poor Country man, and moreover his modesty so great, as he would
it not to be known what fault it was, or else that the offenders should
publicly be accused, offering for all that to be the revenger of the wrong
done unto the poor, and the punisher of the injury exercised against ye
desolate; a woork certainly worthy of a true christian Prince, and which
establishes kingdoms decayed, conserueth those that be, rendering the Prince
to be beloved of God, and feared of his Subjects. The pore old man seeing the
Duke in so good mind, and that accordingly he demanded to know the wrong
done unto him, the name of the factor, and that also he had promised him his
help and ryghtfull correction due unto the deserved fault, the good old man I
say conceiving courage, recited from point to point the whole discourse of the
rape, and the violence done upon his poor virtuous daughter, (...) claring
besides the name and surname of those which accompanied the Gentleman, the
author of that conspiracy, who (as we have already said) was one that was in
greatest favor with the Duke: who not withstanding the love that he bare to the
accused, hearing the unworthiness of a deed so execrable, said: As God lives
this is a detestable fact, and well deserves a sharp and cruel punishment.
Not withstanding (...) take good heed that you do not mistake ye same, by
accusing one for an other, for the Gentleman whom thou haste named to be the
rauisher of thy daughter, is of all men deemed to be very honest, and do well
assure thee that if I find thee a liar, thy head shall answer for example to
each false accuser and slaunderer in time to come. But if the matter be so true
as thou have said, I promise thee by the faith I bear to God, so well to
redress thy wrong, as thou shall have cause to be thoroughly satisfied with my
justice. To whom the good old man thus answered. My Lord the matter is so
true, as at this day he keeps my daughter (like a common strumpet) in his
house. And if it please your highness to send thither, you shall know that I
do use no false accusation or lying words before you, my Lord and Prince, in
presence of whom as before the minister and lieuetenant of God, man ought not
to speak but truly and religiously. Since it is so, said the Duke get thee
home to thy house where God willing I will be this day at dinner, but take heed
upon thy life, thou say nothing to any man what so ever it be: for the rest let
me alone, I will provide according to reason. The good man almost so glad for
his good exploit, as the day before he was sorrowful for his loss, joyfully
went home to his homely house and Country cabaue, which he (...) to be made
ready so well as he could, attending the coming of his deliverer, succor,
support, and judge, who when he had heard service, commanded his horse to be
sadled: for (said he) I hear say there is a wild Boar haunting hereby, so
well lodged as is possible to see, we will go thither to wake him from his
sleep and ease, and use that pass time til dinner be ready. So departing from
Florence, he rode straight unto yt Mil where his dinner was made ready by his
servants. There he dined very soberly, and using few words unto his
company, sat still all pensive, musing upon that he had to do. For on the
one side the gravity of yt (...) moved him rigorously to chastise him which
had committed the sante with all cruelty and insolency. On the other side the
love which he bare him (mollifying his heart) made him change his mind, and to
moderate his sentence. The Princes mind thus wandering between love and
rigor, one brought him word that the Dogs had rousde the great est Heart that
ever he saw: which news pleased him very much, for by that means he sent
away the multitude of his Gentlemen to follow yt chase, retaining with him his
most familiar friends, and those that were of his privy and secret council,
whom he would to be witnesses of that which he intended to do, and causing
his host to come before him, he said: My friend, thou must bring us to the
place whereof this morning thou toldest me, that I may discharge my promise. The
Courtiers wo^dred at those words, ignorant whereunto yt same were spoken: but
the good man whose heart lept for joy, as already feeling some great benefit at
hand, and honor prepared for the beautifying of his house, seeing the Duke on
horse back, ran bisides him in stead of his Lackey, with whom the Prince
held much pleasant talk all along the way as they went together, (...) they
had not gone sarre, but the Gentleman the (...), with his Companions,
understanding that the Duke hunted there aboutes, came to do him (...): and
his Fortune was such, as he nor any of his friends perceived the old man: by
means whereof the Duke pursued the pray whereof they nothing doubted. For that
cause the said (...) said to his Prince: My Lord, if fortune had so much
favored me, as I might have known of your coming into these quarters, I
would have done my duty to entertain you, not as appertains to the
greatness of your excellency, but according to the ability of the least, and
yet the most obedient of your (...). To whom the Duke dissembling his anger
said: Sir, I dined here hard by within my tents, not knowing that your house
was so near us, but since that I have met you upon your (...) Marches and
(...), I will not go hence before I see your lodging: for so far as I can
judge by the outward part of this goodly building, me thinks the workman
has not forgotten any thing that should serve for the setting forth and
ornament of this part of the house, which for the quantity is one of the
fairest plottes that I have seen.

So approaching the Castle, yt Duke lighted, to view the commodities of the
place, and specially the image, for which alone he was departed from his City,
whereof the Master of the house (drunk with the sudden pleasure to see the
Duke there) thought nothing. So descending into the (...) Court, they saw a
Marble fountain that discharged the water in four great gutters, received by
four naked Nymphs, and by them poured forth into (...), (...) wrought with
(...), where was an armed Knight, lying under an high and broad tree, which
ouershadowed the Fountain. And hard by, they espied a little door which showed
the way into (...) singular and well planted a Garden, as ever the delicious
and pleasant Gardens were of Alcinoe. For in the same (bysides the Artificial
(...), and ordinary travel of the gardener) nature produced four Fountains in
the four corners, making the place and plain of the Garden equally parted in
fouresquare form. Now these fountains watered all the fair knots of the
same, without any pain to the gardener, except to open certain little (...),
whereby the water sprang and ran, where he thought it needful. I will here
leave to speak of the Trees and fruits divided in flue form order, the
Laberynthes subtilely and finely made: the sweet Herbers yelding such
contentation to the eye, as if the Duke had had no greater respect to the wrong
done to the Millers daughter, than incited with the gentleness of the master
of the house, and the singularity of the place, perchance he might have
forgotten himself within that little earthly Paradise. And to perform the
excellency of the place, the working hand and industry of man, helped by the
benefit of Nature, had wrought a (...) or (...) very deep, wherein were
bestowed a good number of (...), and wherein the immortal voice of an Echo
answered their talk with a triple voice in that profound and earthly place:
which moved the Duke to call the Gentleman unto him, unto whom he said: If it
be so, that the rest of the house do mat (...) with that which I have already
seen, I am out of doubt it is one of the (...) and most delectable (...) at
(...) (...) (...) the whole compass of Italy. Wherefore my friend, I pray thee
that we may see the hole, (...) for the conte^tation of our minds, and also
that I may make some vaunt that I have seen the rarest and best furnished
little house that is within all the jurisdiction of Florence. The Gentleman
bathed in ease and full of pleasure, seeing that the Duke liked so well his
house, brought him from chamber to chamber, which was enriched either with
stately tapissarie of Turkey making, or with rich Tables divinely wrought, with
vtensils so neat and fit, as the Duke could cast his (...) upon none of them,
but he was driven into an admiration and wonder. And the further he went, the
greater he saw the increase, and almost a regeneration, or as I may say, a new
birth of rare things, which made yt littleness of the place more stately and
wonderful: wherefore he greatly esteemed him in his mind which had devised
the magnificence of such a furniture. After then that he had visited the
Portals, Galleries, Parlers, Chambers, Garrets, Wardrobes, Closets, and
chiefest places of that house, they came into a gallerie, which had a direct
prospect upon the Garden, at the end whereof there was a chamber shut, over
which there was such Antike and Imbossed work, as it was marvel to behold,
and upon the garden side in like workmanship, ye might have viewed a troop of
Nymphs flying (a (...) the side of a wood adjoining upon a great river) an
hierde of Satires, making as though they would have ouerrunne them: a pleasure
it was to see their (...) mouths, their eyes fixed upon the place where (...)
clouenfooted pursuters were, and the countenance of them which so well
expressed their fear, as there (...) nothing but speech. Moreover a better
sight it was to behold the Satire Bucks, with displayed throfe, and their
fingers pointing at the bast of those fearful (...), as though they mocked
their (...) flyghte. Within a while after ye might have seen Hercules lying a
bed with his wife, toward whom a Eaunus came thinking to enjoy the beauty and
embraceme^ts of the sleeping dame. But fayrer it was to see how that strong
(...) gave him the mock, and strained him so hard, as he thought his belly
would burst. The Duke beholding as he thought, the fairest place of the house so
shut, by and by suspected the truth of the cause. For the Gentleman knowing
the coming of the Duke, had withdrawn his woman into the same, for that it
was the most secret chamber of his house, and the furdest from all ordinary
service. And therefore said the Duke: wherefore is not this chamber opened
unto us so well as the rest? I suppose the same to be your treasure house, and
the storehouse of your most delicat things: but you may be assured that we be
not come hither to trouble you, but only (as we think) to do you pleasure. My
Lord (said the Gentleman) the place is to far out of order, at this time to
show your grace. Moreover I know not where the keys be, for this morning the
keeper of my house is gone unto the city, and I can not tell to whom he has
delivered the same. The Duke which heard the end of his excuse, not accepting
the same for the price which the courtier would and thought to have sold it,
was sure then of that which before he did suspect. Wherefore with furious
countenance he said unto him: Go too, go too, either with the key, or (...)
it, let this door be opened, that I may see all thy secrets within. The
rauisher seeing yt Duke to be earnest, could not tell at the first face, of what
wood to make his arrows, and stood (...) (...), and surprised with a new
fear. In the end notwithstanding, playing the good fellow, he went unto
(...) Duke, in whose (...) smiling he whispered (because he knew right well
that the Duke was an indifferent good companion, and loved so well his
neighbors wife as his own.) And said: My Lord there is a pretty which within,
whom I do keep, and would not show her to any living man but to you. That is
the cause I ask, (said the Duke) let us see her that I may give judgment of
her beauty, and tell you whither she be worthy of keeping or not. The master
of yt house opened the chamber door, thinking to have gained much, and supposed
to insummate himself the better into the favor of the Duke, but immediately he
saw himself far deceived of his account. For the ravished and shamefast
maiden coming for the of the Chamber with her hair about her eyes, and her
garments berent and torn, her stomach and breast all naked and discovered, her
face and eyes all blubbered with tears, like a desperate woman threw her self
at the Princes feet, saying: Ah (my Lord) behold here, and have pity upon
the most unfortunate wenche of all most wretched caytife women, who shamefully
and (...) has been abused and defloured by him, which impudently dares to
bring you into the place the witness of his abominable and wicked life. The
Duke seeing this sight, and having compassion upon the maiden, turned his face
toward the Gentleman and his Companions (which by chance were come thither,
as the Duke was entered into the Gallerie) not with mild and pleasant
countenance as he showed from the beginning, but with a look so grave and
severe, as the hardest of the company could not tell what to do, or what answer
to make him. Upon them then began the righteous Prince to vomit his
displeasure, saying: (...) this the (...) of the blood whereof thou art
descended, to rauishe thy neighbors daughters under mine obeisance and
protection? Do thou thus abuse the familiarity which hitherto I have showed
unto thee? Think thou that the laws be perverted by seeing some change in
the common wealth of Florence? No I assure thee, for so long as the soul shall
reside within my body, I will be he that shall pursue the wicked with all
extremity, and shall not endure the oppressyon of the poor, enough afflicted
with their own proper misery. O God could I have thought that a Gentleman of
my house, would have been so prodigal of his honor, as to soil his hands
so (...) by rauishing of them which ought to be required, and to dishonor
them in place where their virtue ought to serve for a general example? I
cannot tell what stays me from cutting of those curssed heads of yours from
your shoulders like arrant traitors and thieves as you be. Get ye hence ye
infamous villains and beastly Ruffians, the troublers of your neighbors rest,
and the spoylers of the same of her, that is more worth than all ye together.
Then speaking to the Maid he said: Rise up my wench, and on me repose thy
comfort, for I promise thee by the Faith of a Gentleman, that I will do thee
such reason, and use thee so uprightly, as both my Consciente shall be
quieted, thou contented, and thine honor restored for the wrong and injury
which it has received of these Gallantes. And by and by he commanded the
Miller to come before him, and all those whom he had brought with him to
assist his doings, before whom he caused to be brought both the ravished
maiden, and the condemned of the rape: unto whom he said: This is the pray my
friends that I determined to take, which I have done without toils, nets, or
chaunting of the Dogs. Behold, I pray you the honor which my household
servants do unto my house, as to ouerrun the simple Country people, and
ravish their daughters between the arms of their proper parents, as to break,
beat down, and overthrow the doors of their houses, who living under the
laws of our city, ought to enjoy like privilege of liberty and franchize. If
one respect (which I will not disclose) did not impeche and stay me, I would do
such cruel justice upon the offenders, as the posterity should make report
thereof. Notwithstanding it shall suffice that they receive this shame before
you all, by (...) themselves banquished of a crime, which for expiation and
revenge, deserves most shameful death and to receive of me for proof of my
mercy, an undeserved pardon of their fault, with condition nevertheless that
thou (speaking to the Gentleman rauisher) shall take this maiden to wife, (for
otherwise thou art not able to repair the honor thou have taken from her) and
shall love her so dearly, as fondly (...) she was beloved of thee. I give her
unto thee to esteem and love her so much, as if she were the very sister of me
the Duke of Florence, who commands thee for the ransom and redemption of
thy head, presently to marry her. I will moreover, and ordain by reason of her
fathers poverty, that for the wrong which he has received of you three, his
daughter shall be endowed with two thousand Crowns by him that marries her,
and with a thousand of either of the two other, to the intent that if her
husband die (without heir,) she have wherewith honestly to maintain her
degree, and the honest port of her house. And hereof I will that without delay
a contract be made, and a public instrument of good record in rolled,
swearing once again before thee, that if I understand that thou use her
otherwise, tha^ a wife ought to be by her husband, I will deal such punishment
and correction over thee, as all men in time to come shall take example. The
Gentleman which expected no better meede than death, joyful of that sentence,
fell down prostrate before the Duke in sign of consent, and the like did his
Companions. But the joy of the Miller and his daughter can not be expressed,
who extolled the virtue and justice of their Prince up into the heavens: to
whom with such humility they rendered their humble thanks, as he would do that
saw him self in so great calamity, and brought to such dishonor as erst they
were seen to be, by means of him that acknowledged one of them for his son,
and the other for her lawful spouse. Thus was the marriage made in presence of
the Duke, with so great joy and contentation of all parts, as there was rage
and trouble for yt rape of the Bride. The Duke being returned to Florence, the
brute of this act incontinently was (...) almost throughout the Region of
Italy, and this judgment no less praised, than the sentence which king
Solomon gave upon yt controversy of the two harlots for the living child,
which either of them claimed for her own. And for this cause was he commended
above any other Prince or Lord which in times passed did command or rule the
Common wealth in all the Country of Thuscan. In this wise that modesty made
him worthy of the Principality, which almost against all right he had
usurped, and of a praise which shall no less continue, than the memory of man
is able to extend the same from one generation to an other, and which Covetous
of the praise of a Prince so virtuous, just and modest, shall not cease to
illustrate and gloriously advance him in open evidence, to the end that his
like exercise the same in like things, or of greater consequence, for not
sufferyng venomous and unprofitable herbs to grow in their Common wealth.
Within the Garden whereof, a little nuldew or untimely rain, is able to mar
and corrupt all the good seeds and plants sown and grifted before.
Considering that wicked weeds and dangerous impes take deeper root than
those that bear a good and sauorous fruit, for the conservation whereof, the
diligent husbandman imployeth almost all the seasons of the year.

The Duchess of Malfi.
The Unfortunate marriage of a Gentleman, called ANTONIO BOLOGNA, with the
Duchess of MALFI, and the pitiful death of them both.

The. xxiij. Nouel.
THe greater Honor and authority men have in this world. and the greater their
estimation is, the more sensible and notorious are the faults by them
committed, and the greater is their (...). In like manner more difficult it is
for yt man to tolerate and sustain Fortune, which all the days of his life
has lived at his (...), if (...) chance he fall into any great necessity,
than for him which ncuer felt but woe, mishappe, and adversity. Dyonisius the
Tyrant of Sicilia, felt greater pain when he was expelled his kingdom, than
Milo did, being vanished from Rome. For so much as the one was a Sovereign
Lord, the son of a King, a Iusticiarie on earth, and the other but a simple
Citizen of a City, wherein the people had Laws, and the laws of Magistrates
had in reverence. So likewise the fall of a high and lofty Tree, makes a
greater noise, than that which is low and little. High Towers and stately
Palaces of Princes be seen further off, than the poor Cabans and hontely
shephierds Sheepecotes. The Walls of lofty Cities salute the viewers of the
same farther of, than the simple caves, which the poor do dig below the
Mountain rocks. Wherefore it behooves the Noble, and such as have charge of
Common wealth, to live an honest life, and bear their port vpryght, that none
have cause to take ill example upon dyscourse of their deeds and naughty
life. And above all, that modesty ought to be kept by women, whom as their
race, Noble birth, authority and name, makes them more famous, eue^ so their
virtue, honesty, chastity, and continency more praise worthy. And behouefull
it is, that like as they wish to be honored above all other, so their life do
make them worthy of that honor, without disgracing their name by deed or
word, or blemishing that brightness which may commend the same. I greatly
fear that all the Princely factes, the exploits and conquests done by the
Babylonian Queen Semyramis, never was reco^mended with such praise, as her
vice had shame, in records by those which left remembrance of ancient acts.
Thus I say, because a woman being as it were the Image of sweetness, courtesy
and shame fastness, so soon as she steppeth out of the right trade, and
leaves the smell of her duty and modesty, bisides the denigration of her
honor, thrusts her self into infinite troubles and causes the ruin of such
which should be honored and praised, if women's allurement solicited them not to
folly. I will not here endeavor my self to seek for examples of Samson, Solomon
or other, which suffered the^ selves fondly to be abused by women: and who by
mean of them be tumbled into great faults, and have incurred greater perils.
Contenting my self to recite a right pitiful History done almost in our time,
when the French under the leading of that notable (...) Gaston de Foix,
vanquished the force of Spain and Naples at the journey of Rauenna in the time
of ye French king called Jews the twelfth, who married the Lady Marie,
daughter to king Henry the seventh, and sister to the victorious Prince of
worthy memory king Henry the eight, wife (after the death of the said Jews)
to the puissant Gentleman Charles, late Duke of Suffolk.

In that very time then lived a Gentleman of Naples, called Antonio Bologna,
who having been Master of household to, Federicke of Aragon, sometime King of
Naples, after the French had expelled those of Aragon out of that City, the
said Bologna retired into France, and thereby recovered the goods, which he
possessed in his country. The Gentleman bisides that he was valiant of his
person, a good man of war, and well esteemed amongs the best, had a passing
number of good graces, which made him to be beloved and cherished of every
wight: and for riding and managing of great horse, he had not his fellow in
Italy: he could also play exceeding well and trim upon the Lute, whose faining
voice so well agreed thereunto, that the most melancholic persons would forget
their heaviness, upon hearing of his heavenly noise: and bisides these
qualities, he was of personage comely, and of good proportion. To be short,
Nature having travailed and dispoyled her Treasure house for enriching of him,
he had by Art gotten that, which made him most happy and worthy of praise,
which was, the knowledge of good letters, wherein he was so well trained, as by
talk and dispute thereof, he made those to blushe that were of that state and
profession. Antonio Bologna having left Federicke of Aragon in France, who
expulsed out of Naples was retired to king Jews, went home to his house to
live at rest and to avoid trouble, forgetting the delicates of Courts and
houses of great men, to be the only husband of his own revenue. But what: It
is impossible to eschew that which the heavens have determined upon us: and
less the unhappy, which seems to follow us, as it were naturally proceeding
from our mothers womb: In such wise as many times, he which seems the wisest
man, guided by misfortune, hastes himself with stouping head to fall headlong
into his death and ruin. Even so it chanced to this Neapolitane Gentleman:
for in the very same place where he attained his adua^cement, he received also
his diminution and decay, and by that house which preferred him to what he had,
he was deprived, both of his estate and life: the discourse whereof you shall
understand. I have told you already, that this Gentleman was Master of the
King of Naples household, and being a gentle person, a good Courtier, well
trained up, and wise for government of himself in the Court and in ye service
of Princes, the Duchess of Malfi thought to entreat him that he would serve
her, in that office which he served the king. This Duchess was of the house of
Aragon, and sister to yt Cardinal of Aragon, which the^ was a rich and puissant
personage. Being thus resolved, was well assured yt she was not deceived: for so
much as she was persuaded, yt Bologna was devoutly affected to ye house of
Aragon, as one brought up there from a child. Wherefore sending for him home to
his house, she used unto him these, or like words: Master Bologna, since your
ill fortune, nay rather ye unhap of our whole house is such, as your good Lord
and master has forgon his state and dignity, and yt you therwithall have lost
a good Master, without other recompense but the praise which every man gives
you for your good service, I have thought good to entreat you to do me yt
honor, as to take charge of the government of my house, and to use the same, as
you did that of the king your master. I know well that the office is to
unworthy for your calling: notwithstanding you be not ignorant what I am, and
how near to him in blood, to who^ you be so faithful and loving a servant:
and albeit ye that I am no Queen, endued with great revenue, yet with that
little I have, I bear a Princely heart: and such as you by experience do know
what I have done, and daily do to those which depart my service, reco^pensing
them according to their pain and travail: magnificence is observed as well in
the Courts of poor Princes, as in the stately Palaces of great Kings and
monarchs. I do remember that I have red of a certain noble gentleman, a
Persian borne, called Ariobarzanes, who used great examples of courtesy and
stoutnes toward king Artaxerxes; wherewith ye king wondered at his magnifice^ce,
and confessed himself to be vanquished: you shall take advise of this request,
and I in the mean time do think you will not refuse ye same, as well for that
my demand is just, as also being assured, ye our house and race is so well
imprinted in your heart, as it is impossible yt the memory thereof can be
defaced. The gentleman hearing yt courteous demand of the Duchess, knowing
himself how deeply bound he was to yt name of Aragon, and led by sour
unknown provocation to his great ill luck, answered her in this wise: I would
to god madame, yt with so good reason and equity I were able to make denial of
your (...), as justly you require the same: wherefore for yt bounden duty which
I owe to yt name and memory of the house of Aragon, I make promise yt I shall
not only sustain ye trauail, but also the danger of my life, daily ready to be
offered for your service: but I feel in mind I know not what, which (...) me
to (...) my self to live alone at home at my house, and to be content with the
little I have, forgoing the su^ptuouse charge of Princes houses, which life
would be well liked of my self, were it not for the fear that you madame should
be discontented with my refusal, and that you should conceive, yt I disdained
your offered charge, or co^tempne your Court for respect of the great Office I
bare in the Court of the King; my Lord and Master. For I cannot receive more
honor; than to serve her, which is of that stock and royal race. Therefore at
all adue^tures I am resolved to obey your will, and humbly to satisfy yt duty of
yt charge wherein it pleases you to employ me, more to pleasure you for
avoiding of displeasure: the^ for desire I have to live an honorable life in yt
greatest princes house of yt world, since I am discharged from him in whose name
rests my (...) and only stay, thinking to have lived a solitary life, and to
pass my (...) in rest, except it were in ye pore ability of my service to yt
house, whereunto I am bound continually to be a faithful servant. Thus Madame,
you see me to be the rediest man of the world, to fulfill the request, and
accomplish such other service wherein it shall please you to employ me. The
Duchess thanked him very heartily, and gave him charge of all her household
train, commanding (...) person to do him such reverence as to her self, and
to obey him as the chief of all her family. This Lady was a widow, but a
passing fair Gentlewoman, fine and very young, having a young son under her
guard and keeping, left by the deceased Duke her husband, together with the
Duchy, the inheritance of her child. Now consider her personage being such,
her easy life and delicate bringing up, and daily seeing the youthely trade and
manner of Courtiers life, whether she felt her (...) pricked with any desire,
which burned her heart yt more incessantly, as the flames were hidden and
covert: from the outward show whereof she stayed her self so well as she could.
But she following best advise, rather esteemed the proof of marriage, than to
burn with so little fire, or to incur the exchange of lovers, as many
unshame fast stru^pets do, which be rather given over, tha^ satisfied with
pleasure of love. And to say the truth, they be not guided by wisdoms lore,
which suffer a maiden ripe for marriage to be long unwedded, or yo^g wife long
to live in widows state, what assurance so ever they make of their chaste and
stayed life. For books be so full of such enterprises, and houses stored with
examples of such stolen and secret practices, as there need no further proof
for assurance of our cause, the same of it self being so plain and manifest.
And a great folly it is to build the fa^tasies of chastity, amid the follies
of worldly pleasures. I will not go about to make those matters impossible, ne
yet will judge at large, but that there be some maidens and wives, which wisely
can contain themselves amongs the troop of amorous suitors. But what? the
experience is very hard, and the proof no less dangerous, and perchance in
a moment the mind of some perverted, which all their living days have closed
their ears from the words of those that have made offer of loving service, we
need not run to forayne Histories, ne yet to seek records that be ancient,
since we may see the daily effects of the like, (...) in Noble houses, and
Courts of Kings and Princes. That this is true, example of this fair Duchess,
who was moved with that desire which pricketh others that be of Flesh and bone.
This Lady waxed very weary of lying alone, and grieved her heart to be without
a match, (...) in the night, when the secret silence and darkness of the same
presented before the eyes of her mind, the Image of the pleasure which she
felt in the life time of her deceased Lord and husband, whereof now feeling her
self despoiled, she felt a continual combat, and durst not attempt that
which she desired most, but eschued ye thing whereof her mind liked best. Alas
(said she) is it possible after the (...) of the value of honest obedience
which the wife owes unto her husband, that I should desire to suffer the heat
which burns and alters the martired minds of those that subdue them selves
(...) love? Can such attempt pierce the heart of me to become amorous by
forgetting and straying from the limittes of honest life? But what desire is
this? I have a certain unacquainted lust, and yet very well know not what it
is that moves me, and to whom I shall vow the spoil thereof. I am truly
more fond and foolish than ever. Narcislus was, for there is neither shadow
nor (...), upon which I can well stay my sight, nor yet simple Imagination of
any worldly man, whereupon I can arrest the conceit of my unstayed heart, and
the desires which provoke my mind. Pygmalion loved once a Marble pillar, and I
have but one desire, the color whereof is more pale than death. There is
nothing which can give the same so much as one spot of vermilion rud. If I do
discover these appetites to any wight, perhaps they will mock me for my labor,
and for all the beauty and Noble birth yt is in me, they will make no
conscience to deem me for their jesting stock, and to solace themselves with
rehersall of my fond conceits. But since there is no enemy in the field, and
that but simple suspicion does assail us, we must break of the same, and
deface the entier remembrance of the lightness of my brain. It appertains
unto me to show my self, as issued forth of the Noble house of Aragon. To me it
does belong to take heed how I err or degenerate from the royal blood
whereof I came. In this sort that fair widow and young Princess fantasied in the
night upon the discourse of her appetites. But when the day was come, seeing
the great multitude of the Neapolitan Lords and gentlemen which marched up and
down the City, eying and beholding their best beloved, or using talk of mirth
with the^ whose servant they were, all that which she thought upon in the
night, vanished so sone as yt flame of burned straw, or the powder of the Canon
shot, and purposed for any respect to live no longer in yt sort, but promised
the conquest of some friend that was lusty and discreet. But the difficulty
rested in that she knew not, upon whom to fix her love, fearing to be
slaundered, and also that the light disposition and manner of most part of youth
were to be suspected, in such wise as giving over all them which vauted upon
their Gennets, Turkey Palfreis, and other Coursers along ye City of Naples,
she purposed to take repast of other Uenison, than of that fond and wanton
troop. So her mishap began already to spin the threede which choked the air
and breath of her (...) life. Ye have heard before yt M. Bologna was one of ye
wisest and most perfect gentlemen that the land of Naples yt time brought
forth, and for his beauty, proportion, galantnesse, valiance, and good grace
without comparison. His favor was so sweet and pleasant, as they which kept
him company, had somewhat to do to abstain their affection. Who then could
blame this fair Princess, if (pressed with desire of match, to (...) ye
ticklish instigations of her wa^ton flesh, and having in her presence a man so
wise) she did set her mind on him, or fantasy to mary him? would not yt party
for calming of his thirst and hunger, being set at the table before sundry
sorts of delicate viands, ease his hunger? Me think the person does greatly
forget himself, which having ha^dfast upon occasion, suffers ye same to vanish
and fly away, since it is well known ye she being bald behind, has no place
to sease upon, when desire moves us to lay hold upon her. Which was the cause
yt the Duchess becam extremely in love with ye master of her house. In such
wise as before al men, she spared not to praise ye great perfectio^s wherewith
he was enriched, who^ she desired to be altogether hirs. And so she was (...),
that it was as possible to see yt night to be void of darkness, as yt Duchess
without the presence of her Bologna, or else by talk of words to set forth his
praise, ye continual remembrance of whom (for that she loved him as her self)
was her only minds repast. The gentleman yt was full wise, and had at other
times felt the great force of ye passion which proceeds from extreme love,
immediately did mark yt cou^tena^ce of the Duchess, and perceived ye same so
nere, as unfeignedly he knew yt very arde^tly yt Lady was in love we him: and
albeit he saw ye inequality and difference between the^ both, she being sorted
out of ye royal blood, yet knowing love to have no (...) (...) state or dignity
determined to follow his fortune and (...) serve (...), which so lovingly showed
her self to him. Then suddenly reproving his fond conceit, he said unto
himself: What folly is that I enterprise, to yt great prejudice and peril of
mine honor and life? Dught the wisdom of a Gentleman to straie and wandre
through the assaults of an appetite rising of sensuality, and that reason give
place to yt which does participate with brute beasts deprived of all reason
by subduing the mind to the affections of the body? No no, a virtuous man
ought to let shine in him self the force of the generositie of his mind. This
is not to live according to the spirit, when pleasure shall make us forget our
duty and sauegard of our Conscience. The reputation of a wise Gentleman
rests not only to be valiant, and skillful in feats of arms, or in service
of the Noble: But needful it is for him by discretion to make himself praise
worthy, and by vanquishing of him self to open the gate to fame, whereby he may
everlastingly make himself glorious to all posterity. Love pricketh and
provoke the spirit to do well, I do confess, but that affection ought to be
addressed to some virtuous end, tending to marriage, for otherwise that virtuous
image shall be soyled with the villainy of beastly pleasure. Alas said he, how
easy it is to dispute, when the thing is absent, which can both force and
violently assail the bulwarks of most constant hearts. I full well do see the
trothe, and do feel the thing that is good, and know what behooves me to
follow: but when I view that divine beauty of my Lady, her graces, wisdom,
behauior and courtesy, when I see her to cast so loving an eye upon me, that
she uses so great familiarity, that she forgets the greatness of her
house to abase her self for my respect: how is it possible that I should be so
foolish to despise a duty so rare and precious and to set light by that which
the Noblest would pursue with all reverence and endeavor? Shall I be so much
void of wisdom to suffer the young Princess, to see her self contempned of
me, to convert her love to tears, by setting her mind upon an other, to seek
mine overthrow? Who knows not yt fury of a woman? specially of the Noble
dame, by seeing her self despised? No, no, she loves me, and I will be her
servant, and use the fortune proffred. Shall I be the first simple Gentleman
that has married or loved a Princess? Is it not more honorable for me to
settle my mind upon a place so high, than upon some simple wenche by whom I
shall neither attain profit, or advancement? Baldouine of Flaunders, did not
he a Noble enterprise when he carried away Judith the daughter of the French
King, as she was passing upon yt seas into England, to be married to the king
of that Country? I am neither Pirat nor aduenturer, for that the Lady loves
me. What wrong do I then to any person by yelding love again? Is not she at
liberty? To whom ought she to make account of her deeds and doings, but to
God alone and to her own conscience? I will love her, and carry like affection
for the love which I know and see that she bears unto me, being assured yt
the same is directed to good end, and that a woman so wise as she is, will not
commit a fault so filthy, as to blemish and spot her honor. Thus Bologna framed
the plot to intertaine the Duchess (albeit her love already was fully bent upon
him) and fortified him self against all mishap and perilous chance that might
(...), as ordinarily you see that lovers conceive all things for their
advantage, and fantasy dreams agreeable to that which they most desire,
resembling the mad and (...) persons, which have before their eyes, the figured
fancies which cause the conceit of their fury, and stay themselves upon the
vision of that, which most troubles their offended brain. On the other side,
ye Duchess was in no less care of her lover, the will of whom was hid and
secret, which more did vex and torment her, than yt fire of love yt burned
her so ferue^tly. She could not tell what way to hold, to do him understand her
heart and affection. She feared to discover ye same unto him, doubting either
of some fond and rigorous answer, or of reueling of her mind to him, whose
presence pleased her more than all yt men of the world. Alas said she, am I
happed into so strange misery, yt with mine own mouth I must make request to
him, which with all humility ought to offer me his service? Shall a Lady of
such blood as I am, be constrained to sue, where all other be required by
importunat insta^ce of their suitors? Ah love, love, what so ever he was yt
clothed thee with such puissa^ce, I dare say he was the cruel enemy of man's
fredom. It is impossible that thou had thy being in heaven, since yt clemency
and courteous influence of ye same, (...) man with better benefits, than to
suffer her nourse children to be entreated with such rigor. He lies which
says yt Venus is thy mother, for the sweetness and good grace yt rests in
yt pitiful Goddess, who takes no pleasure to see lovers perced with so egre
trauails as that which afflicts my heart. It was some fierce cogitatio^ of
Saturn, that brought thee forth, and sent thee into the world to break the
(...) of them which live at rest without any passion or grief. Pardon me Love,
if I blaspheme thy majesty, for the stresse and endless grief wherein I am
plunged, makes me thus to roue at large, and the doubts which I conceive, do
take away the health and sou^dnesse of my mind, the (...) experience in thy
schole causes this amaze in me, to be solicited with desire yt countersayeth
the duty, honor, and reputation of my state: the party whom I love, is a
Gentleman, virtuous, valiant, sage, and of good grace. In this there is no
cause to blame Love of blindness, for all yt inequality of our houses,
apparent upon the first sight and show of the same. But from whence issue the
Monarchs, Princes and greater Lords, but from the natural and common moss of
earth, whereof other men do come? what makes these differences between those
yt love each other, if not the sottish opinion which we conceive of greatness,
and pre-eminence: as though natural affections be like to that ordained by the
fantasy of men in their laws extreme. And what greater right have (...) to
ioyn with a simple gentlewoman, than ye Princess to mary a Gentleman, and such
as Anthonio Bologna is, in whom heaven and nature have forgotten nothing to
make him equal with them which march amongs the greatest. I think we be the
daily slaves of the fo^d and cruel fantasy of those Tyraunts, which say they
have puissance over us: and that straining our will to their tirannie, we be
still bound to the chain like the galley slave. No no, Bologna shall be my
husband, for of a friend I purpose to make him my loyal and lawful husband,
meaning thereby not to offend God and men together, and pretend to live without
offe^se of conscience, whereby my soul shall not be hindered for any thing I do,
by marying him who^ I so strau^gely love. I am sure not to be deceived in Love.
He loves me so much or more as I do him, but he dares not disclose the same,
fearing to be refused and cast off with shame. Thus two united wills, and two
hearts tied togithers we equal knot cannot choose but bring forth fruits
worthy of such society. Let men say what they list, I will do none otherwise
than my head and mind have already (...). Semblably I need not make account to
any (...) for my fact, my body, and reputation being in full liberty and
freedom. The bond of marriage made, shall cover the fault which men would
deem, and leaving mine estate, I shall do no wrong but to the greatness of my
house, which makes me amo^gs men right honorable. But these honors be nothing
worth, where the mind is void of contentation, and where the heart pricked
forward by desire leaves the body and mind restless without quiet. Thus the
Duchess founded her enterprise, determining to mary her household Master,
seeking for occasion and time, meet for disclosing of the same, and albeit
that a certain natural shame (...), which of (...) accompanies Ladies, did
close her mouth, and made her to defer for a certain time the effect of her
resolved mind. Yet in the end vanquished with love and impacience, she was
forced to break of silence, and to assure her self in him, (...) fear
conceived of shame, to make her way to pleasure, which she lusted more tha^
marriage, the same serving her, but for a Mask and couerture to hide her
follies and shameless lusts, for which she did the penance that her folly
deserved. For no colorable deed or deceitful trompery can serve the excuse of
any notable wickedness. She then thoroughly persuaded in her intent, dreamyng
and thinking of naught else, but upon the unbracement of her Bologna, ended and
determined her conceits and pretended follies: and upon a time sent for him up
into her chamber, as commonly she did for the affairs and matters of her
house, and taking him a side unto a (...), having prospect into a garden, she
knew not how to begin her talk: (for the heart being seized, ye mind troubled,
and the wits out of course, the tongue failed to do his office,) in such
wise, as of long time she was unable to (...) one only word. He surprised
with like affection, was more asto^ned by seeing the alteration of his Lady.
So the two Lovers stood still like Images beholding one another, without any
meuing at all, until the Lady the hardiest of them both, as feeling the most
vehement and greatest grief, took Bologna by the hand, and dissembling what
she thought, used this or such like language: If any other bisides your self
(Gentleman) should understand the secrets which now I purpose to disclose, I
doubt what speech were necessary to color my words: But being assured of
your discretion and wisdom, and with what perfection nature has endued you,
and Art, having accomplished that in you, which nature did begin to work, as
one bred and brought up in the royal Court of the second Alphonse, of
Ferdinando and Federick of Aragon my cousins, I will make no doubt at all to
manifest to you the hidden secrets of my heart, being well persuaded that,
when you shall both hear and (...) my reasons, and taste yt light which I bring
for the for me, easily you may (...) that mine (...) cannot be other, than just
and reasonable. But if your conceits shall straye from that which I shall speak,
and deem not good of that which I determine, I shall be forced to think and
say that they which esteem you wise and sage, and to be a man of good and
ready (...), be maruelously deceived. Notwithstanding my heart foretells that
it is impossible for master Bologna, to wandre so far from equity, but that
by and by he will enter the lystes, and discern the white from black, and the
wrong from that which is just and right. For so much as hitherto I never saw
thing done by you, which preposterated or perverted ye good judgment that all
the world esteems to shine in you, the same well manifested and declared by
your tongue, the right judge of the mind: you know and see how I am a widow
through the death of that noble Gentleman of good remembrance, the Duke my Lord
and husband: you be not ignorant also, that I have lived and governed my self
in such wise in my widow state, as there is no man so hard and severe of
judgment, that can blason reproach of me in yt which appertains to the
honesty and reputation of such a Lady as I am, bearing my port so right, as my
conscience yeldeth no remorse, supposing that no man has where with to bite
and accuse me. Louching the order of the goods of the Duke my son, I have
used them with such diligence and discretion, as bisides the dettes which I
have discharged since the death of my Lord, I have purchased a goodly Manor
in Calabria, and have annexed the same to the Dukedom of his heir: and at this
day do not owe one penny to any creditor that lent money to the Duke, which he
took up to furnish the charges in the wars, which he sustained in the service
of the Kings our sovereign Lords in the late wars for the kingdom of Naples.
I have as I suppose by this means stopped the slanderous mouth, and given
cause unto my son, during his life to account himself bound unto his mother.
Now having till this time lived for other, and made my self subject more than
Nature could bear, I am intended to change both my life and condition. I have
till this time run, travailed, and removed to the Castles and Lordships of the
Dukedom, to Naples and other places, being in mind to tarry as I am a widow.
But what? new affairs and new council has possessed my mind. I have travailed
and pained my self enough, I have too long abidden a widows life, I am
determined therefore to provide a husband, who by loving me, shall honor and
cherish me, according to the love which I shall bear to him, and my desert. For
to love a man without marriage, God defend my heart should ever think, and shall
rather die a hundred thousand deaths, tha^ a desire so wicked shald soil my
conscience, knowing well yt a woman which sets her honor to sale, is less
than nothing, and deserves not yt the common air should breathe upon her, for
all the reverence yt men do bear or make them. I accuse no person, albeit yt
many noble women have their forheds marked, with the blame of dishonest life,
and being honored of some, be nevertheless the common fable of ye people. To
the intent then yt such mishap happen not to me, and perceiving my self unable
still thus to live, being young as I am, and (God be thanked) neither deformed
nor yet painted, I had rather be the loving wife of a simple feere, than yt
Concubine of a king or great Prince. And what? is the mighty Monarche able to
wash away the fault of his wife which has aba^doned him contrary to yt duty
and honest which ye undefiled bed requires? no les the^ Princesses yt whilom
trespassed with those which were of baser stuff than themselves. Messalina we her
imperial robe could not so well cover her faults, but yt the Historia^s do
defame her with yt name and title of a common woman. Faustina the wife of yt
sage Monarch Marcus Aurelius, gained like report by rendering her self to others
pleasure, bisides her lawful spouse. To mary my self to one that is mine
equal, it is impossible, for so much as there is no Lord in all this Country
meet for my degree, but is to old of age, yt rest being dead in these later
wars. To mary a husband that yet is but a child, is folly extreme, for the
inconveniences which daily chance thereby, and the evil entreaty yt Ladies do
receive when they come to age, and their nature wax cold, by reason whereof,
imbracements be not so favorable, and their husbands glutted with ordinary meat
use to ru^ in excha^ge. Wherefore I am resolved without respite or delay, to
choose some well qualitied and renoumed Gentleman, that has more virtue than
richesse, of good Fame and brute, to the intent I may make him my Lord,
espouse, and husband. For I cannot employ my love upon treasure, which may be
taken away, where richesse of the mind do fail, and shall be better content
to see an honest Gentleman with little revenue to be praised and commended of
every man for his good deeds, than a rich carle curssed and detested of all
the world. Thus much I say, and it is the sum of all my secrets, wherein I
pray your Council and advise. I know that some will be offended with my choice,
and the Lords my brothers, specially the Cardinal will think it strange, and
receive the same with ill digesture, that much a do shall I have to be agreed
with them and to remove the grief which they shall conceive against me for this
mine enterprise: wherefore I would the same should secretly be kept, until
without peril and danger either of my self or of him, whom I pretend to
mary, I may publish and manifest, not my love but the marriage which I hope in
God shall soon be consummate and accomplished with one, whom I do love better
than my self, and who as I full well do know, does love me better than his
own proper life. Master Bologna, which till then harkned to the Dration of
the Duchess without moving, feeling himself touched so near, and hearing yt
his Lady had made her approach for marriage, stood still astonned, his tongue
not able to frame one word, only fantasied a thousand (...) in the air, and
formed like number of imaginations in his mind, not able to conjecture what
he was, to whom the Duchess had vowed her love, and the possession of her
beauty. He could not think that this joy was prepared for himself for yt his
Lady spoke no word of him, and he less durst open his mouth, and yet was well
assured that she loved him beyond measure. Not withstanding knowing the
fickleness and unstable heart of women, he said unto himself that she would
change her mind, for seeing him to be so great a Cowarde, as not to offer his
service to a Lady by whom he saw himself so many times both want only
looked upon, and entertained with some secrecy more tha^ familiar. The
Duchess which was a fine and subtle dame, seeing her friend rapt with the
passion, and standing still immovable through fear, pale and amazed, as if he
had been accused and condemned to die, knew by that countenance and
astonishment of Bologna, yt she was perfectly beloved of him: and so meaning
not to suffer him any longer to continue in that amaze, ne yet to further fear
him, with her dissembled and fained marriage of any other but with him, she took
him by the hand, and beholding him with a wa^ton and luring eye, (in such sort
as the curious Philosophers themselves would awake, if such a La^pe and torch
did shine within their studies,) she said thus unto him: Seignor Anthonio, I
pray you be of good cheer, and torment not your self for any thing yt I have
said: I know well, and of long time have perceived what good and faithful love
you bear me, and with what affection you have served me, since first you
used my company. Think me not to be so ignorant, but that I know full well by
outward signs, what secrets be hid in the inner heart: and that conjectures
many times do give me true and certain knowledge of concealed things. And am
not so foolish to think you to be so indiscreet, but that you have marked my
countenance and manner, and thereby have known that I have been more
affectioned to you, than to any other. For that cause (said she, straining him
by ye hand very lovingly, and with cherefull color in her face) I swear unto
you, and do promise yt if you so think meet, it shall be none other but your
self whom I will have, and desire to take to husband and lawful spouse,
assuring my self so much of you, as the love which so long time has been hidden
and covered in our hearts, shall appear by so evident proof, as only death
shall end and undo the same. The gentleman hearing such sudden talk, and the
assurance of yt which he most wished for, albeit he saw yt danger extreme
whereunto he lau^ched himself by espousing this great Lady, and the enemies he
should get by entering such aliance: notwithstanding building upon vain hope,
and thinking at length that the choler of the Aragon brother would pass away
if they understood yt marriage, determined to pursue yt purpose, and not to
refuse that great preferment, being so prodigally offered, for which cause he
answered his Lady in this manner. If it were in my power madame, to bring to
pass yt, which I desire for your service by acknowledging of ye benefits and
favors which you depart unto me, as my mind presents thanks for the same, I
would think my self the happiest Gentleman yt lives, and you the best served
Princess of the world. For one better beloved (I dare presume to say, and so
long as I live will affirm) is not to be found. If til this time I delayed to
open that which now I discover unto you, I beseech you Madame to impute it to
the greatness of your estate, and to the duty of my calling and office in
your house, being not seemly for a servant to talk of such secrets with his
Lady and mistress. And truly yt pain which I have endured to hold my peace,
and to hide my grief, has been more noisome to me than one hundred thousand
like sorrows together, although it had been lawful to have revealed the^ to
some trusty friend: I do not deny madame, but of long time you did perceive my
folly and presumption, by addressing my mind so high, as to the Aragon blood,
and to such a Princess as you be. And who ca^ beguile the eye of a Lover,
specially of her, whose Paragon for good mind, wisdom and gentleness is not?
And I confess to you bisides, that I have most evidently perceived how certain
love has lodged in your gracious heart, wherewith you bare me greater
affection, tha^ you did to any other within the compass of your family. But
what? Great Ladies hearts be fraught with secrets and conceits of other effects,
than the minds of simple women, which caused me to hope for none other guerdon
of my loyal and faithful affection, than death, and the same very short, Since
yt little hope accompanied with great, nay rather extreme passion, is not able
to give sufficient force, both to suffer and to stablish my heart with
constancy. Now for so much as of your motion, grace, courtesy and liberality
the same is offered, and that it pleases you to accept me for yours, I humbly
beseech you to dispose of me not as husband, but of one which is, and shall be
your servant for ever, and such as is more ready to obey, tha^ you to
command. It rests now Madame, to consider how, and in what wise our affairs
are to be directed, yt things being in assurance, you may so live without peril
and brute of slanderous tongues, as your good fame and honest port may
continue without spot or blemish.

Behold the first Act of the Tragedy, and the provision of the fare which
afterward sent them both to their grave, who immediately gave their mutual
faith: and the hour was assigned the next day, that the fair Princess should
be in her chamber alone, attended upon with one only Gentlewoman which had been
brought up with ye Duchess from her cradle, and was made privy to the heavy
marriage of those two lovers which was consummate in her presence. And for the
present time they passed yt same in words, for ratificatio^ whereof they went to
bed together. But yt pain in the end was greater than the pleasure, and had been
better for them both, yea and also for the third, that they had showed them
selves so wise in the deed, as discrete in keeping silence of that which was
done. For albeit their marriage was secret, and thereby politikely governed them
selves in their stelthes and robberies of love, and that Bologna more often held
the state of the steward of the house by day, than of Lord of ye same, and by
night supplied that place, yet in ye end, the thing was perceived which they
desired to be closely kept. And as it is impossible to till and culture a
fertile ground, but yt the same must yield some fruit, even so the Duchess
after many pleasures (being ripe and plentiful) became with child, which at the
first astonned the married couple: nevertheless the same so well was provided
for, as the first childbedde was kept secret, and (...) did know thereof. The
child was nourced in the town, and the father desired to have him named
Federick, for remembrance of the parents of his wife. Now fortune which lies
in daily wait and ambushment, and likes not yt men should long loiter in
pleasure and passetime, being envious of such prosperity, cramped so the legs
of our two lovers, as they must needs change their game, and learn some other
practice: for so much as the Duchess being great with child again, and
delivered of a girl, the business of the same was not so secretly done, but
that it was discovered. And it suffised not that the brute was noised through
Naples, but that the sound flew further off. As each man does know that rumor
has many mouths, who with the multitude of his tongues and Trumps,
proclaims in diverse and sundry places, the things which chance in all the
regions of the earth. Even so that babbling fool, carried the news of that
second childbed to the ears of the Cardinal of Aragon the Duchess brother,
being then at Rome. Think what joy and pleasure the Aragon brothers had, by
hearing the report of their sisters fact. I dare presume to say, that albeit
they were extremely wroth with this happened (...), and with yt dishonest fame
which yt Duchess had gotten throughout Italy, yet far greater was their
sorrow and grief, for that they did not know what he was, that so courteously
was allied to their house, and in their love had increased their ligneage. And
therefore swelling with despite, and rapt with fury to see themselves so
defamed by one of their blood, they purposed by all means whatsoever it cost
them, to know the lucky lover that had so well tilled the Duchess their sisters
field. Thus desirous to remove that shame from before their eyes, and to be
revenged of a wrong so notable, they sent espial round about, and scoutes to
Naples, to view and spy the behauior and talk of the Duchess, to settle some
certain judgment of him, which stealingly was become their brother in law.
The Duchess Court being in this trouble, she did continually perceive in her
house, her brothers men to mark her countenance, and to note those that came
thither to visit her, and to whom she used greatest familiarity, because it
is impossible but that the fire, although it be raked under the ashes, must
give some heat. And albeit the two lovers used each others company, without
showing any sign of their affection, yet they purposed to change their estate
for a time, by yelding truce to their pleasures. Yea, and although Bologna was
a wise and prouide^t personage, fearing to be surprised upon the fact, or that
the Gentlewoman of the Chamber corrupted with Money, or forced by fear, should
pronounce any matter to his hinderance or disauantage, determined to absent
himself from Naples, yet not so suddenly but that he made the Duchess his
faithful Lady and companion privy of his intent. And as they were secretly
in their chamber together, he used these or such like words: Madame, albeit
the right good intent and unstained conscience, is free from fault, yet the
judgment of men has further relation to yt exterior appearance, than to
virtues force and innocence it self, as ignorant of the secrets of the
thought: and so in things that be well done, we must of necessity fall into the
sentence of those, whom beastly affection rauisheth more, than ruled reason.
You see the solemn watch and guard which the servant of the Lords your
brothers do within your house, and the suspicion which they have conceived by
reason of your second childbed, and by what means they labor truly to know
how your affairs proceed, and things do pass. I fear not death where your
service may be aduau^ced, but if herein the maiden of your chamber be not
secret, if she be corrupted, and if she keep not close that which she ought to
do, it is not ignorant to you that it is ye loss of my life, and shall die
suspected to be a whoremonger and varlet, even I, (I say) shall incur that
peril, which am your true and lawful husband. This separation chances not
by Justice or desert, since the cause is too righteous for us: but rather your
brethren will procure my death, when I shall think the same in greatest
assurance. If I had to do but with one or two, I would not change the place, ne
march one step from Naples, but be assured, that a great band, and the same well
armed will set upon me. I pray you madame suffer me to retire for a time, for I
am assured that when I am absent, they will never soil their hands, or imbrue
their, sweards in your blood. If I doubted any thing at al of, peril touching
your own person, I had rather a hundred hundred times die in your company,
than live to see you no more. But out of doubt I am, yt if the things were
discovered, and they knew you to be begotten with child by me, you should be
safe, where I should sustain the penance of yt fact, committed without fault or
sin. And therefore I am determined to go from Naples, to order mine affairs,
and to cause my Revenue to be brought to the place of mine abode, and from
thence to Ancona, until it pleases God to mitigate the rage of your brethren,
and recover their good wills to consent to our marriage. But I mean not to do
or conclude any thing without your advise. And if this intent do not like you,
give me council Madame, what I were best to do, that both in life and death
you may know your faithful servant and loving husband is ready to obey and
please you.

This good Lady hearing her husbands discourse, uncertain what to do, wept
bitterly, as well for grief to lose his presence, as for that she felt her self
with child the third time. The sighs and tears, the sobbes and heavy looks,
which she threw forth upon her sorrowful husband, gave sufficient witness of
her pain and grief. And if none had heard her, I think her playntes would
have well expressed her inward smarte of mind. But like a wise Lady, seeing
the alleged reasons of her husband, licensed him, although against her mind,
not without utterance of these few words, before he went out of her Chamber:
Dear husband, if I were so well assured of the affection of my brethren, as I
am of my maids fidelity, I would entreat you not to leave me alone: specially
in the case I am, being with child. But knowing that to be just and true which
you have said, I am content to force my will for a certain time, that hereafter
we may live at rest together, joining our selves in the company of our
children and family, void of those troubles, which great Courts ordinarily
bear within the compass of their Palaces. Of one thing I must entreat you,
that so often as you can by trusty messenger, you send me word and
intelligence of your health and state, because the same shall bring unto me
greater pleasure and contentation, than the welfare of mine own: and because
also, upon such occurrentes as shall chance, I may provide for mine own
affairs, the surety of my self, and of our children. In saying so, she
embraced him very amorously, and he kissed her with so great sorrow and grief
of heart, as the soul thought in that ecstasy out of his body to take her
flight, sorrowful beyond mesure so to leave her whom he loved, for the great
courtesies and honor which he had received at her hands. In the end, fearing
that the Aragon espials would come and perceive them in those priuities, Bologna
took his leave, and bad his Lady and spouse Farewell.

And thus was the second Act of this Tragical History, to see a fugitife
husband secretly to mary, especially her, upon whom he ought not so much as to
look but with fear and reverence. Behold here (O ye foolish lovers) a Glass
of your lightness, and ye women, the course of your fond behauior. It
behooves not the wise suddenly to execute their first motions and desires of
their heart, for so much as they may be assured that pleasure is pursued so
near with a repentance so sharp to be suffered, and hard to be digested, as
their voluptuausnesse shall utterly discontent them. True it is, that marriages
be done in Heaven, and performed in earth, but that saying may not be applied
to fools, which govern themselves by carnal desires, whose scope is but
pleasure, and the reward many times equal to their folly. Shall I be of
opinion that a household servant ought to solicit, nay rather suborne the
daughter of his Lord without punishment, or that a vile and abject person dare
to mount upon a Princes bed? No no, policy requires order in all, and each
