their request, and understanding that the Council of the Dieci had committed
the matter wholly to the Duke, they inade a supplication unto him in yt name of
yt. iij. Gentlewomen, wherein they craved nothing else but their matter might be
herd. The Duke (...) his advise like to take effect, assigned a day when yt
same should be heard, commanding them at yt time before him and the Lords of
the Council and all the college of the state to appear. The day being come,
all yt Lords assembled, desirous to see to what issue this matter would grow.
On the morning the three Gentlewomen honestly accompanied with other Dames, went
to the palace, and going along the street of San Marco, diverse people (...) to
utter many railing words against the^. Some cried out (as we see by unstable
order the vulgar people in like cases use to do) and doing a certain courtesy
by way of disdain and mockery: Behold yt honest women, yt without sending
their husbands out of Venice, have placed the^ in ye castle of Cornetto, and
yet the arrant whores be not ashamed to show them selves abroad, as though
they had done a thing that were honest and praise worthy. Other shot forth
their boltes, and with their proverbs proceeding from their malicious mouths,
thwited the poor women at their pleasure. Other also seeing mistress Gismonda
in their company, thought that she went to declame against master Aloisio
Foscari, and none of them all happened on the troth. Arrived at the palace,
ascending the marble stairs or steps of the same, they were brought into the
great hall, where the Duke appointed the matter to be heard. Thither repaired
the friends and those of nerest kin to the three Gentlewomen; and before the
matter did begin, the duke caused also the three prisoners to be brought
thither. Thither also came many other Gentlemen, with great desire to see the
end of those events. Silence being made, the duke turning his face to ye women,
said unto them: Ye Gentlewomen have made request by supplication to grant you
public audience according to justice, for that you do allege that law and
order does so require, and that every well ordered common wealth (...) deumeth no
subject without due answer by order of law. Behold therefore, that we
desirous to do justice, be ready in place to hear what ye can say. The two
husbands were very angry and wrathful against their wives, and the more their
stomachs did (...) with choler and disdain to see their impudent and
shameless wives with (...) audacitie to appear before the majesty of a
counsel so honorable and dreadful, as though they had been the most honest and
(...) women of the world. The. (...). honest wives perceived the anger and
displesure of their husbands, and for all that were not afraid ne yet
dismayde, but smiling to the^ selves and somewhat moving their heads in decent
wise, seemed unto them as though they had mocked them. Anselmo more angry and
impacient than Girolamo, brake out into such fury, as had it not ben for the
majesty of the place, and the company of people to have stayed him, would
have killed them: and seeing he was not able to hurt them, he began to utter the
vilest words, that he possibly could devise against them. Mistress Isotta
hearing her husband so spitefully to spit forth his poison in the presence of
that honorable assembly, conceived courage, and craving license of the Duke
to speak, with merry countenance and good vttrance began thus to say her mind:

Most excellent Prince, and ye right honorable lords, perceiving how my dear
husband uncomely and very dishonestly does use himself against me in this
noble company, I do think master Girolamo Bembo to be affected with like
rage and mind against this gentlewoman mistress Lucie his wife, although more
te^perate in words, he do not express the same. Against whom if no reply be
made, it may seem that he has spoken the truth, and that we by silence
should seem to condemn our selves to be those most wicked women whom he
alleges us to be. Wherefore by your gracious pardon and license (most
honorable) in the behalf of mistress Lucie and my self, for our defense I
purpose to declare the effect of my mind although my purpose be clean altered
from that I had thought to say, being now justly provoked by the unkind
behavior of him, whom I do love better than my self, which had he been
silent and not so rashly run to the overthrow of me and my good name, I would
have conceiled and only touched that, which should have concerned the
purgation and sauegard of them both, which was the only intent and meaning of
us, by making our, humble supplication to your majesty's. Nevertheless, so so
far as my feeble force shall stretch, I will assay to do both the one and the
other, although it be not appropriate to our kind in public place to declame,
or yet to open such bold attempts, but that necessity of matter and
opportunity of time and place, does bolden us to enter into these terms,
whereof we crave a thousand pardons for our unkindly dealings, and render
double thanks to your honors, for admitting us to speak. Be it known therefore
unto you, yt our husbands against duty of love, laws of marriage, and
against all reason, do make their heavy complaints, which by and by I will make
plain and evident. I am right well assured, that their extreme rage and bitter
hearts sorrow do proceed of. y. occasions: The one, of ye murder whereof they
have falsely accused the^ selves: ye other of iealosy, which grievously does
gnawe their hearts, thinking us to be vile and abominable women, because they
were surprised in each others chamber. Concerning the murder, if they have
soiled their hands therein, it appertains unto you my lords to render their
desert. But how can ye same be laid to our charge, for so much as they (if it
were done by the^) co^mited ye same without our knowledge, our help and counsel?
And truly I see no cause why any of us ought to be burdened with yt outrage,
and much less cause have they to lay the same to our charge. For meet it is
yt he that does any unlawful act, or is accessarie to the same, should suffer yt
due penalty and severe chastisement accordingly as the sacred laws do
prescribe, as an example for other to abstein from wicked facts. But hereof what
need I to dispute, wherein the blind may see to be none offense, because
(thanks be to God) Master Aloisio lives, which declares the fond confession
of our vngitle husbands, to be contrary to troth? And if so be our husbands in
deed had done such an abominable enterprise, reason and duty had moved us to
sorrow and lament them, because they be borne of noble blood, and be gentlemen
of this noble city, which like a pure virgin inuiolably does co^serue her laws
and customs. Great cause I say, had we to lament them, if like homicides and
murderers they had spotted their noble blood with such foul (...), thereby
deserving death, to leave us young women widows in woeful plight. Now it
behooves me to speak of the iealoufis they have conceived of us, for that
they were in each others chamber, which truly is the doubtful knot and scruple
that forces al their disdain and grief. This I know well is the nail that
pierces their heart: other cause of offense they have not: who like men not
well advised, without examination of us and our demeanor, be fallen into
despair, and like men desperate, (...) wrongfully accused themselves. But
because I may not consume words in vain, to stay you by my long discourse from
matters of greater importance, I humbly beseech you (right excellent prince) to
command them to tell what thing it is, which so bitterly does torment them.
Then the Duke caused one of the noble men assistant there, to demand of them
the question: who answered, yt the chiefest occasion was, because they knew
their wives to be harlots, who^ they supposed to be very honest: and for so much
as they knew them to be such, they conceived sorrow and grief, which with such
extremity did gripe the^ at yt heart, as not able to sustain yt great infamy,
ashamed to be seen of me^ were induced through desire of death to confess yt
they never did. Mistress Isotta hering the^ say so, began to speak again,
turning her self unto them: Were you offended then at a thing which ye thought
inco^uenie^t and not mete to be done? We then have greatest cause to complain.
Why then (...) husband went you to the chamber of mistress Lucie at that time
of the night? What had you to do there? what thing thought you to find there
more than was in your own house? And you master Girolamo, what constrained you
to forsake your wives bed to come to my husbands, where no man ever had, or at
this present has to do but him self? were not yt shetes of the one so white,
so fine, neat and sweet as the other? I am (most noble Prince) sorry to
declare my husbands folly, and ashamed that he should forsake my bed to go to
an other, that did account my self so well worthy to entertain him in mine
own, as the best wife in Venice, and now through his abuse, I abstain to
show my self amongs the beautiful and noble dames of this City. The like
misliking of her self is in mistress Lucie, who (as you see) may be numbered
amongs the fairest, Either of you ought to have been contented with your wives,
and not (as wickedly you have done) to forsake them, to seek for better bread
than is made of wheat, or for purer gold than whereof the Angel is made: O
worthy deed of yours, that have the face to leave your own wives, that be
comely fair and honest, to seek after strange carrion. O beastly order of men
that can not content their lust within the bounds of their own house, but
must go hunt after other women as beasts do after the next of their kind that
they chance upon. What vile affection possessed your hearts to lust after
others wife? You make complainte of us, but we with you have right good cause
to be offended, you ought to be grieved with your own disorder, and not with
others offense, and this your affliction patiently to bear, because you went
about to beguile one an others love, like them that be weary and glutted with
their own fare, seeking after other dainties more delicate if they were to be
found.

But praised be God and our provident discretion, if any hurt or shame has
chanced, the same does light on you. Moreover I know no cause why men should
have more liberty to do evil than we women have: albeit through the
weakness and cowardice of our sex, ye men will do what ye lift. But ye be
now no Lords, nor we servant, and husbands we do you call, because the holy
laws of Matrimony (which was the first Sacrament given by God to men after the
creation of the world) do require equal faith, and so well is the husband
bound to the wife as she unto him. Go to then and make your complaint: the
next Ass or beast ye meet, take her to be your wife. Why do ye not know that
the balance of Justice is equal, and wayeth down no more of one side than of
other? But let us now leave of to reason of this matter, and come to yt for
which we be come hither. Two things (most righteous Prince) have moved us to
come before your majesty, and all this honorable assembly, which had they not
been, we would have been ashamed to show our faces, and less presumed to speak
or once to open our lips in this Noble audience, which is a place only meet
for them yt be most expert and eloquent orators, and not for us, to whom the
needle and distaffe be more requisite. The first cause that forced us to come
forth of our own house, was to let you understand yt our husbands be no
murderers, as is supposed, neither of this Gentleman present master Aloisio, ne
yet of any man else: and thereof we have sufficient and worthy testimony. But
herein we need not to travail much, or to use many words: for neither
master Aloisio is slain, ne any other murdered, yt is known or manifest
hitherto. One thing rests, which is that Madonna Lucia and I do humbly
beseech your excellent Majesty, that your grace and the authority of the
right honorable Lords here present, (...) vouchsafe to reconcile us to our
husbands, that we may obtain pardon and favor at their hands, because (...)
have so manifestly made their acts to appear, and for that we be the offense,
and they the offenders, and yet by their own occasions, we have committed the
error (if it may be so termed.) And now to come to the conclusion, I do
remember (...) I was a child, that I have heard the Gentlewoman my mother say
(whose soul God pardon) many times unto me, and other my sisters, and to
mistress Lucia, that was brought up with us, being by her instructed in diverse
good and virtuous lessons, that all the honor a woman can do unto her husband,
whereby she beautifieth him and his whole race and family, consists in her
honest, chaste, and virtuous life, without which, she ought rather to die than
live. And that a Gentleman's wife when she has given her body to the use of an
other man, is the common mark for every man to point at in the streate where
she goth, her husband thereby incurring reproach and shame which no doubt is the
greatest iniuric and scorn that an honest Gentleman can receive, and the most
shameful reproach that can blemish his house. Which lesson we so well
remembering, desirous not to suffer the careless and unbridled appetites of
our (...) to (...) vnrained, and run at large to some dishonest end, by a
faithful and commendable policy, did provide for the mischief that might
ensue. I need not here rehearse the enimitie and debate that many years did
reign between our husbands fathers, because it is known and manifest unto
the whole City. We two therefore here present, the wives of those noble Gentle
men, brought up together from our Cradle, perceiving the malice between our
husbands, made a virtue of necessity, deemyng it better for us to lose our
sweet and anncient conversation, than to minister occasion of disquietnesse.
But the nerenesse of our houses would not that natural hatred should defrande
and take away (...) ingrafted amity. Wherefore many times when our husbands
were gone forth, we met together, and talked in our gardens, between which
there is but a thin hedge beset with primme and roses, which commodity in
their abse^ce we did discretely use. And as sometimes for pleasure we walked
with our husbands there, ye (she turning unto them) did cast your eyes upon
each others wife, and were straighte way in love, or else perchance you fained
your selves to be, which espied by us, many times between our selves did common
of the same, and red your amorous letters and song sent unto us. For which
dissoyaltie and treson toward us your wives, we sought no dishonor to your
persons, we were content to suffer you to be abused with your fond love, we
blabbed it not abroad to our gossips, as many leude and fantastical women be
wont to do, thereby to raise slander to our husbands, and to stir up ill
report upon them, whose infirmities it becomes us to conceile and hide. We
devised means by some other way to let you understand your fault, and did
cast upon you many times right loving looks. Which although it were against
our own desire, yet the cause and full conclusion of the same, was to practice,
if it were possible, to make you friends. But considering that this love and
allurementes of either parts, could not tend to other end, as we coniectured,
but to increse displeasure, and to put the swords into your hands, we therefore
consulted between our selves, and uniformly in one mind did agree for (...)
(...) and satisfaction of all parts, at such nights as ye fained to go into
diverse places about earnest affairs as ye alleged, Mistress Lucie with the
help of Cassandra my maid, through the Gardeine came into my chamber, and I by
means of Jane her maid by like way repaired unto hirs. And yt poor me^
guided by our maids were brought unto your chambers where ye lay with your own
wives, and so by tilthe of others land in strange soil (as ye believed) ye lost
no labor. And because your embraceme^ts then, were like to those achieved by
amorous Gentlemen, using us with more earnest desire than you were wo^t to do,
both we were begotten with child: which ought to be very gladsome and grateful
unto you, if ye were so feign to have children as ye showed your selves to be.
If then none other offense does grieve you, if remorse of conscience for other
cause does not offend you, if none other sorrow does displease you: Give over
your grief. Remit your displeasure. Be glad and joyful. Thank us for our
policy, and pleasant disport yt we made you. If hitherto ye have been enemies,
he^ceforth be friends, put of that ancient malice so long continued, mitigate
your hateful mood, and live ye from henceforthe like friendly Gentlemen,
yield up your rancor into the lap of your Country, yt she may put him in exile
for ever, who like a pitiful and loving mother would gladly see all her
children of one accord and mind. Which if ye do, ye shall do singular
pleasure to your friends, ye shall do great disco^fort to your foes, ye shall do
singular good to the common wealth, ye shall do greatest benefit to your selves,
ye shall make us humble wives, ye shall increase your posterity, ye shall be
praised of all men, (...) finally shall depart the best contented men yt ever
the world brought forth. And now because ye shall not think that we have piked
out this tale at our fingers ends, thereby to seek your sauegard and our fame
and praise, behold the letters which you sent us, behold your own hands
subscribed to the same, behold your seals assigned thereunto, which shall
render true testimony of that which unfeignedly we have affirmed. Then both
delivered their letters, which viewed and seen, were well known to be their own
husbands hands, and the same so well approved her tale, as their husbands were
the gladdest men of the world, and the Duke and seignorie maruelously satisfied
and contented. In so much as the whole asse^bly with one voice, cried out for
their husbands deliverance. And so with the consent of the Duke and the whole
seignorie they were clearly discharged. The parents, cosins and friends of the
husbands and wives were wonderfully amazed to here this long history, and
greatly praised the manner of their delivery, accompting the women to be very
wise, and mistress Isotta to be an eloquent gentlewoman, for that she had so
well defended the cause of their husbands and of themselves. Anselmo and
Girolamo openly in the presence of all the people embraced and kissed their
wives with great (...). And then the husbands shaked one an other by the
hands; between whom began a brotherly accord, and from that time forth lived
in perfect amity and friendship, exchaunging the wanton love that either of
the^ bare to others wife into brotherly friendship, to the great co^tentation
of the whole City. When the multitude assembled to hear this matter thoroughly
was satisfied, the Duke with cheereful countenance loking toward Gismonda,
said thus unto her: And you fair Gentlewoman, what have you to say? Be bold
to utter your mind, and we will gladly hear you. Mistress Gismonda bashful
to speak, began wonderfully to blush, into whose chekes entered an orient rud,
intermixed with an Alablaster white, which made her countenance more (...)
tha^ it was wont to be. After she had stood still a while (...) her eyes
declined toward the ground, in comely wise lifting the^ up again with shamfast
audacitie she began to say: If I most noble prince, in open audience should
attempt to speak of love, whereof I never had experience, or knew what thing it
was, I should be doubtful what to say thereof, and peradventure durst not open
mouth. But hering my father (of worthy memory) many times to tell yt your
majesty in ye time of your youth disdained not to open your heart to receive ye
amorous flames of love, and being assured yt there is none but that does love
little or much, I do not doubt but for the words which I shall speak, to obtain
both pity and pardon. To come then to ye matter: God I thank him of his
goodness, has not permitted me to be one of yt sort of women, yt like
hipocrites do mumble their Pater nosters to saints, appering outwardly to be
devout and holy and in fruit do bring forth devils, and all kinds of vices,
specially ingratitude, which is a vice that does suck and dry up the
fou^tain of godly piety. Life is dear to me (as naturally it is to all) next
which I esteem mine honor, that peradventure is to be preferred before life,
because without honor life is of no reputation. And where man and woman do live
in shame notorious to the world, ye same may be termed a living death rather
tha^ a life. But ye love yt I bear to mine only beloved master Aloisio here
present, I do esteem above al yt jewels and treasures of the world, whose
personage I do regard more tha^ mine own life. The reason yt moves me there to
is very great, for before yt I loved him, or ever me^t to fire my mind yt way,
he derely regarded me, continually devising which way he might win and obtain
my love, sparing no travel by night and day to seek ye same. For which tender
affection should I show my self unkind and froward? God forbid. And to be plain
with your honors, he is more dear and acceptable unto me, than yt balls of
mine own eyes, being the derest things that appertain to yt furniture of the
body of man, without which no earthly thing can be gladsom and joyful to ye
sense and feeling. Last of all, his amorous and affectionate demonstration of
his love toward me, by declaring him self to be careful of mine honor, rather
more willing to bestow his own, than to suffer the same to be touched with the
left suspicion of dishonestie, I can not choose, but so faithfully embrace, as
I am ready to guage my life for his sake, rather than his finger should ache for
yt offense. And where has there ben ever found such liberality in any lover?
What is he that has been ever so prodigal, to employ his life, the most
special pledge in this world, rather than he would suffer his beloved to
incur dishonor? Many histories have I red, and Chronicles of our time, and
yet I have found few or none comparable unto this Gentleman, the like of whom
be so rare and seldom as white crows or swannes of color black. O singular
liberality, never heard of before. O fact that can never be sufficiently
praised. O true love most unfeigned. Master Aloisio rather tha^ he would have my
fame any one jot to be impaired, or suffer any shadow of suspicion to blemish
the same, frankly has confessed himself to be a thief, regarding me and mine
honor more than himself and life. And albeit that he might a thousand ways
have saved himself without the imprisonment and adversity which he has
sustained: nevertheless after he had said, being then past remembrance through
the fall, that he fell down from my window, and perceived how much that
confession would prejudice and hurt my good name, and spotte the known honesty
of the same, of his good will chose to die rather than to speak any words that
might breed ill opinion of me, or the least thing of the world yt might
ingendre infamy and slander. And therefore not able to call back the words he
had spoken of the fall, nor by any means could color ye same, he thought to
save yt good name of another by his own hurt. If he then thus redily and
liberally has protruded his life to manifest danger for my benefit and
sauegard, preferring min honor above the care of himself, shall not I abandon
all that I have, yea and therwithall hazard mine honor for his salvation? But
what? Shall I disdain bountifully to employ my self and all the endeavor of my
friends for his delivery? No no (my Lords) if I had a thousand lives, and so
many honors at my commandment, I would give them al for his relief and
comfort, yea if it were possible for me to recover a fresh. x. C. M. lives, I
would so frankly bestow them all, as ever I desired to live, that I might enjoy
mine own Aloisio. But I am sorry, and ever shall be sorry, for that it is not
lawful for me to do more for him, tha^ yt which my small power and possibility
is able. For if he should die, truly my life could not endure: if he were
deprived of life, what pleasure should I have to live in this world after him?
whereby (most honorable and righteous judge,) I believe before the honest, not to
lose any one jot of mine honor, because I being (as you may see) and young
woman and a widow desirous to mary again, it is lawful for me to love and to
be beloved for none other intent (whereof God is the only judge) but to attain
a husband according to my degree. But if I should lose my reputation and honor,
why should not I adventure the same for him, that has not spared his own for
my sake? Now to come to the effect of the matter, I do say with all duetifull
reverence, that it is an accusation altogether false and untrue, that ever
master Aloisio came to my house as a Thief against my will. For what need he
to be a thief, or what would he do with my goods, that is a lord and owner
of. xx. times so much as I have? Alas good Gentleman, I dare depose and guage
my life, that he never thought, much less did any robbery or thing
unlawful, wherewith justly he may be charged. But he repaired to my house with
my consent, as a loving and affectionate lover, the circumstance whereof, if it
be duly marked, must aduouch the same to be of truth infallible. For if I
had not given him license to come, how was it possible for him to convey his
ladder so high, that was made but of ropes, and to fasten the same to the iaume
of the window, if none within did help him. Again, how could the window of
the chamber be open at that time of the night, which is still kept shut, if it
had not been by my consent. But I with the help of my maid threw down to
him a little rope, whereunto he tied his ladder and drew the same up, and making
it so fast, as it could not undo, and then made a sign for master Aloisio to
come up. But as both our ill fortune would have it, before I could catch any
hold of him, to mine inestimable grief and hearts sorrow he fell down to the
ground. Wherefore (my lords) I beseech your honors to revoke the confession
wherein he has made him self to be a thief. And you master Aloisio declare
the troth as it was, since I am not ashamed in this honorable assembly to tell
the same. Behold the letters (my lords) which so many times he wrote unto me,
wherein he made suit to come to my speech, and continually in the same does
call me wife. Behold the ladder, which till now, did still remain in my
chamber. Behold my maid, which in all mine affairs, is as it were mine own
hand and helper. Master Aloisio being here upon demanded of the Lords of the
articles, which she in her tale had recited, confessed them all to be true: who
at the same instant was discharged. The Duke greatly commended them both, her
for her stout audacitie, in defense of an innocent Gentleman, and him for his
honor and modesty, seeking to preserve the fame and good report of the
Gentlewoman. Which done, the Counsel disassembled and brake up. And the
friends of both the parties accompanied them home to the house of mistress
Gismonda, where to the great rejoice and pleasure of al men, they were
solemnly married in sumptuous and honorable wise, and master Aloisio with his
wife lived in great prosperity long time after. Mistress Lucia and mistress
Isotta, at the expired time were delivered of two goodly sons, in whom the
fathers took great joy and delight. Who with their wives after that time lived
very quietly and well, one loving an other like natural brethren, many times
sporting among them selves discretely at the deceipts of their wives. The
wisdom of the Duke also was wonderfully extolled and commended of all men, the
fame whereof was increased and bruted throughout the region of Italy, And not
without cause. For by his prudence and advise, the dominion of the state and
Common wealth was amplified and dilated. And yet in the end being old and
impotent, they unkindly deposed him from his Dukedom.

The Lord of Virle
The Lord of VIRLE, by the commandment of a a fair young widow called ZILIA,
and for his promise made, the better to attain her love, was contented to
remain dumb the space of three years, and by what means he was revenged,
and obtained his suit.

The. xxvij. Nouel.
THey that have passed the most part of their youth in humain folies, and have
rather followed the vanities of fools and insensate lovers, in matters of
love, and that the contemplation of heavenly things, or else of those that here
on earth may give some entry for man to attain glory and honor of his name,
they I say, shall serve me for witnesses, to confirm the opinion of long time
rooted in the fancies of men: which is, that the beauty and comely favor of a
woman, is the very true and natural Adamant that can be found, since the same
stone (for a certain attractiue power and agreeable quality therein enclosed)
does not better draw the iron, than ye woman does, by a certain hidden force,
which resting under ye allureme^t of her eye, draws unto it yt hearts and
affections of men, which has made many beleene, that the same only essence
was sent to us below, to serve both for men's torment and joy together. But yet
there is an other thing of greater wonder it is not to hear tell that Paris for
sooke Troy, to go visit Helena in Greece, that Hercules had given over his
mace, to handle the (...) at the commandment of a woman, or that Solomon was
sotted in his wisdom to dalie with those that made him a volu^tarie slave. But
that a woman of whom a man had received no favor and courtesy at all, had
forgotten her own duty to her servant, if it seem not strange, I can not
tell what to call wonderful or marvelous: if defense of speech for love, is
not deemed such, whereby man is different from brute beasts: (for reason is
altogether refused by lovers, and notwithstanding our fathers have seen the
example of that virtue no long time past in the person of a Gentleman, very
wise and well trained up in other things. A case so strange as declaring the
singular force of nature in that matter, wherein the seems to have given ye
preferme^nt above all things in earth. Examples hereof, is the effemination of
Hercules, the deprivation of Samsons strength, the loss of sense, and the
idolatry of the famous and wise king Solomon, and the simplicity of a
warelesse and uncircumspect Gentleman, of whom ye shall read the History.

Thurin (as is well known to them that have traveled Piedmont) is the
ornament and bulwark of all the country, so well for the natural site of the
place, as for the artificial and industrious work of man's hand, which has
instaured and furnished with great magnificence, that which nature had
indifferently enriched, for the rudeness and little knowledge of the time past.
Now besides this stately and strong city, there stands a little town named
Montcall, a place no less strong, and of good defense, than well planted in a
fair and rich soil. In this town there dwelt a Gentlewoman a widow called
Zilia, beautiful amongs the most excellent fair Gentlewomen of the country,
which country (besides the other happy and heavenly influences) seems to be
specially favored, for having the most fairest and courteous Gentlewome^, above
any other within the compass of Europa. Notwithstanding this fair Zilia,
degenerating from the nature of her climate, was so haggarde and cruel, as it
might have been thought. she had been rather nourished and brought up amidde
the most desert mountains of Sauoy, than in the pleasant and rich champayn
country, watered and moistened with Eridanus, the father of rivers, at this day
called the Pau, the largeness whereof does make men to marvel, and the
fertility allureth every man to be desirous to inhabit upon the same. This
fair rebellious widow, albeit that she was not above. xxiiij. or. xxv. years
of age, yet protested never more to be subject to man, by marriage, or
otherwise, thinking her self well able to live in single life: A mind truly
very holy and commendable, if the pricks of yt flesh do obey the first motions
and adhortations of the spirit, but where youth, pleasure, and multitude of
suitors do address their endeavor against that chastity (lightly enterprised)
the Apostles counsel ought to be followed, who wills young widows to marie
in Christ, to avoid the temptations of the flesh, and to flee offensive
slander and dishonor before men. Now mistress Zilia (her husband being dead)
only bent her self to enrich her house, and to amplify the possession of a
little infant which she had by her late departed husband. After whose death she
became so covetous, as having removed, and almost cut off quite the wonted
port she used in her husbands days, employed her maids in household affairs,
thinking nothing to be well done yt passed not through her own hands. A thing
truly more praise worthy, than to see a sort of effeminate, fine, and dainty
fingred dames, which think their honor diminished if they hold but their nose
over their household matters, where their hand and diligence were more
requisite, for so much as the mistress of the house is not placed the chief
to hear only the reasons of them that labor, but thereunto to put her hands,
for her present eye seems to give a certain perfection to the work which
the servants do by her commandment. Which caused the historians in times
past, to describe unto the posterity a gentlewoman called Lucretia, not
babbling amongs young folish girls, or running to feasts and Maigames, or
Masking in the night, without any regard of the honor and dignity of her race
and house, but in her Chamber sowing, spinning, and carding, amids the troop
of her maiden servants: wherein our mistress Zilia passed the most part of her
time, spending no minute of the day, without some honest exercise, which she
did for that she liked not to be seen at feasts and bankets, or to be gadding
up and down the streats, wandering to gardens or places of pleasure, although
to such places youth sometimes may have honest repair to refreshe their
wearied bodies with some virtuous recreation, and thereby to rejoice the
heaviness of the mind. But this Ge^tlewoman was so severe in following the
rigorous and constrained manners of our ancients, that impossible it was, to
see her abroad, except it were when she went to Mattens or other divine
service. This Gentlewoman seemed to have studied the divinity of the
Egiptians, which paint Venus holding a key before her mouth, and setting her
foot upon a Tortus, signifying unto us thereby, yt duty of a chaste woman,
whose tongue ought to be locked, that she speak not but in time and place, and
her feet not straying or wa^dering, but to keep her self within the limits of
her own house, except it be to serve God, and sometimes to render our bounden
duty to them which have brought us into light. Moreover Zilia was so religious
(I will not say superstitious) and rigorous to observe customs, as she made it
very squeimish and strange to kiss Gentlemen that met her, a civility which
of long time has been observed, and yet remains in the most part of the
world, that Gentlewomen do welcome strangers and guestes into their houses
with an honest and chaste kiss. Notwithding the institution and profession of
this widow had wiped away and deferred this point of her youth: whither it
were for that she esteemed her self so fair, as all men were unworthy to
touch the utter parts of so rare and precious a vessel, or that her great
and inimitable chastity made her so strange, to refuse that which her duty
and honor would have permitted her to grant. There chanced about this time
that a gentleman of the Country called Sir Philiberto of Virle, esteemed to be
one of the most valiant Gentlemen in those parts, repaired upon an holy day to
Montcall, (whose house was not very far off the Town) and being at divine
service, in place of occupying his sense and mind in heavenly things, and
attending the holy words of a Preacher, which that day declared the word of
God unto the people, he gave himself to contemplate the excellent beauty of
Zilia, who had put off for a while her mourning veil, that she might the
better behold the good father that preached, and receive a little air,
because the day was extreme hot. The Gentleman at the first blushe, when he
saw that sweet temptation before his eyes, thought him self rapt above the
third heaven, and not able to withdraw his look, he fed himself with the
venom which by little and little, so seized upon the soundest parts of his
mind, as afterward being lively rooted in heart, the Gentleman was in
danger still to remain there for a guage, without any hope of ease or
comfort, as more amply this following discourse, shall give you to understand.
Thus all the morning he beheld the Gentlewoman, who made no more account of
them, that with great admiration did behold her, than they themselves did of
their life, by committing the same to the hands of a woman so cruel. This
Gentleman being come home to his lodging, enquired what fair widow that was,
of what calling, and of what behauior, but he heard tell of more truly, than
he would of good will have known or desired to have been in her, whom he did
presently choose to be the only mistress of his most secret thoughts. Now
understanding well the stubburne nature and uncivil manner of that widow, he
could not tell what part to take, nor to what Saint to vow his devotion, to
make suit unto her he thought it time lost, to be her servant, it was not in
his power, having already inguaged his liberty into the hands of her, which
once holdyng captive the hearts of men, will not infraunchise them so soon as
thought and will desire. Wherefore bayting himself with hope, and tickled
with love, he determined what soever chanced, to love her, and to assay if by
long service he could lenifie that hard heart, and make tender that unpliant
will, to have pity upon the pain which she saw him to endure, and to
recompense his laborsome travels, which he thought were virtuously employed for
gayning of her good grace. And upon this settled deliberation, he retired
again to Virle (so was his house named) where disposing his things in order,
he returned again to Montcall to make his long resiance there, to put in
readiness his furniture, and to welde his artillery with such industry, as
in the end he might make a reasonable breach to force and take the place: For
surprisyng whereof, he hazarded great dangers, the rather, that he him self
might first be taken. And where his assaults and policies could not prevail,
he minded to content him self with the pleasure and passetyme that he might
receive in the contemplation of a thing so fair, and the ordinary sight of an
image so excellent. The memory of whom rather increased his pain than yielded
comfort, did rather minister corrosiue poison, than give remedy of ease, a
cause more of cruel and sudden death, than of prolonged life. Philiberto then
being become a citizen of Mo^tcall, used to frequent the Church more than he
was wont to do, or his devotion served him, and that because he was not able
elsewhere to enjoy the presence of his Saint, but in places and temples of
devotion: which no doubt was a very holy and worthy disposition, but yet
not meet or requisite to observe such holy places for those intentes, which
ought not to be profaned in things so fond and foolish, and acts so
contrary to the institution and mind of those, which in times paste were the
first founders and erectours of temples. Signior Philiberto then moved with
that religious superstition, made no conscience at all to speak unto her
within the Church. And true it is, when she went out of the same, he (moved
with a certain familiar courtesy, natural to each Gentleman of good bryngyng
up) many times conducted her home to her own house, not able for all that
(what so (...) he said) to win the thing that was able to engender any little
contentation, which grieved him very much: For the cruel woman fained as
though (...) understood nothing of that he said, and turnyng the wayne against
the oxen, by contrary talk she began to tell him a tale of a tubbe, of matters
of her householde, whereunto he gave so good heed, as she did to the hearing of
his complaints. Thus these two, of diverse affections, and moved with contrary
thoughts, spoke (...) to an other, without apt answer to eithers talk. Whereby
ye Gentleman conceived an assured argument of his ruin, which void of al hope
and means, he saw to be inevitable, and therefore practiced with (...) dames
of the City, that had familiar resort unto her house, and used frequent
conversation with (...) rebellious lady Zilia. To one of them then he
determined to communicate his secrets, and to do her to understand in deed the
only cause that made him to (...) at Montcall, and the grief which he
sustained, for that he was not able to discover his torment to her, that had
given him the wound. This Gentleman therefore, repaired to one of his
neighbors, a woman of good courage, which at other (...) had experimented what
meats they feed on, which (...) at Venus table, and what bitterness is
intermingled, amid those drinks that Cupido quaffeth unto his guestes. (...)
whom (having before coniured her to keep secret that which he would declare) he
disclosed the secrets of his mind, expressing his love without naming of his
lady before he herd the answer of his neighbor, who understanding almost to
what purpose the affections of the pacient were directed, said unto him: Sir,
needful it is not to use long orations, the love that I bear you for the
honest qualities which hitherto I have known to be in you, shall make me to
keep silent, that whereof as yet I do not know the matter, and the assurance
you have, not to be abused by me, constrains me to warrant you, that I will
not spare to do you all the pleasure and honest service I can. Ah mistress
(answered sir Philiberto) so long as I live, I will not fail to acknowledge
the liberality of your (...), by offering your self pacientely to hear, and
secretly to keep the words I speak, accorduigly as they deserve: and that
(which is more than I require) you do assure me that I shall find such one
of you, as will not spare to give your aid. Alas, I resemble the good and wise
Captain, who to take a (...) does not only aid himself with the
forwardenesse and valiance of his soldiers, but to spare them, and to avoid
slaughter for making of way, planteth his cannon, and battereth the wall of the
fort, which he would assail, to the intent that both the soldier and the
ordinance may perform and suffice the perfection of the platte, which he
has framed and devised within his politic head. I have already encouraged my
soldiers, and have lost the better part truly in the skirmish which has
delivered unto me my sweet cruel enemy. Now I am driven to make ready the
fire, which rests in the kindled match of your co^ceipts, to batter yt fort
hitherto (...), for any assault which I can make. I understand not (said she
smiling) these Labyrinthes of your complaints, except you speak more plain. I
never haunted the wars, (...) knew (...) thing it is to handle weapons,
improper and not seemly for mine estate and kind. The war (quod he) whereof
I speak, is so natural and common, as I doubt not, but you have somtymes
(...), with what (...) and camisados men use to take their enemies, how they
plant their (...), (...) what means both the assaylant and (...) ought to
use. So far as I see (said she) there (...) nothing for us, but the assurance
of the field, since we be ready to enter in combat: and do think that the fort
shall not be hard to win, by reason of the walls, dikes, rampars, bulwarks,
platformes, counterforts, curtines, vamewres and engines which you have
prepared, besides a number of false brayes and flanks, placed in good order,
and the whole defended from the thundryng cannons and bombardes, which do
amaze the wandering enemy in the field. But I pray you leaving these warlike
tumults, to speak more boldly without these extrauagantes and digressions, for
I take pity to see you thus troubled, and ready to excede the bounds of your
modesty and wonted wisdom. Do not marvel at all mistress (quod he) since
according to new occurrents and alterations, both the purpose, talk, and
counsel ordinarily do change. I am become the servant of one which makes me
altogether like unto those that (...) mad, and bound in chains, not able to
speak or say any thing, but what the spirits which be in them, do force them
to utter. For I neither will, think, or (...) any thing, but that which the
enchaunter Love does command and suffer to express, who, so rigorously does
(...) my heart, that in place where boldness is most requisite, he depriueth
me of force, and leaves me without any countenance. And being alone, God (...)
how frankly I do wander in the place, where mine enemy may command, and
with what (...) I do invade her province. Alas, is it not pity then to see
these diversities in one self matter, and upon one very thing? Truly I would
endure willyngly all these travails, if I (...) in the end my service might be
accepted, and hoped that my (...) should find relief: but living in this (...),
I must needs norish the (...) and the solace of the unhappy, which are wishes
and vain hope, trusting that some God, will (...) me a faithful friend that
will assaye to rid me from the hell wherinto I am thrown, or else to shorte^
this miserable life, which is a (...) times more painful than death. In saying
so, he began to sigh so strangely as a man would have thought that two smithes
(...) working at the (...), had given two blows at his stomach, so vehement was
the enclosed wind within his heart, that made him to fetch forth those
terrible (...), the eyes not forgetting to yield forth a river of tears, which
gushing forth at the center of his heart, mounted into his brains, at length
to issue forth, through the spout proper to the channel of such a fountain.
Which the gentlewoman seeing, moved with compassion, could not contain to keep

reputation, which to this day I have kept unspotted, defend the use of my good
will in things yt may (...) mine honor, yet sir by seeing the extremity which

you with so good heart, as (...) you trust me with the secrets of your thought.
There rests only for me to know, the thing that you will have me to do, and
toward what woman your devotions be inclined: for sure I am to give her such
(...) of that which I have seen and known of your good will and service toward
the mistress of your heart, that (...) shall be altogether out of taste, and
void of appetite, (...) she do not accept that affectionate offered will, the
like whereof shall never be proffered again. And truly such a woman may judge
her self right happy to have a Gentleman, so (...), (...) and faithful, for
(...) and lover, which honoring and serving her beauty (...) good (...), is

forth in these days like (...), men being grown to (...) disloyalty, as in

the same, in the soil of women's hearts: and they not able to depart the

Finishing these words she took her leave of Zilia, and arrived to the lovers

great gladsom cheer, through the glistering show before mine eyes of the faint

thrust me forth into a thousand winds, tempests, and raging storms of rain.
By means whereof I see no mean at all to hope for end of my mishaps: and much
less the shipwreck which suddenly may rid me from this danger more
intolerable, than if I were overwhelmed within the bottomless depth of the

follow thee by trace, and pleasantly subdue themselves to thy traitorous
folies? At lest wise if I saw some hope of health I would endure without

what is he of whom I speak? Of whom do I attend for solace and relief? of

Of the most noysom poison that ever was myngled with the most subtle druggs
that ever were. Whom shall I take to be my defender? He which is in ambush

that: be affectionate to a service so just and good. Ah Basiliske, colored

throughout mine heart? At least wise if I had some drugge to repel thy

feel and prove that this sentence is more than true:

No physike herbs the grief of love can cure,
Ne yet no drugge that pain can well assure.
Alas, the sear clothe will not serve, to tense the wound the time shall be
but lost, to cut the same is but increase of pain, to salve the same bredeth
matter to cause mine overthrow. To be short, any dressing can not avail,
except the hand of her alone which gave the wound. I would to God the saw the
bottom of my heart, and viewed the closet of any mind, yt she might judge my
firm says and know the wrong she does me by her rigor and froward will. But O
unhappy man, I feel that she is so resolved in obstinate mind, as her rest
seems only to depend upon my pain, her ease upon my grief, and her joy upon

Now when sir Philiberto saw the messanger, he said unto her: And how now

which suffers him self so fondly to be charmed, (...) the peril of the abused
ought to serve him for example. They be to the masculine kind a great
confusion, and unawares for want of due forsight, the same (...) suffer it self
to be bound and taken captive by ye very thing which has no being to work
effect, but by his own freewil. But this inchantme^t which rises of women's
beauty, being to men a pleasant displeasure, I think to be decked with that
drawing virtue and allurement, to punish and torment the faults of men, for
they once fed and baited with a fading favor and poisoned sweetness, forget
their own perfection, and nousled in their foolish fancies, seeking felicity
and sovereign gift, in the matter wherein does lie the sum of their
vnhappes. In like manner the virtuous and shamfast dames, have not their eyes of
mind so blindfolde, but that they see whereunto those frank services, (...)

and doubt not but those lovers do imitate the Scorpion, whose venom lies in
his tail, the end of such love, being the ruin of good renoume, and the
decay of former virtues. For which cause the heavens, the friend of their
sex, have given them a providence, which those gentle, vnfauoured lovers term
