said unto him: I shall see by and by sir, if that love which you (...) to bear
me, be so vehement as you seem to make. Ah Madame (said the unadvised lover)
commau^d only, and you shall see with what devotion I will perform your will,
were it that it should cost me the price of my proper life. You shall have
(quod she) the kiss which you require of me if you will make promise, and
swear by the says of a Gentleman, to do the thing which I shall command,
without fraud, couin, or other delay. Madame (said the over wilful lover) I
take God to witness that of the thing which you shall command I will not
leave one jot (...), but shall be executed to the uttermost of your request
and will. She hearing him swear with so good affection, said unto him smiling:
Now then upon your oath which I believe, and assured of your virtue and Noble
nature, I will also perform and keep my promise: And saying so, she embraced
him and kissed him very lovingly. The pore gentleman not knowing how (...) he
had brought that dissauorable favor, and bitter sweetness, held her a while
between his arms, doubling kiss upon kiss, with such pleasure, as his soul
thought to fly up to the heavens with that impoisoned baulme which he sucked
in the sweet and sugared breath of his cruel mistress: who undoing her self
out of her lovers arms, said unto him: Since that I have made the first
disclosure both of the promise and the effect thereof, it behooves that you
perform that which rests, for the full accomplishment of the same. Come on
hardily (says he) and God knows how spedily you shall be obeyed. I will then
(quod she) and command you upon your promised faith, yt from this present
time, until yt space of three years be expired, you speak to no living person
for any thing that shall happen unto you, nor yet express by tongue, by sound
of word, or speech, the thing you want or desire, otherwise if you shall do,
I will never trust living man for your sake, but will publishe your same to be
villainous, and your person perjured, and a promise breaker. I leave for you to
think whether this unhappy lover were amazed or not, to hear such a strange
request and commandment so unjust, and therwithall the difficulty in the
performance. Notwithstanding he was so stout of heart, and so religious an
obseruer of his (...), that at that very time he began to do the part which she
had commanded, playing (...), and using other signs, that he would do his
duty, according to her demand. Thus after his right humble reverence unto
her, he went home, where fayning that he had lost his speech by means of a
Catarre or reume which distilled from his brain, he determined to forsake his
country until the time of his penance was expired. Wherefore setting stay in
his affairs, and prouidyng for his train, he made him ready to depart.
Notwithstanding, he wrote a Letter unto Zilia, before he took his journey,
which was toward the country of France, that in old time has beue the
solace and refuge of the miserable, as well for the pleasantness and
temperature of the air, the great wealth and the abundaunce of all things,
as for the courtesy, gentleness, and familiarity of the people: which may
compare with any other Nation upon the earth.

Now the Letter of Philiberto, fell into the hands of Lady Zilia, by means
of his Page instructed for that purpose: who advertised her of the departure of
his master, and of the despair wherein he was. Whereof she was somewhat
sorye, and offended: but yet puttyng on her aunciente severity, took the
Letters, and breakyng the seal, found that which follows.

THE very evil that causes mine anoy
The matter is that bredes to me my joy,
Which does my woeful heart full sore displease,
And yet my hap and hard ill luck does ease.
I hope one day when I am frank and free,
To make her do the thing that pleases me,
Whereby gain I shall, some pleasant gladness,
To supply mine undeserved sadness,
The like whereof no mortal Dame can give
To loving man that here on earth does live.
This great good turn which I on her pretend,
Of my conceits the full desired end,
Proceeds from thee (O cruel mystres mine)
Whose froward heart has made me to resign
The full effect of all my liberty
(To please and ease thy fond fickle fancy)
My use of speech, in silence to remain:
To every wight a double hellish pain.
Whose faith had thou not wickedly abusde
No stresse of pain for thee had been refusde,
Who was to thee a trusty servant sure,
And for thy sake all dangers would endure.
For which thou have defaced thy good name,
And there unto procurde eternal shame.
I That roaring tempest huge which thou have made me felt,
The raging storms whereof, well nere my heart has swelt
By painful pangs: whose waltering waves by troubled skies
And thousand blastes of wind that in those seas do rise
Do promise shipwreck sure of that thy sailing Bark
When after weather clear does rise some tempest dark.
For either I or thou which art of Tygres kind,
In that great raging gulf some danger sure shall find,
Of that thy nature rude the dest'nies enemies be,
And thy great overthrow full well they do foresee.
The heavens unto my estate no doubt great friendship shoe
And do seek ways to end, and finish all my woe.
This penance which I bear by yelding to thy hest
Great store of joys shall heap, and bring my mind to rest.
And when I am at ease amids my pleasant happes,
Then shall I see thee fall, and suarlde in Fortunes trapes.
Then shall I see thee banne and curse the wicked time
Wherein thou made me gulpe such draught of poisoned wine.
By which thy mortal cup, I am the offered wight,
A vowed sacrifice, to that thy cruel spite.
Wherefore my hoping heart, does hope to see the day,
That thou for silence now, to me shall be the pray.
I O blessed God most just, whose worthy laud and praise
With uttered speech in Skies aloft I dare not once to raise,
And may not well pronounce and speak what suffrance I sustain,
Ne yet what death I do endure, whiles I in life remain.
Take vengeance on that traitresse rude, afflict her corpse with woe,
Thy holy arm redress her fault, that she no more do so.
My reason has not so far strayed, but I may hope and trust
To see her for her wickedness, be whipped with plague most just:
In the mean while, great hauinesse my sense and soul does bite,
And shaking fever vex my corpse for grief of her despite.
My mind now set at liberty, from thee (O cruel dame)
Does give defiance to thy wrath, and to thy cursed name,
Proclamyng mortal war on thee, until my tongue untied
Shall joy to speak to Zilia fast weeping by my side.
The heue^s forbid, that causeless wrong abroad should make his vau^t,
Or that an undeserved death, forget full tomb should haunt:
But that in written book and verse their names should ever live,
And eke their wicked deeds should die, and virtues still reuine.
So shall the pride and glory both, of her be punished right,
By length of years, and tract of time. And I by virtues might
Full recompense thereby shall have, and stand still in good fame,
And she like caitife wretch shall live, to her long lasting shame.
Whose fond regard of beauties grace, contemned has the force
Of my true love full fixed in her: her heart void of remorse,
Esteemed it self right foolishely, and me abused still,
Usurping my good honest faith and credit at her will.
Whose loyal faith does rest in soul, and therein still shall bide,
Until in filthy stinking grave, the earth my corpse shall hide.
Then shall that soul fraught with that faith, to heue^s make his (...).
And rest among the heavenly rout, bedeckt with sacred air. (pair,
And thou for thy great cruelty, as God above does know,
With rufull voice shall weep and wail for thy great overthrow,
And when thou would fain purge thy self for that thy wretched
No kindness shall to thee be done, extreme shall be thy mede (deed
And where my tongue does want his will, thy mischief to display
My hand and pen supplies the place, and shall do so always.
For so thou have constrainde the same by force of thy behest:
In silence still my tongue to keep, t'accomplishe thy request.
Adieu, farewell my tormenter, thy friend that is full mute,
Does bid thee farewell once again, and so he ends his suit.
He that lives only, to be revenged of thy cruelty, Philiberto of Virle.


Zilia like a disdainful woman made but a jest at the letters and complaints
of the infortunat lover, saying that she was very well content with his
service. And that when he should perform the time of his probatiou, she should
see if he were worthy to be admitted into the fellowship of them which had made
sufficient proof of the order and rule of love. In the mean time Philiberto
rode by great iourneys (as we have said before) toward the goodly and pleasant
Country of France. wherein Charles the seventh that time did reign, who
miraculously (but give the French man leave to flatter and speak well of his
own Country, according to the flattering and vaunting nature of that Nation)
chased ye English men out of his lands and ancient Patrimony in the year of
our Lord. 1451. This king had his camp then warfaring in Gascoine, whose luck
was so fortunate as he expeld his enemies, and left no place for the^ to
fortify in the said Country, which encouraged the king to follow that good
occasion, and by prosecuting his victorious fortune, to profligat out of
Normandy, and to dispatch himself of that enemy, into whose hands and
servitude the Country of Guiene was rightly delivered and victoriously won
and gotten by the Englishmen. The king then being in his Camp in Normandy,
the Piedmont Gentleman the Lord of Virle aforesaid, repaired thereunto to serve
him in his person, where he was well known of some Captains which had seen
him at other times, and in place where worthy Gentlemen are wont to frequent,
and in the Duke of Sauoyes court, which the Frenchmen did very much (...),
because the Earl of Piedmont that then was Duke of Sauoy had married Iolanta
the second daughter of Charles the seventh. These Gentlemen of France were
very much sorry for the misfortune of the Lord of Virle, and knowing him to be
one of the brauest and lustiest men of arms that was in his time within the
Country of Piedmont, presented him before the King, commending unto his grace
the virtue, gentleness, and valianee of the man of war: Who after he had
done his (...) according to his duty, which he knew full well to do, declared
unto him by signs that he was come for none other intent, but in those wars
to serve his majesty: whom the king heard and tha^kfully received, assuring
himself and promising very much of the (...) Gitlema^ for respect of his
personage which was comely and well proportioned, and therefore represented some
force and great dexterity: and that which made the king the better to fantasy
yt gentleman, was ye report of so many worthy me^ which extolled even to yt
heane^s ye prowess of yt Piedmont knight. Whereof he gave assured testimony in
yt assault which yt king made to deliver (...) the chief City and defense of
all (...) in ye year of our Lord. 1451. where Philiberto behaved himself so
(...) as he was yt first yt mounted upon yt walls, and by his dexterity and
invincible force, made way to the soldiers in the breche, whereby a little while
after they entered and sacked ye enemies, driving the^ out of yt City, and
wherein not long before, yt is to say. 1430. yt Duke of Somerset caused loan yt
Pucelle to be burnt. The King advertised of yt service of the du^be Gentleman,
would reco^pense him according to his desert, and because he knew him to be of
a good house, he made him a Gentleman of his chamber, and gave him a good
pension, promising him moreover to continue his liberality, when he should see
him prosecute in time to come, yt towardness of service which he had so happily
begone. The du^be Gentleman thanking the king very humbly, both for yt present
princely reward, and for promise in time to come, lifted up his hand to heaven,
as taking God to witness of the faith, which inviolable he promised to keep
unto his Prince: which he did so earnestly, as hardely he had promised, as well
appeared in a skirmish between yt French, and their ancient enemies the English
men, on whose side was ye valiant and hardy Captain the Lord Talbot, who has
eternized his memory in ye victories obtained upon yt people, which sometimes
made Europa and Asia to tremble, and appalled ye monstrous and warlike Country
of Africa. In this conflict the Piedmont knight joined with the lord Talbot,
against who^ he had so happy success, as upon yt shock and (...), he overthrew
both man and horse, which caused ye disco^fiture of yt English me^: who after
they had horssed again their captain, (...) amain, leaving the (...) bespred with
dead bodies and bludshed of their co^panio^s. This victory recovered such (...)
and boldness to yt French, as from yt time forth the English me^ began with
their places and forts to lose also their hearts to defend themselves. The king
excedingly well contented with the prowess and valia^ce of the dumb gentleman,
gave him for service past the charge of v. C. men of arms, and endued him with
some possessions, attending better fortune to make him understand how much ye
virtue of valiance ought to be rewarded and cherished by Princes that be aided
in their necessity with the diligence of such a virtuous and Noble Gentleman.
In like manner when a Prince has something good in himself, he can do no less
but cherish yt which (...) himself by Princely conditions, since yt virtue in
what so ever place it takes root, can not choose but produce good fruit, yt
use whereof far surmounts them all which aproche yt place, where these first
seeds were thrown. Certain days after, the king desirous to reioyee his
Knights and Captains that were in his train, and desirous to extinguish quite
the woeful time which so (...) space held France in fearful silence, caused
(...) triumph of Turney to be proclaimed within the City of Roane, wherein the
Lord of Virle was deemed and esteemed one of the best, which further did
increase in him the good will of ye king, in such wise as he determined to
procure his health, and to make him have his speech again. For he was very
sorry that a gentleman so valiant was not able to express his mind, which if
it might be had, in council would serve the state of common wealth, so well as
the force and valor of his body had til then served for defense and recovery of
his places. And for that purpose he made Proclamation by sound of Trumpet
throughout the Countries as well within his own kingdom, as the regions
adjoining upon the same, yt who so ever could heal that dumb Gentleman, should
have ten thousand Frankes for recompense. A man might have then seen
thousands of Physicians assembled in field, not to skirmish with the English
me^, but to combat for reward in recovery of the Pacients speech, and begone
to make such war against those ten thousand Franks, as the King was afraid
that the cure of that disease could take no effect: and for that cause ordained
furthermore, that who so ever would take in hand to heal the dumb, and would
not keep promise within a certain prefixed time, should pay the said sum, or
for default thereof should pledge his head in gage. A man might then have seen
those Physic masters, as well beyond yt Mountains, as in France it self,
retire home again, bleeding at the nose, cursing with great impiety their
Patrones, Galen, Hypocrates and Auicen, and blamed with more than reprochful
words, the Art wherewith they fished for honor and richesse. This brute was
spread so far, and babbling Fame had already by mouth of Trumpe published ye
same throughout the most part of the Provinces, Towns, and Cities near and
far off to France, in such wise as a man would have thought that the two young
men (which once in the time of the Macedonian wars brought tidings to
Vatinius that the King of (...) was taken by the Consul Paulus Emilius) had
been vagant and wa^dering abroad to carry news of the Kings edicte for the
healing of the Lord of Virle. Which caused that not only the brute of the
Proclamation, but also the credit and reputation wherein the said Lord was with
the French King, came even to Montcall, and passed from mouth to mouth, til at
length Zilia the principal cause thereof understood the news, which reioysed
her very much, seeing ye firm amity of the dumb Lord, and the sincere faith
of him in a promise unworthy to be kept, for so much as, where (...) and fear
bear swinge in hearts of men, religion of promise, specially the place of the
given faith, gives over his force and reuolteth, and is no more bound but to
that which by good will he would observe. Now thought she, thought? nay rather
she assured her self, that the Gentleman for all his written letter was so
surprised with her love, and kindled with her fire in so ample wise, as when he
was at (...): and therefore determined to go to Paris, not for desire she had
to see her pacient and penetenciarie, but rather for couetise of the ten
thousand Fra^ks, whereof already she thought her self assured, making good
account that the dumb Gentleman seeing himself discharged by her of his
promise, for gratifying of her, would make no stay to speak, to the intent she
might bear away both the (...) and money which all others had (...) till that
time. Thus you see that she whom honest amity and long service could little
induce to compassion and desire to give some ease unto her most earnest lover,
yielded her self to covetous gain and gredinesse for to increase her richesse.
O curssed hunger of Money, how long will thou thus blind the reason and
sprites of men? Ah perilous gulf how many have thou overwhelmed within thy
botto^lesse throat, whose glory, had it not been for thee, had surpassed ye
clouds, and been equal with the brightness of the Sun, where now they be
obscured with the thickness of thy fogges and palpable darkness. Alas the
fruits which thou bring forth for all thine outward appearance, conduce no
felicity to them that be thy possessors, for the dropsey that is hidden in
their mind, which makes them so much the more thirsty, as they drink often in
that thirsty Fountain, is cause of their alteration: and most miserable is
that insaciable desire the Covetous have to glut their appetite, which can
receive no contentation. This only (...) sometimes procured the death of the
great and rich Roman Crassus, who through Gods punishment fell into the hands
(...) the Persians, for violating and sacking the Temple of God that was in
Jerusalem. Sextimuleus burning with Covetousness and gredinesse of money, did
once cut of the head of his patron and defender Caius (...) the Tribune of the
people, incited by the Tyrant, which tormenteth the hearts of the couctous. I
will not speak of a good number of other examples in people of all kinds, and
diverse nations, to come again to Zilia. Who forgetting her virtue, the first
ornament and shining quality of her honest behauior, feared not the weariness
and travail of way, to commit her self to the danger of loss of (...), and to
yield to the mercy of one, unto whom she had done so great injury, as her
conscience (if she had not lost her right sense) ought to have made her
think that he was not without desire to revenge yt wrong (...) done unto him,
and specially being in place where she was not known, and he greatly honored
and esteemed, for whose love that Proclamation and search of Physic was made
and ordained. Ziha then having put in order her affairs at home, departed from
Montcall, and passing the Mountes, arrived at Paris, at such time as greatest
despair was had of the dumb Knights recovery. When she was arrived there,
within few days after she inquired for them that had the charge to entertain
such as came, and would take upon them the cure of the said pacient. For (said
she) if there be any man in the world, through whom the Knight may get his
health, I hope in God that I am she which shall have the praise. Hereof the
Commissaries deputed hereunto, were advertised, who caused the fair Physician
to come before them, and asked her if it were she, that would take upon her to
cure this dumb Gentleman. To whom she answered, my masters it has pleased
God to reveal unto me a certain secret very proper and meet for the cure of
his malady, wherewithal if the pacient will, I hope to make him speak so
well, as he did these two years past and more. I suppose said one of the
Commissaries, that you be not ignorant of the (...) of the Kings Proclamation.
I know full (quod she) the effect thereof, and therefore do say unto you, that I
will loose my life if I do not accomplish that which I do promise, upon
condition that I may have license to tarry with him alone, because it is of no
less importance than his health. It is no marvel said the Commissary,
considering your beauty, which is sufficient to frame a new tongue in the most
(...) person, yt is under the heavens. And therefore do your endeavor, assuring
you, that you shall do a great pleasure unto the King, and besides the praise
which you shall acquire, get the good will of the dumb gentleman which is the
most excellent man of the world, and therefore shall be so well recompensed, as
you shall have good cause to be routented with the Kings liberality. But (to
the intent you be not deceived) the meaning of the Proclamation is, that
within. xv. days after you begin ye cure, you must make him hole, or else to
satisfy the pains ordained in the same. Whereunto she submitted her self,
blinded by Avarice and presumption, thinking that she had like power over the
Lord of Virle, as when she gave him that sharp and cruel penance. These
conditions promised, the Commissaries went to advertise the Knight, how a
Gentlewoman of Piedmont was of purpose come into France to help him: whereof
he was maruellously astonned. Now he would never have thought that Zilia had
borne him so great good will, as by abasing the pride of her courage, would have
come so far to ease ye grief of him, whom by such great torments she had so
wonderfully persecuted. He thought again that it was the Gentlewoman his
neighbor which sometimes had done her endeavor to help him, and had provoked
Zilia to absolve him of his faith, and acquit him of his promise. Musing upon
the diversity of these things, and not knowing whereupon to settle his
judgment, the deputies commanded that the woman Physician should be brought to
speak with the patient. Which was done: and brought in place, the Commissaries
presently with drew themselves. The Lord of Virle seeing his enemy come before
him, whom sometimes he loved very (...), judged by and by the cause wherefore
she came, that only avarice and gredy desire of gain (...) rather procured
her to pass the mountains trauail, than due and honest amity, wherewith she
was double bound through his perseverance and humble service, whereby he was
estraunged of himself, as he fared like a shadow and image of a dead man.
Wherefore calling to mind the rigor of his Lady, her inciuilitie and fond
commandment, so long time to forbid his speech, the love which once he bare
her, with a vehement desire to obey her, suddenly was so cooled and qualified,
that love was turned into hatred, and will to serve her, into an appetite of
revenge: whereupon he determined to use that present fortune, and to play his
part with her, upon whom he had so foolishly doted, and to pay her with that
mo^ney wherewith she made hint feel the fruits of unspeakable cruelty, to
give example to fond and presumptuous dames, how they did abuse Gentlemen of
such degree whereof the Knight was, and that by having regard to the merit of
such personages, they be not so prodigal of themselves, as to set their
honor in sale for vile reward and filthy mucke: which was so constantly
conserved and defended by this Gentlewoman, against the assaults of the good
grace, beauty, calour, and gentleness, of that virtuous and honest suter. And
notwithstanding, in these days we see some to resist the amity of those that
love, for an opinion of a certain virtue, which they think to be hidden
within the corpse of excellent beauty, who afterward do set them selves to
sale to him yt gives most, and offreth greatest reward. Such do not deserve to
be placed in rank of chaste Gentlewomen, of whom they have no smack at all, but
amongs the throng of strumpets kind, that have some spark and outward show of
love: for she which loves money (...) hunteth after gain, will make no bones,
by treasons trap to betray that unhappy man, which shall yield himself to
her: her love tending to insensible things, and such in deed, as make the
wysest sort to falsify their faith, and sell the right and equity of their
Judgment. The Lord of Virle, seeing Zilia then in his company, and almost
at his commandment, feigned as though he knew her not, by reason of his small
regard and less intertainment showed unto her at her first coming: Which
greatly made the poor Gentlewoman to muse. Nevertheless she making a virtue of
necessity, and seeing her self to be in that place, from whence (...) could
not depart, without the loss of her honor and life, purposed to prove
Fortune, and to commit her self unto his mercy, for all the mobiltie which
the ancient attribute unto Fortune. Wherefore shutting fast the door, she
went unto the Knight, to whom she spoke these words: And what is the matter
(sir knight) that now you make so little account of your own Zilia, who in
times past you said, had greater power and authority over you? What is the
cause that moves you hereunto? Have you so soon forgotten her? Behold me
better, and you shall see her before you, that is able to acquit you of your
promise, and therefore prays you to pardon her committed faults done in
times past by abusing so cruelly the honest and (...) love which you bare her.
I am she, which through folly and temeritie did stop your mouth, and tied up
your tongue. Give me leave I beseech you, to open the same again, and to break
the line, which lets the liberty of your speech. She seeing that the dumb
Gentleman would make no answer at all, but Mumme, and showed by signs, that
he was not able to undo his tongue, weepyng began to kiss him, embrace him,
and make much of him, in such wise, as he which once studied to make eloquent
orations before his Lady, to induce her to pity, forgot then those
ceremonies, and spared his talk, to show himself to be such one as she
had made at her commandment, mused and devised altogether upon the execution
of that, which sometime he had so paynefully pursued, both by words and
continual service, and could profit nothing. Thus waked again by her,
which once had mortified his mind, assayed to renew in her that, which long
time before, seemed to be a sleep. She more for fear of loss of life, or
the price of the reward, than for any true or earnest love, suffered him to
receive that of her, which the long suter desires to obtain of his mistress.
They lived in this joy and pleasure the space of. xv. days ordained for the
assigned term of her cure, wherein the poor Gentlewoman was not able to
convert her offended friend, to speak, although she humbly prayed him to show
so much favor, as at least she might go free, from either loss: tellyng him
how little regard she had to her honor, to come so far to do him
pleasure, and to discharge him of his promise. Much other gay and lowlye talk
she had to move the Knight to take no regard of that she said, for he
determined to bring her in such fear, as he had been heaped full of
heaviness, which came to pass at the expired time. For the co^missaries
seeing that their pacient spoke not at all, summoned the gentlewoma^ to pay the
penalty pronounced in the edict, or else to lose her life. Alas, how bitter
seemed this drink to this poor Gentlewoman, who not able to dissemble the
grief that pressed her on every side, began to say: Ah I wretched and Caitife
woman, by thinkyng to deceive an other, have sharpened the sword to finishe
mine own life. (...) it not enough for me to use such cruelty toward this
mine enemy, which most cruelly in double wise takes revenge, but must I come
to be thus tangled in his snares, and in the hands of him, who inioying the
spoils of mine honor, will with my life, deprive me of my fame, by making me
a common fable, to all posterity in time to come? O what hap had I that I was
not rather devoured by some furious and cruel beast, when I passed the
mountains, or else that I brake not my neck, down some steep and headlong hill,
of those high and hideous mountains, rather than to be set here in stage, a
pageant to the whole city to gaze upon, for enterprising a thing so fondely,
done of purpose by him, whom I have offended. Ah Signior Philiberto, what
(...) rewardest thou for pleasures received, and favors felt in her, whom thou
did love so much, as to make her die such shameful and dreadful death. But O
God, I know that it is for worthy guerdon of my foolish and wicked life. Ah
disloyalty and fickle trust, is it possible that thou be harbored in the
heart of him, which had the brute to be the most loyal and courteous
Gentleman of his country? Alas, I see well now that I must die through mine
only simplicity, and that I must sacrifice mine honor to the rigor of him,
which with two advantages, takes over cruel revenge of the little wrong,
wherewith my chastity touched him before. As she thus had finished her
complaint, one came for her to carry her to prison, whether willingly she went
for that she was already resolved in desire, to live no longer in that misery.
The gentleman contented with that pain, and not able for to dissemble the
grief, which he conceived for the passion which he saw his well-beloved to
endure, the enjoying of whom renewed the heat of the flames forepast, repaired
to the king, unto whom to the great pleasure of the standers by, and exceeding
rejoice of his majesty (to hear him speak) he told the whole history of
the love between him and cruel Zilia, the cause of the loss of his spech, and
the sum of his revenge. By the faith of a Gentleman (said the King) but here
is so strange an history as ever I heard: and verily your faith and loyalty
is no less to be praised and commended than the crueltic and covetousness of
the woman woorthye of reproach and blame, which truly deserves some grievous and
notable justice, if so be she were not able to render some apparent cause for
the couerture and hidyng of her folly. Alas sir (said the Gentleman) pleases
your majesty to deliver her (although she be worthy of punishment) and
discharge the rest that be in prison for not recovery of my speech, since my
only help did rest, either at her commandment which had bound me to that
wrong, or else in the expired time, for which I had pledged my faith. To which
request, the King very willingly agreed, greatly praisyng the wisdom,
courtesy, and above all the fidelity of the lord of Virle, who causing his
penitenciarie to be set at liberty, kept her company certain days, as
well to feast and banquet her, in those lands and possessions which the kings
majesty had liberally bestowed upon him, as to saciate his appetite with the
fruits whereof he had sauoured the taste when he was voluntarily dumb. Zilia
found that favor so pleasant, that in a manner she counted her imprisonment
happy, and her travel rest, by reason that distress made her then feel more
lively the force and pleasure of liberty, which she had not found to be so
pleasant, had she not received the experience and pain thereof. Mark here how
fortune (...) with them which trusting in their force, despise (in respect of
that which they do them selves) the little porcio^ that they judged to be in
others. If the vainglorie and arrogant presumption of a chastity impregnable
had not deceived this Gentlewoman, if the sacred hunger of gold had not
blinded her, it could not (...) been known, wherein her incontinencie
consisted, not in the minion delights and alluring toys of a passionate
lover, but in yt covetous desire of filling her purse, and hypocritical glory
of praise among men. And notwithstanding, ye see the gain which she made, to
(...) her turn nothing at all, but to the perpetual reproach of her name, and
raised a slander, such as ill speakers and enemies of womenkind, do burden
that sex withal. But the fault of one which by her own presumption deceived
her self, ought not to obscure the glory of so many virtuous, fair and
honest dames, who by their chastity, liberality and courtesy, be able to
deface the blot of folly, covetousness, and cruelty of this gentlewoman here,
and of all other that do resemble her. Who taking leave of her lover, went home
again to Piedmont, not without an ordinary grief of heart, which served
her for a spur to her conscience, and continually forced her to think, that
the force of man is less tha^ nothing, where god works not by his grace,
which failyng in us, our works can savor but of the (...) and corruption of
our nature, wherein it tumbleth and tosseth like the Sow that waloweth in the
puddle full of filth and dirte. And because ye shall not think in general
terms of woman's chastity and discretion, that I am not able to vouche some
particular example of later years, I mean to tell you of one, that is not only
to be praised for her chastity in the absence of her husband, but also of her
courage and policy in chastizing (...) vaunting natures of two Hungarian lords
that made their braggs they would win her to their wills, and not only her,
but also al other, what soever they were of womankinde.

A Lady of Boeme
Two Barons of (...) assuring them selves to obtain their suit made to a fair
Lady of (...), (...) of her a strange and marvelous repulse, to their great
shame and infamy, curssyng the time that ever they adventured an enterprise so
foolish.

The. xxviij. Nouel.
P Enelope, the woeful wife of absent Ulysses, in her tedious lo^ging for the
home return of that her adueturous knight, assailed with careful heart
amidde the troop of amorous suitors, and within the bowels of her royal palace,
deserved no greter fame for her valiant encountries and stout defense of the
invincible and Adamante forte of her chastity, than this Boeme Lady (...) by
resisting two mighty barons, that canoned the walls and well mured rampart of
her pudicitie. For being threatened in his Princes court, whether all the well
trained crew of each science and profession, did make repair, being menaced
by Venus band, which not only summoned her forte, and gave her a camisado by
thick AP Arms, but also forced the place by fierce assault, she like a
courageous and politic captain, gave those brave and lusty soldiers, a
foul repulse, (...) in end taking them captines, urged them for their
victuals to fall to woman's toil, more shameful than shameless Sardanapalus
amidde his amorous troop.

I need not aggrauate by length of preamble, the fame of this, Boeme Lady, nor
yet (...) recou^t the triumph her victory: vain it were also by glorious
hymns to chaunt the wisdom of her beleuyng Make, who not careless of her
life, employed his care to serve his Prince, and by service at chieued the
cause that drove him to a soldiers state. But yet for trustlesse faith in the
prime conference of his future port, he consulted with Pollaco, for a
compounded drugge, to ease his suspect mind, which medicine so eased his
malady, as it not only preserved him from the infected humor, but also made
him happy for ever. Such fall the euentes of valiant minds, though many times
mother iealosie yt (...) wytch steppeth in her foot to anoy the well disposed
heart. For had he joined to his valiaunce credit of his loving wife, without
the blind advise of such as profess that black and lying science, double
glory he had gained: once for endeavoring by service to seek honor: the
second, for absolute trust in her, that never meant to beguile him, as by her
first answer to his first motion appears. But what is to be objected
against the Barons? Let them answer for their fault, in this discourse
ensuing: which so lessoneth all noble minds, as warely they ought to beware
how they adventure upon the honor of Ladies, who be not altogether of one
self and yeldyng trampe, but well (...) and steeled in the shamefast shop of
loyalty, which armure defends them against the fond skirmishes and
vnconsidred conflicts of Venus wanton band. The majesty's also of ye King and
Queen, are to be advanced above the stars for their wise dissuasion of those
noble men from their hot and hedlesse enterprise and then their justice for due
execution of their forfait, the particularitie of which discourse in this wise
does begin.

Mathie Coruine sometime king of Hungaric, about the year of our Lord.
1458. was a valiant man of war, and of goodly personage. He was the first
that was famous, or feared of the Turks, of any prince that governed that
kingdom. And amongs other his (...) so well in arms and letters, as in
liberality and courtesy he excelled all that reigned in his time. He had to
wife Queen Beatrice of Arragon, the daughter of old (...), king of Naples,
and sister to the mother of Alphonsus, Duke of Ferrara, who in learning, good
conditions, and al other virtues generally dispersed in her, was a surpassing
Princess, and she wed hirself not only a courteous and liberal Gentlewoman to
king Mathie her husband, but to al other, that for virtue seemed worthy of
honor and reward: in such wise as to the court of these two noble princes,
repaired the most notable men of al nations that were given to any kind of good
exercise, and every of them according to their desert and degree were welcomed
and entertained. It chanced in this time, that a knight of (...), the vassal
of King Mathie, for that he was likewise king of that country, borne of a
noble house, very valiant and well exercised in arms, fell in love with a
passing fair Gentlewoman of like nobility, and reputed to be the (...) of all
the country, and had a brother that was but a poor Gentleman, not luckie to
the goods of fortune. This Boemian knight was also not very rich, having only
a castle, with certain revenues (...), which were (...) able to yield unto him
any great maintenance of living. Falling in love then with this fair
Gentlewoman, he demanded her in marriage of her brother, and with her had but a
very little dowry. And this knight not well forseeing his poor estate, brought
his wife home to his house, and there, at more leisure considering yt same,
began to feel his lack and penury, and how hardly and scant his revenues were
able to maintein his port. He was a very honest and gentle person, and one that
delited not by any means to burden and fine his tenants, co^tenting himself
with ye revenue which his auncesters left him, the same amounting to no great
yearly rent. When this gentleman perceived yt he stood in need of
extraordinary relief, after many and diverse considerations with himself, he
purposed to follow the court, and to serve king Mathie his souerain lord and
master, there by his diligence and experience, to seek means for ability to
sustain his wife and him self. But so great and fervent was yt love that he
bare unto his lady, as he thought it impossible for him to live one hour (...)
her, and yet judged it not best to have her with him to ye court, for avoiding
of further charges (...) to courting ladies, whose delight (...) pleasure rests
in the toys and tricks of ye same, yt cannot he well avoided in poor ge^tleme^,
without their names in the Mercers or Drapers Iornals, a heavy thing for them
to consider if for their disport they like to walk yt streets. The daily
thinking thereupon, brought yt poor Gentleman to great sorrow and heaviness.
The lady that was young, wise and discrete, marking ye manner of her husband,
feared yt he had some (...) of her. Wherefore upon a day she thus said unto him:
Dear husband, willingly would I wish and desire a good turn at your hand, if I
wist I should not displease you. Demand what you will (said the knight) if I
can I will gladly perform it, because I do esteem your satisfaction, as I do
mine own life. Then the Lady very sobrely prayde him, that he would open unto
her the cause of that discontenment, which he showed outwardly to have, for
that his mind and behavior seemed to be contrary to ordinary custom, and
contrived day and night in fighes, auoidyng the company of them that were wont
specially to delight him. The Knight hearing his ladies request, paused a
while, and then said unto her: My well-beloved wife, for so much as you desire to
understand my thought and mind, and whereof it comes that I am so sad and
pensife, I will tell you: All the heaviness wherewith you see me to be
affected, does tend to this end. Feign would I devise that you and I, may in
honor live together, according to our calling. For in respect of our
parentage, our liuelode is very poor, the occasion whereof were our parents,
who morgaged their lands, and consumed a great part of their goods that our
auncesters left them. I daily thinkyng hereupon, and conceiving in my head
diverse imaginations, can devise no means but one, yt in my (...) seems best,
which is, yt I go to the Court of our souerain lord Mathie, who at this present
is inferring wars upon ye Turk, at whose hands I do not mistrust to receive
good (...), being a most liberal prince, and one that estemeth al such as be
valiant and active. And I for my part will so govern my self (by Gods grace)
that by deserte I will procure such living and (...), as hereafter we may live
in our old days a quiet life to our great stay and comfort: For although
Fortune hitherto has not favored that state of pare^tage, whereof we be, I
doubt not with noble courage to win that in despite of Fortunes teeth, which
obstinately hitherto she has denied. And the more assured am I of this
determination, because at other times, I have served under the Lord Vaiuoda in
Transsyluania, against the Turk, where many times I have been required to serve
also in the Court, by that honorable Gentleman, the Count of Cilia. But when
I did consider the beloved company of you (dear wife) the sweetest companion
that ever wight did (...), I thought it impossible for me to forbear your
presence, which if I should do, I were worthy to sustain that dishonor, which
a great number of careless Gentlemen do, who followyng their private gain
and will, abandon their young and fair wives, neglecting the fire which Nature
has instilled to the delicate bodies of such tender creatures. Fearing
therwithall, that so soon as I should depart, the lusty young Barons and
Gentlemen of the country would pursue the gain of that love, the price
whereof I do esteem above the crown of the greatest emperor in all the
world, and would not forgo for all the riches and precious Jewels in the
fertile soilt of Arabie, who no doubt would (...) together in greater heaps
than ever did the wowers of Penelope, within the famous graunge of Ithaca,
the house of wandering Ulysses. Which pursuit if they did attain, I
should for ever hereafter be ashamed to show my face before those that be of
valor and regard. And this is the whole effect of the scruple ((...) wife)
that hinders me, to seek for our better estate and fortune. When he had
spoken those words, (...) held his peace. The Gentlewoman which was wise and
stout, perceiving the great love that her husband bare her, when he had stayed
himself from talk, with good and merry countenance answered him in this wise:
Sir Vlrico (which was the name of the Gentleman) I in like manner as you have
done, have devised and thought upon the Nobility and birth of our ancestors,
from whose state and port (and that without our fault and crime) we be far
wide and divided. Notwithstanding I determined to set a good face upon the
matter, and to make so much of our painted sheath as I could. In deed I
confess my self to be a woman, and you men do say that women's hearts be faint
I feeble: but to be plain with you, the contrary is in me, my heart is so
stout and ambitious, as paraduenture not meet and consona^t to power and
ability, although we women will find no lack if our hearts have pith and
strength enough to bear it out. And feign would I support the state wherein my
mother maintained me. Now be it for mine own part (to God I yield the thanks) I
can so moderate and stay my little great heart, that contented and satisfied I
can be, with that which your ability can bear, and pleasure command. But to
come to the point, I say that debating with my self of our state as you full
wisely do, I do verily think that you being a young Gentleman, lusty and
valiant, no better remedy or devise can be found, than for you to aspire and
seek the Kings favor and service. And it must needs rise and redounde to your
gain and preferment, for that I hear you say the Kings majesty does
already know you. Wherefore I do suppose that his grace (a skillful
Gentleman to way and esteem the virtue and valor of each man) cannot choose
but (...) and recompense the well doer to his singular co^tentation and comfort.
Of this mine opinion I durst not before this time utter word or sign for fear
of your displeasure. But now since your self has opened ye way and means, I
have presumed to discover ye same, do what shall seem best unto your good
pleasure. And I for my part, although yt I am a woman (accordingly as I said
eue^ now) tha thy nature am desirous of honor, and to show my self abroad more
rich and sumptuous than other, yet in respect of our fortune, I shall be
contented so long as I live to continue with you in this our Castle, where by
the grace of God I will not fail to serve, love, and obey you, and to keep
your house in that moderate sort, as the revenues shall be able to maintain
the same. And no doubt but that poor living we have orderly used, shall be
sufficient to find us two, and. v. or. (...). servants with a couple of
horse, and so to live a quiet and merry life. If God do send us any children,
til they come to lawful age, we will with our poor living bring them up so
well as we can, and then to prefer them to some Noble men's services, with
whom by Gods grace they may acquire honor and living, to keep them in their
aged days. And I do trust that we two shall use such mutual love, and
rejoice, that so long as our life does last in wealth and woe, our contented
minds shall rest satisfied. But I waying the stoutnesse of your mind, do know
that you esteem more an ounce of honor, than all the gold that is in the
world. For as your birth is Noble, so is your heart and stomach. And therefore
many times seeing your great heaviness, and manifold muses and studies, I
have wondered with my self whereof they should proceed, and amongs other my
conceits, I thought that either my behauior and order of dealing, or my
personage did not like you: or else that your wonted gentle mind and
disposition had been altered and transformed into some other Nature: many times
also I was content to think that the cause of your disquiet mind, did rise
upon the disuse of arms wherein you were wont daily to accustom your self
amongs the troops of the honorable, a company in deed most worthy of your
presence. (...) many times these and such like cogitations, I have sought
means by such loving allurements as I could devise, to ease and mitigate your
troubled mind, and to withdraw the great impiety and care where with I saw
you to be affected. Because I do esteem you above all the world, deeming your
only grief to be my double pain, your aching finger, a (...) feuerfit, and
the least woe you can sustain most bitter death to me, that loves you more
dearly than my self. And for that I do perceive you are determined to serve
our Noble King, the sorrow which without doubt will assail me by reason of
your absence, I will sweeten and lenifie with contentation, to see your
commendable desire appeased and quiet. And the pleasant memory of your valiant
factes shall beguile my penfife thoughts, hoping our next meeting shall be more
joyful tha^ this our disjunction and departure heavy. And where you doubt of yt
confluence and repair of the dishonest which shall attempt the winning and
subduing of mine heart and unspotted body hitherto inuiolably kept from yt
touch of any person, cast from you yt fear, expel from your mind that fond
conceit: for death shall sooner close these mortal eyes, than my chastity
shall be defiled. For pledge whereof. I have none other thing to give, but my
true and simple faith, which if you dare trust, it shall hereafter appear so
firm and inviolable, as no spark of suspicion shall enter your careful
mind, which I may well term to be careful, because some care before hand
does rise of my behauior in your absence. The trial whereof shall yield sure
evidence and testimony, by passing my careful life which I may with better
cause so term, in your absence that God knows will be right (...) and
careful unto me, who ioyeth in nothing else but in your welfare. Nevertheless
all means and ways shall be agreeable unto my mind for your assurance, and
shall breed in me a wonderful contentation, which lusts after nothing but
your satisfaction. And if you list to close me up in one of the Castle towers
till your return, right glad I am there to continue an Ankresse life: so that
the same may ease your desired mind.

The Knight with great delight gave ear to the answer of his wife, and when she
had ended her talk, he began to say unto her: My well-beloved, I do like well
and greatly commend the stoutnesse of your heart, it pleases me greatly to
see ye same agreeable unto mine. You have lightened the same from inestimable
woe, by understanding your conceived purpose and determination to guard and
preserve your honor, praying you therein to persevere still remembering that when
a woman has lost her honor, she has forgone the chiefest jewel she has in
this life, and deserves no longer to be called woman. And touching my talk
proposed unto you, although it be of great importance, yet I mean not to
depart so soon. But if it do come to effect I assure thee wife, I will leave
thee Lady and mistress of all that I have. In the mean time I will consider
better of my business, and consult with my friends and kinsmen, and the^
determine what is best to be done. Till which time let us live and spend our
time so merely as we can. To be short, there was nothing that so much molested
the Knight, as the doubt he had of his wife, for that she was a very fine and
fair young Gentlewoman: And therefore he still devised and imagined what
assurance be might find of her behauior in his absence. And resting in this
imagination, not long after it came to pass that the Knight being in company
of diverse Gentlemen, and talking of sundry matters, a tale was told what
chanced to a gentleman of the Country which had obtained the favor and good
will of a woman, by means of an old man called Pollacco, which had the name
to be a famous enchaunter and Physician, dwelling at Cutiano a City of Boeme,
where plenty of silver Mines and other metals is. The knight whose Castle was
not far from Cutiano, had occasion to repair unto that City, and according
to his desire found out Pollacco, which was a very old man, and talking with
him of diverse things, perceived him to be of great skill. In end he entreated
him, that for so much as he had done pleasure to many for (...) of their love,
he would also instruct him, how he might be assured that his wife did keep her
self honest all the time of his absence, and that by certain signs he might
have sure knowledge whether she brake her faith, by sending his honesly into
Cornwall. Such vain trust this Knight reposed in the lying Science of Sorcery,
which although to many other is found deceitful, yet to him served for sure
evidence of his wives sidelitie. This Pollacco which was a very cunning
enchaunter as you have hard, said unto him: Sir you demand a very strange
matter, such as where with never hitherto I have been acquainted, ne yet
searched the depthe of those hidden secrets, a thing not commonly sued for, ne
yet practiced by me. For who is able to make assurance of a woman's chastity,
or tell by signs except he were at the deed doing, that she has done amiss?
Or who can gain by proctors wryt, to summon or sue a sprituall Court,
peremptorily to affirm by never so good evidence or testimony, yt a woman has
hazarded her honesty, except he swear Rem to be in Re, which the greatest
(...) that ever Padua bred, never saw by process duly tried? Shall I then
warrant you the honesty of such (...) cattle prone and ready to lust, easy to
be vanquished by the suites of earnest pursuers? But blame worthy surely I am,
thus generally to speak: for some I know, although not many, for whose pore
honesties I dare adventure mine own. And yet that number how small so ever it
be, is worthy all due reverence and honor. Notwithstanding. (because you
seem to be an honest Gentleman) of that knowledge which I have, I will not be
greatly (...). A certain secret experiment in deed I have, wherewith
perchance I may satisfy your demand. And this is it. I can by mine Art in
small time, by certain compositions, frame a woman's Image, which you
continually in a little box may carry about you, and so often as you list
behold the same. If the wife do not break her marriage faith, you shall still
see the same so fair and well colored as it was at the first making, and seem
as though it newly came from the painters shop, but if perchance she mean to
abuse her honesty, the same will wax pale, and in deed committing that filthy
fact, suddenly the color will be black, as arrayed with cole or other (...),
the smell whereof will not be very plesa^t: but at al times when she is attempted
or pursued, the color will be so yealow as gold. This marvelous secret devise
greatly pleased the Knight, verily believing the same to be true, specially much
moved and assured by ye fame bruted abroad of his science, whereof ye Citizens
of (...) told very strange and incredible things. When the price was paid of
this precious jewel, he received ye Image, and joyfully returned home to his
castle, where tarying certain days, he determined to repair to yt Court of the
glorious king Mathie, making his wife privy to his intent. Afterward when he
had disposed his household matters in order, he committed yt government thereof
to his wife, and having prepared all necessaries for his voyage, to the great
sorrow and grief of his beloved, he departed and arrived at Alba Regale, where
that time the King lay with Queen Beatrix his wife: of whom he was joyfully
received and entertained. He had not long continued in the Court, but he had
obtained and won the favor and good will of all men. The King (which knew him
full well) very honorably placed him in his court, and by him accomplished
diverse and many weighty affairs, which very wisely and trustely he brought to
pass according to the kings mind and pleasure. Afterward he was made Colonel
of a certain number of footmen sent by ye king against the Turks to defend a
hold which the enemies of God began to assail under ye conduct of Mustapha
Basca, which conduct he so well directed, and therein stoutly behaved himself, as
he chased al ye Infidels out of those coasts, winning thereby yt name of a most
valiant soldier and prudent captain. Whereby he meruellously gained ye favor
and grace of the king, who (over and besides his daily intertainement) gave
unto him a Castle, and the Revenue in fee farm for ever. Such rewards deserve
all valiant men, which for the honor of their Prince and country do willingly
employ their service, worthy no dout of great regard and cherishing, upon their
home return, because they hate idleness to win glory, devising rather to
spend hole days in field, than hours in Court, which this worthy Knight
deserved, who not able to sustain his pore estate, by politik wisdom and
prowess of arms endeavored to serve his Lord and country, wherein surely he
made a very good choice. Then he devoutly served and praised God, for that he
put into his mind such a Noble enterprise, trusting daily to atchieue greater
fame and glory: but the greater was his joy and contentation, because the image
of his wife enclosed within a box, which still he carried about him in his
pursie, continued fresh of color without any alteration. It was noysed in
the Court, that this valiant Knight Vlrico, had in Boeme the fairest and
goodliest Lady to his wife that lived either in Boeme or Hungary. It chanced
as a certain company of young Gentlemen in the Court were together, (amongs
whom was this Knighte) that a (...) Earon said unto him: How is it possible
sir (...), being a year and a half since you departed out of Boeme, that you
have no mind to return to see your wife, who as the common fame reports, is
one of the goodliest women of all the Country: truly it seems to me, that
you care not for her, which were great pity if her beautic be correspondent to
her fame. Sir (quod Vlrico) what her beauty is I refer unto the world, but
how so ever you esteem me to care of her, you shall understand that I do
love her, and will do so during my life. And the cause why I have not visited
her of long time, is no little proof of the great assurance I have of her
virtue and honest life. The argument of her virtue I prove, for that she is
contented that I should serve my Lord and king, and sufficient it is for me to
give her intelligence of my state and welfare, which many times by letters at
opportunity I fail not to do: the proof of my Faith is evident by reason of
my bounden duty to our sovereign Lord of whom I have received so great and
ample benefits, and the warfare which I use in his graces service in the
frontiers of his Realm against the enemies of Christ, whereunto I bear more
good will than I do to wedlock love, preferring duty to Prince before
marriage, albeit my wives faith and consta^cy is such, as freely I may spend my
life without care of her deuoir, being assured that besides her beauty she is
wise, virtuous and honest, and loves me above all worldly things, tendering me
so dearly as she does the balls of her own eyes. You have stoutly said
(answered the Barone) in defense of your wives chastity, whereof she can make
unto her self no great warrantise, because a woman sometimes will be in mind
not to be moved at the requests and gifts offered by ye greatest Prince of the
world, who afterward within a day upon the only sight and view of some lusty
young man, at one simple word uttered with a few tears and shorter suit, yeldeth
to his request. And what is she then yt can conceive such assurance in her
self? What is he that knows the secrets of hearts which be impenetrable?
Surely none as I suppose, except God him self. A woman of her own nature is
moveable and plyant, and is the most ambitious creature of the world. And (by
God) no woman do I know but that she lusts and desires to be beloved,
required, sued vn^to, honored and cherished? And oftentimes it comes to pass
yt the most crafty dames which think with fained looks to feed their diverse
lovers, be the first that thrust their heads into the amorous nets, and like
little birds in hard (...) of weather be caught in lovers (...) wigges.
Whereby sir Vlrico I do not see that your wife (above all other women compacte
of flesh and bone) has such privilege from God, but that she may be soon
entised and corrupted. Well sir (said the (...) Knight) I am persuaded of that
which I have spoken, and verily do believe the effect of my belief most true.
Every man knows his own affairs, and the fool knows better what he has,
than his neighbors do, be they never so wise. Believe you what you think good,
for I mean not to digress from that which I conceive. And suffer me (I pray
you) to believe what I list, since belief cannot hurt me, nor yet your discredit
can hinder my belief, being free for each man in semblable chances to think
and believe what his mind lusts and likes. There were many other Lords and
Gentlemen of the court (...) at that talk, and as we commonly see (at such
like metings) (...) man utters his mind: whereupon many and sundry opinions
were produced touching that question. And because diverse me^ be of diverse
natures, and many presume upon the pregnancie of their wise heads, there rose
some stur about yt talk, each man obstinate in his alleged reason, more
froward (...) than reason did require: the communication grew so hot, and talk
brake forth so loud, as the same was reported to the (...). The good Lady sorry
to hear tell of such strife within her Court, abhorring naturally all
controversy and contention, sent for the parties, and required them from point
to point to make recital of the beginning and circumsta^ce of their reasons and
arguments. And when she understood the effect of al their talk, she said, that
every man at his own pleasure might believe what he list, affirming it to be
presumptuous and extreme folly, to judge all women to be of one disposition,
in like sort as it were a great error to say that al men be of one quality and
condition: the contrary by daily experience manifestly appearing. For both in
me and women, there is so great difference and variety of natures, as there be
heads and wits. And how it is commonly seen that two brothers and sisters,
born at one birth, be yet of contrary natures and (...), of manners and
conditions so diverse, as the thing which shall please the one, is altogether
displesant to ye other. Whereupon the (...) concluded, yt the (...) Knight had
good reason to continue that good and honest credit of his wife, as having
proved her fidelity of long time, wherein she showed her self to be very wise
and discrete. Now because (as many times we see) the natures and appetites of
diverse men to be insaciable, and one man to be sometimes more foolish hardy
than another, even so (to say the (...),) were those two Hungarian Barons, who
seeming wise in their own conceits, one of them said to the (...) in this
manner: Madame your grace does well maintain the sere of womankinde, because you
be a woman. For by nature it is given to that kind, stoutly to stand in (...)
of themselves, because their imbecillitie and weakness otherwise would bewray
them: and although good reasons might be alleged to open the causes of their
(...), and why they be not able to attain the hault excellency of man, yet
for this time I do not mean to be tedious unto your grace, least the little
heart of woman would rise and display that conceit which is wrapped within that
little molde. But to return to this chaste Lady, through whom our talk
began, if we might crave license of your majesty, and safe (...) of this
Gentleman to know her dwelling place, and have (...) to speak to her, we doubt
not but to break with our battering talk, the Adamant walls of her (...)
that is so famous, and carry away that spoil which (...) we shall (...). I know
not answered the (...) Knight, what ye can or will (...), but sure I am, that
hitherto I am not (...). Many things were spoken there, and sundry opinions of
(...) parts alleged. In end the two Hungarian. (...) persuaded them selves,
and made their vaunts that they were able to clime the skies, and both would
attempt and also bring to passeny enterprise were it never so great, affirming
their former offer by oath, and would gage all the lands and goods they had,
that within the space of. v. months they would either of them obtain the
Gentlewomans good will to do what they list so that the Knight were (...),
neither to return home, ne yet to advertise her of yt their determination. The
Queen and all the standers by laughed heartily at this their offer, mocking
and jesting at their foolish and youthly conceits. Which the Barons
perceiving, said: You think Madame that we speak triflingly, and be not able
to accomplish this our proposed enterprise, but Madame, may it please you to
give us leave, we mean by earnest attempt to give proof thereof. And as they
were thus in reasoning and debating the matter, the king (hearing tell of this
large offer made by the Barons) came into the place where the Queen was, at
such time as she was about to dissuade them from their fra^tike devise. Before
who^ he being entered the chamber, the two Barons fell down upon their knees,
and humbly besought his grace, that the compacte made between sir Vlrico and
them might proceed, disclosing unto him in few words the effect of all their
talk, which frankly was granted by ye king. But the Barons added a Prouiso,
that when they had won their wager, the Knight by no means should hurt his
wife, and from that time forth should give over his false opinion, that women
were not naturally given to the suits and requests of amorous persons. The
Boeme Knighte, who was assured of his wives great honesty and loyal faith,
believed so true as the Gospel, the proportion and quality of the image, who
in all the time that he was far off, never perceived the same to be either pale
or black, but at that time lookyng upon the image, he perceived a certaie
yealow color to rise, as he thought his wife was by some love pursued, but yet
suddenly it returned again to his natural hew, which boldned him to say
these words to the Hungarian barons: Ye be a couple of pleasant and unbelieving
Gentlemen, and have conceived so (...) opinion, as ever men of your calling
did: but since you proceed in your obstinate folly, and will needs guage all the
lands and goods you have, that you be able to vanquishe my wives honest and
chaste heart, I am contented, for the singular credit which I repose in her,
to join with you, and will pledge the poorelyuing I have for proof of mine
opinion, and shall accomplish all other your requests made here, before the
majesty's of the King and Queen. And therefore (...) it (...) your highness,
since this fond devise can not be beaten (...) of their heads, to give license
unto those noble men, the lords Vdislao, and Alberto, (so were they called) to
put in proof the merry conceit of their disposed minds (whereof they do so
greatly brag) and I (...) your good grace and favor, am content to agree to
their demaundes: and we answered the Hungarians do once again affirm the
same which we have spoken. The King wylling to have them give over that
strife, was entreated to the contrary by the Barons: whereupon the King
perceiving their follies, caused a decree of the bargain to be put in writing,
either parties interchaungeably subscribing the same. Which done, they took
their leaves. Afterward, the two Hungarians began to put their enterprise
in order, and agreed between themselves, Alberto to be the first that should

the Lord Vladislao should proceed. These things concluded, (...) all

the castle, and demanding of the host, the conditions of the Lady, he
understood that she was a very fair woman, and that her honesty and love

espying, speedily imagined into what port his (...) bark would arrive: (...)

had caught the Eele by the tail, not well practiced in Cicero his school,
ceased not (...) to contriue the (...), by making her believe, that he was
far in love. The Lady weary (God wot) of his fond (...) and amorous
reasons, and yet not to seem scornful. made him good countenance, in such
wise as the Hungarian two or three days did nothing else but proceed in
vain pursuit: She perceiving him to be but a (...) of the first coat,
devised to recompense his Follies with such enterteynemente, as during all his
life, he should keep the same in good remembrance. Wherefore not long
after, faynyng as though his great wisdom, uttered by cloquente talk,

and your pleasant gesture in my house, have so inchaunted me, that impossible
it is, but I must (...) agree unto your will: for where I never thought
during life, to stayne the purity of marriage bed, and determined continually
to preserve my self inuiolablye for my husband, (...) Noble grace and
courteous behauioure, have (I say) so bewitched me, that ready I am to be at
your commandment, humbly (...) your honor to beware, that knowledge hereof

(...), over the door whereof, ye shall find the arms of my husband, entailed

the mean time I will wait and and provide, that none shall molest and trouble
us, and then shall bestow our selves for accomplishement of that which your
love desires. Now in very deed this chamber was a very strong prison ordained
in ancient time by the progenitors of that territory, to imprison and punish
the bassals and tenants of the same, for offenses and crimes committed. The
Baron hearing this liberal offer of the Lady, thinking that he had obtained
the sum of all his joy, so glad as if he had conquere^d a whole kingdom,
the best contented man alive, thankyng the Lady for her courteous answer,
departed, and returned to his Inn. (...) knows upon how merry a pin the
heart of this young Baron was set, and after he had liberally banketted his
host and hostess, pleasantly disposing him self to mirth and recreation, he
went to bed, where joy so lightened his merry head, as no sleep at all could
close his eyes: such be the savage pangs of those that aspire to like
delights, as the best reclaimer of the wildest hawk could never take more
pain or devise (...) shifts to man the same for the better atchieuing of her
pray, than did this brave Baron sustain for bryngyng his enterprise to
effect. The next day early in the morning he rose, dressyng himself with the
swetest parfumes, and putting on his finest suit of (...), at the appointed
hour he went to the castle, and so secretly as he could, according to the
Ladies instruction, he conveyed himself up into the chamber (...) he found
open, and when he was entered, he shut the same. The manner of the door was
such, as none within could open it without a (...), and besides the strong
lock, it had both bar and (...) on the outside, with such fastening, as the
devil him self being locked within, could not break forth. The Lady which
waited hard by for his (...), so soon as she perceived that the door was
shut, stepte unto the same, and both double locked the door, and also
without she barred and fast bolte the same, carrying the (...) away with her.
This chamber was in the highest tower of the house (as is before said) wherein
was placed a bed with good furniture, the wyndow whereof was so high, that
none could look out without a ladder. The other parts thereof were in good and
convenient order, apt and mete for an honest prison. When the Lord Alberto was
within, he satte down, waiting (as the Jews do for Messiah) when the Lady
according to her appointement should come. And as he was in this expectation,
building castles in the air, and devising a thousand Chimeras in his brain,
behold he heard one to open a little wicket that was in the door of that
chamber, which was so straight and little, as scarcely able to receive a loaf
of bread, or cruse of wine, used to be sent to the prisoners. He thinkyng that
it had been the Lady, rose (...), and heard the noise of a little girl, who
loking in at the hole, thus said unto him: My Lord Alberto, the Lady Barbara
my mistress (for that was her name) has sent me thus to say unto you: That
for so much as you be come into this place, by countenance of Love, to
dispoyle her of her honor, she has imprisoned you like a thief, according to
your deserte, and purposes to make you suffer penance according to the measure
of your offense. Wherefore so long as you shall remain in this place, she
minds to force you to gain your bread and drink with the art of spinning, as
pore women do for sustentation of their living, meaning thereby to cool the
heat of your lusty youth, and to make you taste the sour sause mete for them
to assay, that go about to rob Ladies of their honor: she bad me likewise to
tell you, that the more yarne you spin, the greater shall be the abundance and
delicacie of your fare: the greater pain you take to gain your food, the
more liberal she will be in distributing of the same: otherwise (she says)
that you shall fast with bread and water. Which determinate sentence she has
decreed, not to be infringed and broken for any kind of suit or entreaty that
you be able to make. When the maiden had spoken these words, she shut the
portall door, and returneo to her Lady. The Baron which thought that he had been comen to a marriage, did eat nothing all the morning before, because he
thought to be enterteined with better and daintier store of viandes, who now
at those news fared like one out of his wits, and stood still so amazed,
as though his legs would have failed him, and in one moment his (...) (...)
to vanish, and his force and breath forsook him, and fell down upon the chamber
(...), in such wise as he that had beheld him, would have thought him rather
dead than living. In this state he was a great time, and after wards somewhat
coming to him self, he could not tell whether he dreamed, or else that the
words were true, which the maiden had said unto him: In the end seeing, and
being verily assured, that he was in a prison so sure as bird in Cage, through
(...) and rage was like to die, or else to lose his wits, faryng with him
self of long time like a mad man, and not knowing what to do, passed the
rest of the day in walkyng up and down the chamber, rauing, stamying, staring,
cursing, and using words of greatest villainy, lamenting and bewailyng the time
and day, that so like a beast and (...) man, he gave the attempt to dispoile
the honesty of an other man's wife. Then came to his (...) the loss of al his
lands and goods, which by the (...), authority were put in comprimise, then
the shame, the scorn, and rebuke whyehe he should receive at other men's
hands, beyond measure vexed him: and reporte^ bruted in the Court (for that
it was impossible but the whole world should know it) so grieved him, as his
(...) seemed to be strained with two sharp and bityng nails, the pains
whereof, forced him to lose his wits and under standing. In the mids of
which pangs furiously vauting up and down the chamber, he espied by chance in
a corner, a (...) furnished with good (...) of flare, and a spindle hangyng
therevppon: and (...) with choler and rage, he was about to spoil and break
the same in pieces: but remembering what a hard weapon Necessity is, he
stayed his wysdom, and albeit he had rather to have contrived his leisure in
noble and Gentlemanlyke passetyme, yet rather than he would be idle, he
thought to reserve that Instrument to avoid the tedious lack of honest and
familiar company. When supper time was come, the maiden returned again, who
opening the Portall door, saluted the Baron, and said: My Lord, my mistress
has sent me to visit your good Lordshyp, and to receive at your good
hands the effect of your labor, who hops that you have spoonne some
substanciall web of threede for earning of your supper, which being done,
shall be readily brought unto you. The Baron full of rage, fury, and felonious
mood, if before he were fallen into choler, now by protestation of these
words, he seemed to transgress the bounds of reason, and began to rail at
the poor wench, scolding and chiding her like a strumpet of the stews, faring
as though he would have beaten her, or done her some (...) there mischief: but
his mood was stayed from doing any hurt: The poor (...) (...) by her (...),
in laughing wise said unto him: Why (my lord) do you chafe and rage against
me? Me thinks you do me wrong to use such reprochful words, which am but a
servant, and bound to the commandment of my mistress: Why sir, do you not
know that a (...) or messanger suffers no pain or blame? The greatest King or
Emperor of the world, receiving (...) from a meaner Prince, never uses his
ambassador with scolding words, ne yet by villainy or rebuke abuses his
person. Is it wisdom then (...) you, being a present prisoner, at the mercy of
your kepers, in this (...) sort to revile me with (...) talk? But (...),
leave of your rages, and quiet your self for this present time, for my
mistress maruelleth much why you durst come (for all your noble state) to give
(...) to violate her good name, which message she required me to tell you,
oue^r and bisides a desire she has to know, whether by the science of
Spinning, you have gained your food: for you seem to kick against the wind,
and beat water in a mortar, if you think from hence to go before you have
earned a recompense of the meat which shall be given you. Wherefore it is your lot
patiently to suffer the (...) of your fondattempt, which I pray you gently to
sustain, and think no scorn thereof hardely: for desperate men and hard
adventurers must needs suffer the dangers thereunto belonging. This is the
determinate sentence of my mistress mind, who fourdeth you no better fare
than bread and water, if you can not show some pretty spindle full of yarne
for sign of your good will at this present pinche of your distress. The
maiden seeing that he was not disposed to show some part of willing mind to
gain his living by that (...) science, shut the portal door, and went her way.
The unhappy Baron (arrived thither in very ill time) that night had neither
bread nor broth, and therefore he fared according to theprouerbe: He that goth
to bed supperlesse, lies in his bed restless. For during the whole night, no
sleep couldfasten his eyes. Now as this baron was closed in prison fast, so
the La die took order, that secretly with great cher ehis servants should be
interteined, and his horse with sweet hay and good prouender well maintained,
all his furnitures, sumpture horse and cariages conveyed within the Castle,
where wanted nothing for the state of such a personage but only liberty,
making the host of the Inn believe (where the Lord harbored before) that he
was returned into Hungary.

But now turn we to the Boeme Knight, who knowing that one of the two
Hungarian Competitors, were departed the Court, and ridden into Boeme, did still
behold the quality of the inchaunted image, wherein by the space of three or
four days, in which time, the baron made his greatest suit to his Lady, he
marked a certain alteration of color in the same: but afterward returned to
his native form: and seeing no greter transformation, he was well assured, that
the Hungarian Baron was repulsed, and employed his labor in vain. Whereof the
Boeme Knight was excedingly pleased and contented, because he was well assured,
that his wife had kept her self right pure and honest. Notwithstanding his
mind was not well settled, ne yet his heart at rest, doubtyng that the Lord
Vladislao, which as yet was not departed the Court, would obtain the thing,
and acquit the fault, which his companion had committed. The imprisoned Baron
which all this time had neither (...) nor dronken, nor in the night could
sleep, in the morning, after he had considered his mysaduenture, and well
perceived no remedy for him to go forth, except he obeyed the Ladies hest,
made of necessity a virtue, and applied himself to learn to Spynne by force,
which freedom and honor could never have made him to do. Whereupon he
took the distaffe, and began to spynne. And albeit that he never spoonne in
all his life before, yet (...) by Necessity, so well as he could, he drew out
his threede, now small and then great, and many times of the meanest sort,
but very often broad, ill favored, ill closed, and worsse twisted, all cut of
form and fashion, that sundry times very heartyly he laughed to him self,
to see his cunning, but would have made a cunnyng woman spinner brust into ten
thousand laughters, if she had (...) there. Thus all the morning he spent
in spynnyng, and when dinner came, his accustomed messanger, the maiden,
repaired unto him again, and openyng the wyndowe demanded of the Baron how
his work went forewarde, and whether he were disposed to manifest the (...)
