of his coming into Boeme? He well beaten in the School of shame, uttered
unto the maid the whole compacte and bargayne made between him and his
companion, and the Boeme Knight her master, and afterward showed unto her his
spindle full of threde. The young Wench smylyng at his work, said: By Saint
Marie this is well done, you are worthy of victual for your hire: for now I
right well perceive that Hunger forces the Woulfe out of her den. I conne
you thancke, that like a Lord you can so puissantly gain your living.
Wherefore proceedyng in that which you have begone, I doubt not but shortly
you will prove such a woorkeman, as my mistress shall not need to put out
her (...) to spinne (to her great charge and cost) for making of her smockes,
but that the same may well be done within her own house, yea although the
same do serve but for Kitchen clothes, for dresser boordes, or cleanyng of
her vessel before they (...) served forth. And as your good deserts do
merit thanckes for this your art, now well begoonne, even so your new
told tale of coming hither, requires no less, for that you have disclosed
the truth. When she had said these words, she reached him some store of
meats for his dynner, and badde him well to fare. When she was returned unto
her Lady, she showed unto her the Spindle full of threede, and told her
therwithall the whole story of the compact between the Knight Vlrico, and the
two Hungarian Barons. Whereof the Lady sore astoonned, for the snares laid to
(...) her, was notwithstanding well (...), for that she had so well for seen
the same: but most of all reioysed, that her husband had so good opinion of
her honest life. And before she would advertise him of these euentes, she
purposed to attend the coming of the Lord Vladislao, to whom she meant to do
like penance for his careless bargain and dishonest opinion, accordingly as
he deserved, maruelling very much that both the Barons, were so rash and
presumptuous, daungerously (not knowing what kind of woman she was) to put
their lands and goods in hazard. But considering the nature of diverse
brainsicke me^, which pass not how carelessly they adventure their gained
goods, and inherited lands, so they may (...) the pray, after which they
vainly hunt, for the prejudice and hurt of other, she made no account of these
attempt, s since honest matrones force not upon the suits, or vain consumed
time of light brained cockscombs, that care not what fond cost or ill
employed hours they waste to anoy the good renoume and honest brutes of women.

But not to discourse from point to point the particulers of this intended
journey, this poor deceived Baron in short time proved a very good Spinner, by
exercise whereof, he felt such solace, as not only the same was a comfortable
sport for his captive time, but also for want of better recreation, it seemed
so joyful, as if he had been pluming and (...) his Hawk, or doing other
sportes belongyng to the honorable state of a Lord. Which his well arrived
labor, the maiden recompensed with abundance of good and delicate meats. And
although the Lady was many times required to visit the Baron, yet she would
never to that request consent. In which time the Knight Vlrico ceased not
continually to view and reuewe the state of his image, which appeared still to
be of one well colored sort. And although this use of his was diverse times
marked and seen of many, yet being earnestly demanded the cause thereof, he
would never disclose the same. Many conjectures thereof (...) made, but none
could attain the truth. And who would have thought that a Knight so wise
and prudent had worn within his pursse any enchanted thing? And albeit the
King and Queen had intelligence of this frequent practice of the Knight, yet
they thought not mete for any private and secret mystery, to demand the
cause. One Month and a half was passed now, that the Lord Alberto was
departed the Court, and become a castle knight and cunning spinster: which made
the Lord Vladislao to muse, for that the promise made between them was broken,
and heard neither by letter or messanger what success he had received. After
diverse thoughts imagined in his mind, he conceived that his companion had
happily enjoyed the end of his desired joy, and had gathered the wished fruits
of the Lady, and drowned in yt maine sea of his own pleasures, was overwhelmed
in the bottom of oblivion: wherefore he determined to set forward on his
journey to give onset of his desired fortune: who without long delay for
execution of his purpose, prepared all necessaries for that voyage, and mounted
on horseback with two of his men, he iourneyed toward Boeme, and within few
days after arrived at the Castle of the fair and most honest Lady. And when
he was entered the Inn where the Lord Alberto was first lodged, he diligently
enquired of him, and hard tell that he was returned into Hungary many days
before, whereof much maruelling, could not tell what to say or think. In yt end
purposing to put in proof the cause wherefore he was departed out of Hungary,
after diligent inquiry of the manners of the Lady, he understood the general
voice, that she was without comparion the most honest, wise, gentle and comely
Lady within the whole Country of Boeme. Incontinently the Lady was
advertised of ye arrival of this Baron, and knowing the cause of his coming,
she determined to pay him also with that money which she had already coined for
the other. The next day the Baron went unto the Castle, and knocking at the
gate, sent in word how that he was come from the Court of King Mathie, to
visit and salute the Lady of that Castle: and as she did entertain the first
Baron in courteous (...), and with loving countenance, even so she did the
second, who thought thereby that he had attained by that pleasant
entertainment, the game after which he hunted. And discoursing upon diverse
matters, the Lady showed her self a pleasant and familiar Gentlewoman, which
made the Baron to think that in short time he should win the price for which he
came. Notwithstanding, at the first brunt he would not by any means descend to
any particularitie of his purpose, but his words ran general, which were, that
hearing tell of the fame of her beauty, good grace and come, linesse, by having
occasion to repair into Boeme to do certain his affairs, he thought it
labor well spent to ride some portion of his journey, though it were besides
the way, to digress to do reverence unto her, whom fame advanced above the
skies: and thus passing his first visitation, he returned again to his
lodging. The Lady when the Baron was gone from her Castle, was rapte into a
rage, greatly offended that those two Hungarian Lords so presumptuously had
bended them selves like common Thieves to wander and roue the Countries, not
only to rob and spoil her of her honor, but also to bring her in
displeasure of her husband, and thereby into the danger and peril of death.
By reason of which rage (not without cause conceived) she caused an other
Chamber to be made ready, next wall to the other Baron that was become such a
Notable spinster. And upon the next return of the Lord Vladislao, she received
him with no less good entertainment than before, and when night came, caused
him to be lodged in her own house in the Chamber prepared as before, where he
slept not very soundly all that night, through the continual remembraunee of
his Ladies beauty. Next morning he perceived himself to be locked fast in a
Prison. And when he had made him ready, thinking to descend to bid the Lady
good morrow, seeking means to unlock the door, and perceiving that he could
not, he stood still in a dumpe. And as he was thus standing, maruelling the
cause of his shutting in so fast, the Maiden repaired to the hole of the door,
giving his honor an (...) salutation, which was, that her Mistress commanded
her to give him to understand, that if he had any lust or appetite to his
breakefast, or minded from thence for the to ease his hunger or contain life,
that he should give him self to learn to reele yarne. And for that purpose
she willed him to look in such a corner of the Chamber, and he should find
certain spindles of threede, and an instrument to wind his yarne upon.
Wherefore (quod she) apply your self thereunto, and lose no time. He that had
that time beholden the Baron in the face, would have thought that he had
seen rather a Marble stone, than the figure of a man. But converting his cold
conceived mood, into mad anger, he fell into ten times more displeasure
with himself, than is before described by the other Baron. But seeing that his
mad behauioure and beastly usage was bestowed in vain, the next day he began
to reele. The Lady afterward when she had intelligence of the good and
gainefull spinning of the Lord Alberto, and the well disposed and towardly
reeling of the Lord Vladislao, greatly rejoiced for making of such two
Notable woorkemen, whose woorkemanship exceeded the labors of them that had
been apprentyzes to the occupation seven years together. Such be the apt
and ready wits of the Souldioures of love: Where in I would wish all Cupides
dearlings to be nousled and applied in their youthly time: the^ no doubt their
passions would appease, and rages assuage, and would give over their over bold
attemptes, for which they have no thank of the chaste and honest. And to this
goodly sight the Lady brought the servants of these Noble men, willing them
to mark and behold the diligence of their masters, and to imitate the
industry of their goodly exercise, who never attained meat before by labor
they had gained the same. Which done, she made the^ take their horse and
furnitures of their Lords, and to depart: otherwise if by violence they
resisted, she would cause their choler to be calmed with such like service as
they saw done before their eyes. The servant seeing no remedy, but must
needs depart, took their leave. Afterward she sent one of her servants in
post to the Court, to advertise her husband of all that which chanced. The
Boeme Knight receiving this good news declared the same unto the King and
Queen, and recited the whole story of the two Hungarian Barons, accordingly as
the tenor of his wives letters did purporte. The Princes stood still in great
admiration, and highly commended the wisdom of the Lady, (...) her for a very
sage and politic woman. Afterward the Knight Vlrico humbly besought the King
for execution of his decree and performance of the bargain. Whereupon the King
assembled his counsel, and required every of them to say their mind. Upon the
deliberation whereof, the Lord Chauncelor of the kingdom, with two
Counselors, were sent to the Castle of the Boeme Knight, to enquire and learn
the process and doings of the two Lords, who diligently accomplished the Kings
commandment. And having examined the Lady and her maiden with other of the
house, and the Barons also, whom a little before the arriual of these
Commisioners, the Lady had caused to be put together, yt by spinning and
reeling they might comfort one an other. When the Lord Chau^celor had framed
and digested in order the whole discourse of this history, returned to the
court where the King and Queen with the Pieres and Noble men of his kingdom
caused the acts of the same to be diuulged and bruted abroad, and after much
talk and discourse of the performance of this co^pact, pro and co^tra, the
Queen taking the Ladies part, and favoring the Knight, the King gave sentence
yt sir Vlrico should wholly possess the lands and goods of the two Barons to
him, and to his heirs for ever, and that the Barons should be banished out of
the kingdoms of Hungary and Boeme, never to return upon pain of death. This
sentence was put in execution, and the unfortunate Barons exiled, which
specially to those that were of their consanguinitie and blood, seemed too
severe and rigorous. Nevertheless the covenant being most plain and evident
to most men, ye same seemed to be pronounced with great Justice and equity,
for example in time to come, to lesson rash wits how they judge and deem so
indifferently of wome^s behauiors amo^gs whom no doubt there be both good and
bad, as there be of men. Afterward the. y. Princes sent for ye Lady to yt
Court, who there was courteously entertained, and for this her wise and
politic fact had in great admiration. The Queen then appointed her to be one
of her women of honor, and esteemed her very dearly. The knight also daily grew
to great promotion, well beloved and favored of the King, who with his Lady
long time lived in great joy and felicity, not forgetting the cunning man
Pollacco, that made him the image and likeness of his wife: whose friendship
and labor he rewarded with money, and other benefits very liberally.

Dom Diego and Gineura
DOM DIEGO a Gentleman of Spain (...) in love with fair GINEVRA, and she with
him: their love by means of one that envied DOM DIEGO his happy choice, was
by default of light credit on her part interrupted. He constant of mind, fell
into despair, and abandoning all his (...) and living, repaired to the Pyrene
Mountains, where he led a savage life for certain mo^ths, and afterward
known by one of his friends, was (by marvelous circumstaunce) reconciled to
his (...) (...), and married.

The. xxix. Nouel.
Men's mischaunces occurring on the bruntes of diverse Tragical fortunes,
albeit upon their first taste of bitterness, they savor of a certain kind of
loathsome relish, yet under the Kind of that vnsauerouse sap, does lurk a
sweeter honey, than sweetness it self, for the fruit that the posterity may
gather and learn by others hurtes, how they may (...) and shun the like.
But because all things have their seasons, and every thing is not convenient
for all times and places, I purpose now to show a Notable example of a vain
and superstitious Lover, that abandoned his living and friends, to become a
Savage desert man. Which History resembles in a manner a Tragical comedy,
comprehending the very same matter and argument, wherewith the greatest part of
the (...) sortearme them selves to cover and defend their follies. It is red
and seen too often by common custom, and therefore (...) here to display what
rage does govern, and headlong hale fond and licentious youth conducted by
the pangue of love, if the same be not moderated by reason, and cooled with
sacred lessons even from the Cradle to more mature and riper age. For the
Tyranny of love amongs all the deadly foes that (...) and (...) our minds,
glories of his force, vaunting himself able to change the proper nature of
things, be they never so sound and perfect: who to make them like his lusts,
(...) himself into a substance qualified diversely, the better to entrap such as
be given to his vanities. But having avouched so many examples before, I am
content for this present to tell the discourse of two persons, chanced not long
since in Catheloigne. Of a Gentleman that for his constancy declared two
extremities in him self of love and folly. And of a Gentlewoman so fickle and
inconstant, as love and they which waited on him, be disordered, for the
trustlesse ground whereupon such foundation of service is laid, which ye shall
easily conceive by well viewing the difference of these twain: (...) I mean
to (...) to the listes, by the blast of this (...) trumpe. And thus the same
begins.

Not long after yt the victorious and Noble prince, young (...), the son of
Alphonsus King of Aragon was dead, Jews the twelfth, that time being French
King, upon the Marches of Catheloigne, between Barcelona and the Mountains,
there was a good Lady then a widow, which had been the wife of an excellent and
Noble knight of the Country, by whom she had left one only daughter, which
was so carefully brought (...) by the mother, as nothing was to dear or heard
to be brought to pass for her desire, thinking that a creature so Noble and
perfect, could not be trained up too delicately. Now bisides her incomparable
furniture of beauty, this young Gentlewoman was adorned with hair so fair,
curle, and yealow, as the new fined gold was not matchable to the shining
locks of this tender infant, who therefore commonly was called Gineura la
Blonde. Half a days journey from the house of this widow, lay the lands of an
other Lady a widow also, that was very rich, and so well allied as any in all
the land. This Lady had a son, whom she caused to be trained up so well in
Arms and good letters, as in other honest exercises proper and meet for a
Gentleman and great Lord, for which respect she had sent him to Barcelona the
chief City of all the Country of (...). Senior Dom Diego, (for so was ye
son of that widow called) (...) so well in all things, that when he was.
(...). years of age, there was no Gentleman of his degree, that did excel
him, ne yet was able to approach unto his perfections and comme^dable behauior.
A thing that did so well content yt good Lady his mother, as she could not tell
what countenance to keep to cover her joy. A vice very commen to fond and
folish mothers, who flater them selves with a shadowed hope of the future
goodness of their children, which many times does more hurt to that wanton and
wilful age, than profit or advancement. The persuasion also of such
towardness, full often does blind yt sprites of youth, as yt faults which follow
the same be far more vile tha^ before they were: whereby the first Table (made
in his first colors) of yt imagined virtue, ca^ take no force or perfection,
and so by incurring sundry mishaps, the parent and child commonly eskape not
without equal blame. To come again therefore to our discourse: it chanced in
yt time that (the Catholic king deceased) Philippe of Austrich which succeeded
him as heir passing through France, came into Spain to be invested and take
possession of al his seigniories and kingdoms: which known to the Citizens of
Barcelona, they determined to receive him with such pomp, magnificence and
honor, as duly appertains to the greatness and majesty of so great a
Prince, as is the son of the Roman Emperor. And amongs other things they
prepared a triumph at the Tilt, where none was suffered to enter the listes,
but young Ge^tlemen, such as never yet had followed arms. Amongs whom Dom Diego
as yt Noblest person was chosen chief of one part. The Archduke then come to
Barcelona after the received honors and Ceremonies, accustomed for such
entertainment, to gratify his subjects, and to see the bravery of the young
Spanish Nobility in arms, would place himself upon the skaffolde to judge the
courses and valiance of the runners. In that magnifique and Princely conflict,
all men's eyes were bent upon Dom Diego, who course by course made his
adversaries to feel the force of his arms, his manhood and dexterity on
horseback, and caused them to muse upon his toward (...) in time to come,
whose noble gests then acquired the victory of the camp on his side. Which
moved King Philip to say, that in all his life he never saw triu^ph better
handled, and yt the same seemed rather a battle of strong and hardy men, than
an exercise of young Gentlemen never wo^ted to support the deeds of arms and
travail of warfare. For which cause calling Dom Diego before him he said. God
grant (yo^g Gentleman) yt your end agree with your goodly beginnings and
hardy shock of (...) done this day. In memory whereof I will this night yt ye do
your watch, for I mean to morrow (by Gods assistance) to dub you knight. The
young gentleman blushing for shame, upon his knees kissed the Princes hands,
thanking him most humbly of ye honor and favor which it pleased his majesty to
do him, vowing and promising to do so well in time to come, as no man should be
deceived of their conceived opinion, nor ye king frustrate of his service,
which was one of his most obedient vassals and subjects. So the next day he
was made Knight, and received the collar of ye order at the hands of King
Phillip, who after ye departure of his prince which took his journey into
Castille, retired to his own (...) and house, more to see his mother, who^e
long time before he had not seen, than for desire of pleasure yt be in
fields, which notwithstanding he exercised so well as in end (...) perceived
(...) in towns and cities, to be an impriso^ment (...) respect of that he felt
in Country. As ye Poets whilom fained love to shote his arrows amid yt (...),
forests, fertile fields, sea coasts, shores of great rivers and fountain
brinkes, and also upon the tops of huge and high Mountains at the pursuit of
the sundry sorted Nymphs and (...) dimigods, deeming the same to be a mean of
liberty to follow loves tract without suspicion, void of company and loathsome
cries of Cities, where (...), envy, false report, and ill opinion of all
things, have pitched their camp and raised their tents. (...) contrariwise
fra^kly and without dissimulation in the fields, the friend discovering his
passion to his Mistress, they enjoy the pleasure of hunting, the natural
music of birds, and sometimes in pleasant herbers (...) with the murmur of some
running brooks, they communicate their thoughts, beautify the accord and
unity of lovers, and make the place famous for yt first witness of their
amorous acquaintance. In like manner thrice and four times blessed (...) they
there, who leaning the unquiet toil that ordinarily does chance to them that
abide in Cities, do render (...) y of their studies to the Muses whereunto they
be most minded. (...) Dom Diego at his own house loved and cherished of his
mother, reverenced and obeyed of his subjects after he had employed some time
at his study, had none other ordinary pleasure but in rousing the Dear,
hunting the wild Bore, run the Hare, sometimes to fly at the Heron or fearful
Partrich alongs the fields, Forrestes, pondes and stepe Mountains. It came to
pass one day, as he Hunted the wild Mountain Goat, which he had dislodged
upon the Hill top, he espied an old Heart that his dogs had found, who so
joyful as was possible of that good luck, followed the course of that swift
and fearful beast. But (such was his Fortune) the dogs lost the foot of
that pray, and he his men: for being horssed of purpose, upon a fair Iennet,
could not be followed, and in end loosing the sight of the Dear, was so far
severed from company, as he was utterly ignorant which way to take. And that
which grieved him most was his horse out of breath skarse able to ride a false
galloppe. For which cause he put his horn to his mouth, and blewe so loud
as he could. But his men were so far off, as they could not hear him. The
young Gentleman being in this distress, could not tell what to do, but to
return back, wherein he was more deceived than before, for thinking to take
the way home to his Castle, wandered still further off from the same. And
trotting thus a long time, he spied a Castle situated upon a little Hill,
whereby he knew himself far from his own house. Nevertheless hearing a
certain noise of hunters, thinking they had been his people, resorted to the
same, who in deed were the servant of the mother of Gineura with the golden
locks, which in company of their mistress had hunted the Hare, Dom Diego, when
he drue nere to the cry of the Hounds, saw right well that he was deceived.
At what time night approached, and the shadows darkening the earth, by reason
of the suns departure, began to clothe the heavens with a brown and mistie
mantell. When the mother of Gineura saw the Knight which rode a soft pace, for
that his horse was tired, and could travail no longer, and knowing by his
outward apperaunce that he was some great Lord, and ridden out of his way, sent
one of her me^ to know what he was, who returned again with such answer as she
desired. The Lady joyful to entertain a Gentleman so excellent and famous,
one of her next neighbors, went forward to bid him welcome, which she did with
so great courtesy as the Knight said unto her: Madame I think that fortune
has done me this (...), by setting me out of the way, to prove your courtesy
and gentle entertainment, and to receive this joy by visiting your house,
whereof I trust in time to come to be so perfect a (...), as my predecessors
heretofore have been. Sir said the Lady, if happiness may be attributed to
them, yt most do gain, I think my self better favored than you, for that it
is my chance to lodge and entertain him, that is the worthiest person and
best beloved in all Catheloigne. The Gentleman blushing at that praise, said
nothing else, but that affection forced men so to speak of his virtues,
notwithstanding such as he was, he vowed from thence for the his service to her
and all her household. Gineura desirous not to be (...) in courtesy, said yt he
should not so do, except she were partaker of some part of that, which the
Knight so liberally had offered to the whole family of her mother. The Gentleman
which till that time took no heed to the divine beauty of the Gentlewoman,
beholding her at his pleasure, was so (...), as he could not tell what to
answer, his eyes were so fixed upon her, spending his looks in (...) of that
fresh hew, stained with a red Uermilion, upon the Alabaster and fair color of
her clear and beautiful face. And for the imbelishing of that natural
perfection, the attire upon her head was so couenable and proper, as it seemed
the same day she had looked for the coming of him, that afterward endured so
much for her sake. For her head was adorned with a Garlande of Flowers,
interlaced with her golden and enameled hair, which gorgeously covered some
part of her shoulders, (...) and hanging down, sometime over her passing fair
forhead, somewhiles upon her ruddie chekes, as the sweet and pleasant windy
breath did move them to and fro: ye should have seen her wavering and crisped
tresses disposed with so good grace and comeliness, as a man would have
thought that Love, and the three Graces could not tell elsewhere, to harbor
themselves, but in that rich and delectable place of pleasure, in gorgeous wise
laced and (...). Upon her ears did hang two sumptuous and rich oriental
perles, which to the artificial order of her hair added a certain splendent
brightness. And he yt had beholden the shining and large forhead of that
Nymph, which galantly was beset with a diamonde of inestimable price and value,
chased with a tresse of gold, made in form of (...) stars, would have
thought that he had seen a rank of the twinckelyng Planettes, fixed in the
(...) in the hottest time of Summer, when that fair season discovers the
order of his glitteryng clouds. In like manner the sparkling eyes of the fair
Gentlewoman, adorned with that goodly vaulte with two arches, equally by even
spaces distinct and divided, dyed with the (...) Indian tree, did so well
set forth their brightness, as the eyes of them that stayed their looks at
noone days directly upon the Sun, could no more be dazeled and offended,
than those were, that did contemplate those two flaming stars, which were in
force able thoroughly to pierce even the bottom of the inward parts. The nose
well formed, justly placed in the amiable valey of the visage, by equal
conformity distinguished the two cheeks, stained with a pure carnation,
resemblyng two little Apples that were arrived to the due time of their maturitie
and (...). And then her Coralline mouth, through which breathing, issued out
a breath more soot and sauorous than Ambre, Musk, or other aromatical parfume,
that ever the (...) soil of (...) brought forth. She sometime vnclosing the
door of her lips, discovered two rank of perles, so finely blanched, as the
purest Orient would blushe, if it were compared with the beauty of (...)
incomparable whiteness. But he that will take upon him to speak of al her
inspeakable beauty, may make his vaunte that (...) has seen all the
greatest perfections that ever dame Nature wrought. Now to come a little lower,
on this fresh Diana appeared a neck, that surmounted the blaunche color of
milk, were it never so excellent white, and her stomach somewhat mounting by
the two pomels and firm teates of her breasts, separated in equal distaunce,
was covered with a veil, so lose and (...), as those two little pretty
mountains might easily be seen, to move and remove, according to the affection
that rose in the center of that modest and sober pucelles mind: who over and
besides all this, has such a pleasant countenance and ioyefull cheer, as
her beauty more than wonderful, rendered her not so worthy to be served and
loved, as her natural goodness and disposed courtesy appearyng in her face,
and her excellent entertainment and comely grace to all indifferently. This was
not to imitate the manner of the most part of our fair Ladies and (...), who
(moved with what opinion I know not) be so disdaynfull, as almost their name
causes coffeehouse, and breeds in them great imperfection, who by
thinking to appear more brave and fine, by too much squeymishe dealyng, do
offuscate and darken with Folly their exterior beauty, blotting and defacing
that which beauty makes amiable and worthy of honor. I leave you now to
consider whether Dom Diego had occasion to forgo his speech, and to be berest
of (...), being lively assailed with one so well armed as Gineura was with her
graces and honesty: who no less abashed with the port, countenance, sweet
talk, and stately behauior of the knight, which she vewed to be in him by
stealing lokes, felt a motion (not wo^ted or accustomed) in her tender heart, ye
made her to change color, and by like occasion spechlesse: an ordinary custom
in the^ yt be surprised with ye malady of love to lose yt use of spech where
the same is most necessary to give the intier charge in the heart, which not
able to support and bear the burden of so many passions, departs some
portion to the eyes, as to the faithful messangers of the minds secret
conceits, which tormented beyond measure, and burning with affection, causes
sometimes the humor to gushe out in that part that discovered the first
assault, and bredde the cause of that fever, which frighted the hearts of those
two young persons, not knowing well what the same might be. When they were come
to the Castle, and dismounted from their horse, many welcomes and gratulations
were made to the knight, which yielded more wood to the fire, and lively touched
the young Gentleman, who was so outraged with love, as almost he had no mind of
himself, and rapt by little and little, was so intoxicated with amorous passion,
as all other thoughts were loathsome, and joy displeasant in respect of the
favorable martyrdom which he suffered by thinking of his fair and gentle
Gineura. Thus the knight which in the morning disposed him self to pursue the
heart, was in heart so attached, as at evening he was become a servant, yea and
such a slave, as yt voluntary servitude wholly dispossessed him from his former
freedom. These be the fruits also of folly, inuegling the eyes of men, that
launch themselves with eyes shut into the gulf of despair, which in end does
cause the ruin and overthrow of him, that yeldeth thereunto. Love proceeds
never but of opinion: so likewise the ill order of those that be afflicted with
that passion, rises not elsewhere, but by the fond persuasion which they
conceive, to be blamed, despised and deceived of the thing beloved: where if
they measured that passion according to his valor, they would make no more
account of that which does torment them, than they do of their health, honor
and life, who for their service and labor delude them, and recompense an other
with that which the foolish lover shall employ, that does haste despair to him,
and end more than desperate, by seeing an other come to enjoy that, for which
he has beat the bushes. During the time that supper was preparing, the Lady
sent her men to seek the huntesmen of Dom Diego, to give them knowledge where
he was become, and thereof to certify his mother, who when she heard tell that
he lay there, was very glad, being a right good friend and very familiar
neighbor with the Lady, the hostess of her (...). The Gentleman supping after
he had tasted the fervent heat that broiled in his mind, could eat little
meat, rather satisfied with the feeding diete of his amorous eyes, which
without any manner of jealousy, distributed their nourishment to the heart, and
(...) very soberly, privily throwing his secret pricks, with lovely and
wanton look, to the heart of the fair Lady, which for her part spared not to
render usury of rollyng looks, whereof he was so sparing, as almost he durst
not lift up his eyes for dazelyng of the same. After supper, the Knight bidding
the mother and daughter good night, went to bed, where in steed of sleep,
he fell to sighing and imagening a thousand diverse (...) (...) like number of
follies, such as they do whose brains be fraught with love. Alas (said he)
what means it, that always I have lived in so great liberty, and now do
feel my self attached with such bondage as I can not express, whose effects
nevertheless be fastened in me? Have I hunted to be taken? Came I from my house
in liberty, to be shut up in prison, and do not know whether I shall be
received, or being received, have interteinement, according to my desert? Ah
Gineura, I would to God, that thy beauty did prick me no worsse, than the
tree whereof thou take thy name, is sharp in touching, and bitter to them
that (...) the same. Truly I esteem my coming hither happy (for all the
passion that I endure) since the purchase of a grief so luckie does qualify
the joy, that made me to wander thus over (...). (...) fair amongs the fairest,
truly the fearful beast which with the bloody hareboundes was torn in pieces,
is not more martired, than my heart divided in opinions upon thine affection.
And what do I know if thou love an other more worthy to be fa uored of thee
tha^ thy poor Dom Diego. But it is impossible yt any can approach ye sincerity
ye I feel in my heart, determining rather to endure death, tha^ to serve other
but fair and golden Gineura: therefore my loyalty receiving no comparison
cannot be matched in man sufficient (for respect of ye same) to be called
servant of thine (...). Now come what shall, by means of this, I am assured yt
so long as Dom Diego lives, his heart shall receive none other impression or
desire, but yt which inciteth him to love, serve, and honor ye fairest
creature at this day within the compass of Spain. (...) herevpo^, sweating,
laboring and traveling upon ye framing of his love, he found nothing more
expedient tha^ to tell her his passion, and let her understand ye good will yt he
had to do her service, and to pray her to accept him for such, as from that
time forth would perpetrate nothing but under yt title of her good name. On ye
other side Gineura could not close her eyes, and knew not yt cause almost yt so
(...) her of sleep, wherefore now tossing on ye one side, and the^ turning to
ye other inhir rich and goodly bed, fa^tasied no fewer devises tha^ passionated
Dom Diego did. In ye end she concluded, yt if yt knight showed her any evident
sign, or opened by word of mouth of love and service, she would not refuse to do
the like to him. Thus passed ye night in thoughts sighs and wishes between
these. (...). apprentises of the thing, whereof they yt be lerners, shall sone
attain ye experience, and they yt follow the occupation thoroughly, in short time
be their (...) masters. The next day yt knight would depart so soon as he was
up: but ye good widow, embracing yt personage and good order of ye knight in
her heart, more tha^ any other that she had seen of long time, entreated (...)
so earnestly to tarry as he which loved better to obey her request tha^ to
depart, although fained ye contrary, in yt end appeared to be vanquished upon ye
great importunity of the lady. All that morning yt mother and the daughter
passed the time with Dom Diego in great talk of common matters. But he was then
more astoonned and inamored than the night before, in such wise as many times
he (...) so unaptly to their demau^ds, as it was easily perceived that his
mind was much disquieted with some thing, yt only did possess ye force and
veheme^ce of yt same: not withstanding ye lady imputed yt to ye (...) of yt
gentleman, and to his simplicity, which had not greatly freque^ted yt company
of Ladies. When diner time was come, they were served with such great fare and
sundry delicates, accordingly as with her heart she wished to intertain ye young
lord, to ye intent from that time forth, he might more willingly make repair
to her house. After diner he re^dred thanks to his hostess for his good cheer
and intertainment that he had received, assuring her, yt all ye days of his
life he would employ himself to recompense her courtesy, and withal duty and
endeavor to acknowledge that favor. And having taken his leave of the mother, he
went to ye damsel, to her I say, that had so sore wounded his heart, who
already was so depely graue^ in his mind, as ye mark remained there for ever,
taking leave of her, kissed her hands, and thinking verily to express yt
whereupon he imagined al ye night, his tongue and wits were so tied and rapt, as
the ge^tlewoman perfectly perceived this alteration, whereat she was no whit
disco^tented and therefore all blushyng, said unto him: I pray to God sir, to
ease and comfort your grief, as you leave us desirous and glad, long to enjoy
your company. Truly Gentlewoman (answered the Knight,) I think my self more
than happy, to hear that wysh proceed from such a one as you be, and
specially for the desire which you say you have of my presence, which shall be
ever ready to do that which it shall please you to (...). The Gentlewoman
bashful for that offer, thanked him very heartily, praying him with sweet and
smiling countenance, not to forget the way to come to visit them, being well
assured, that her mother would be very glad thereof. And for mine own part
(quod she) I shall think my self happy to be partaker of the pleasure and
great amity that is between our two houses. After great reverence and leave
taken between them, Dom Diego returned home, where he told his mother of the
good interteynement made him, and of the great honesty of the Lady his
hostess: wherefore Madame (quod he to his mother) I am desirous (if it be your
pleasure) to let them know how much their bountiful hospitality has tied me
to them, and what desire I have to recompense the same. I am therefore willing
to bid them hither, and to make the^ so good cheer, as with all their heart
they made me when I was with them. The Lady which was the assured friend of
the mother of Gineura, liked well the advice of her son, and told him that
they should be welcome, for the aunciente amity of long time between them,
who was wont many times to visit one an other. Dom Diego upon his mothers
words, sent to entreat the Lady and fair Gineura, that it would please them
to do him the honor to come unto his house: To which request she so
willingly yielded, as he was desirous to bid them. At the appointed day Dom
Diego sought al means possible honorably to intertaine them: In meats whereof
there was no want, in instruments of all sorts, Mummeries, Morescoes, and a
thousand other passetimes, whereby he declared his good bryngyng up, the
gentleness of his spirit, and the desire that he had appear such one as he
was, before her, which had already the full possession of his liberty. And
because he would not fail to accomplish the perfection of his intent, he
invited all the Gentlemen and Gentlewomen that were his neighbors. I will not
here describe the least part of the provision for that feast, nor the
diversity of meats, or the delicate kinds of wines. It shall suffice me to
tell that after dinner they daunced, where the knight took his mistress by the
hand, so glad to see her self so advanced, as he was content to be so near
her, that was the sweet torment and unspeakable passion of his mind, which he
began to discover unto her in this wise: Mistress Gineura, I have been always
of this mind, that Music has a certain secret hidden virtue (which well can
not be expressed) to revive the thoughts and cogitations of man, be they never
so mornful and pensive, forcing them to utter some outward rejoice: I speak it
by my self, for that I live in extreme anguish and pain, that all the joy of
the world seems unto me displeasaunt, care, and disquietnesse: and
nevertheless my passion, agreeing with the plaintiff voice of the instrument,
does rejoice and conceive comfort, as well to perceive insensible things
(...) to my desires, as also to see my self so near unto her, that has the
salve to ease my pain, to discharge my disease, and to deprive my mind from
all griefs. In like maner-reason it is, that she her self do remedy my
disease, of whom I received the prick, and which is the first foundation of
all mine evil. I can not tell (said the Gentlewoman) what disease it is you
speak of, for I should be very unkind to give him occasion of grief, that
does make us this great cheer. Ah Lady mine (said the Knight) fetching a
sighe from the bottom of his heart, the intertainement that I receive by the
continual contemplation of (...) beauties, and the unspeakable (...) (...)
those two beams, which twynckle in your (...), be they that happily do
vere me, and make me drink this cup of bitterness, wherein not wythstanding
I find such sweetness as all the heavenly drink called Ambrosia, feigned by
the Poets, is but gall in respect of that which I taste in mind, feelyng my
devotion so bente to do you service, as only Death shall untie the knotte
wherewith voluntarilye I knytte my self to be your servant for ever, and if
it so please you, your faithful and loyal friend and husband. The young
Damoselle not woonted for to hear such Songs, did change her color at
least three or four times, and nevertheless (...) a little anger of that
which did content her most: and yet not so sharp, but that the Gentleman
perceived well enough, that she was touched at the quycke, and also that he
was accepted into her good grace and favor. And therefore he continued still
his talk, all that time after dynner, and the maiden said unto him: Sir, I
will now confess that grief may cover alteration of affections proceedyng
from Love. For although I had determined to dissemble that which I think,
yet there is a thing in my mind (which I may not name) that governs me so
strongly, and draws me far from my propre devises and conceiptes, in such
wise as I am constrained to do that which this second inspiration does lead
me unto, and does force my mind to receive an Impression, that what will be
the end thereof, as yet I know not. Not withstandyng, reposyng me in your
virtue and honesty, and acknowledgyng your merit, I think my self happy to
have such (...) for friend, that is so fair and comely a Knight, and for
such I do accept you until you have obtained of my Lady my mother, the
second point, which accomplisheth that which is most desired of them, that
for virtues sake do love. For but only for that, you shall be none otherwise
favored of me, than hitherto you have been. Till now have I attended for this
right happy day of joy and bliss (said the (...)) in token whereof, I do
kiss your white and delicate hands, and for acknowledgyng the favor that
presently I do receive, whereby I may make my vaunt to (...) the servant of
her, that is the fairest, most courteous, and honest Gentlewoman on this side
the Mountains. As he had ended those words, they came to cover for
supper, where they were served so honorably, as if they had been in the
Court of the Monarch of Spain. After supper, they went to walk abroad
alongs the (...) side, besette with wyllowe trees, where both the beauty of
the time, the runnyng (...), the charm of the natural music of birds, and
the pleasant murmr of the tremblyng leaves, at the whistelyng of the sweet
Western wind, moved them again to renew their passetyme after dynner. For
some did give them selves to talk, and to devise of (...) matter: some
framed nosegayes, garlandes, and other pretty poesyes for their friends: Other
some did leap, run, and throw the bar. In the end a great lord, neighbor
to Dom Diego, whose name was Dom Roderico, knowing by his friends countenance to
what saint he was vowed, and perceiving for whose love (...) feast was
celebrate, took by (...) hand a gentlewoman that sat next to fair Gineura,
and (...) her to dance after a song, whereunto she being pleasant and wise,
made no great refusal. Dom Diego failed not to join with his mystresse, after
whom followed the rest of that noble train, every of them as they thought
best. Now the Gentlewoman, that began to dance, song this song so apt for
the purpose, as if she had entered the heart of the enemy and mystresse of
Dom Diego, or of purpose had made the same in the name of her, whom the
matter touched above the rest.

Who may better sing and dance amongs us Ladies all,
Than she that does her lovers heart possess in bondage thrall?
The young and tender feblenesse
Of mine unskillful age,
Whereof also the tenderness
Does feeble heart assuage:
Whom beauties force has made to frame
Unto a lovers hest.
So soon as first the kindled flame
Of loving toys increst.
Who may better sing and dance, amongs us Ladies all,
Than she that does her lovers heart possess in bondage thrall?
I have assayed out to put
The fire thus begoonne,
And have attempted of to cut
The threede which love has spoonne:
And new alliance feign would flee
Of him whom I love best,
But that the Gods have willed me
To yield to his request.
Who may better sing and dance amongs us Ladies all,
Than she that does her lovers heart possess in bondage (...)
So amiable is his grace,
Not like among us all:
So passing fair is his face,
Whose hue does stain us all:
And as the shining sunny day
Does every man delight,
So he alone does bear the sway,
Amongs each loving wight.
Who may (...) sing and dance amongs us Ladies all,
Than she that does her lovers heart possess in bondage thrall?
Why should not then, the fairest dame,
Apply her gentle mind,
And honor give unto his name,
With humble heart and kind?
Since he is full of courtesy,
Indewd with noble grace,
And breast replete with honesty,
Well known in every place.
Who may better sing and dance amongs us Ladies all,
Than she that does her lovers heart possess in bondage thrall?
If I should love, and serve him than,
May it be counted vice?
If I retain that worthy man,
Shall I be demde unwise?
I will be gentle to him sure,
And render him mine aid:
And love that wight with heart full pure,
That never love assaide.
Who may better sing and dance amongs us Ladies all,
Than she that does her lovers heart possess in bondage thrall?
Thus the most sacred unity,
That does our hearts combine:
Is void of wicked flattery,
The same for to (...).
No hardened rigor is our guide,
Nor folly does us lead:
No Fortune can us twain divide,
Until we both be dead.
Who may better sing and dance amongs us Ladies all,
Than she that does her lovers heart possess in bondage (...)?
And thus assured certainly,
That this our love shall dure,
And with good luck hope verily,
The same to put in ure.
The sown seeds of amity,
Begone betwixt us twain,
Shall in most perfect unity,
For evermore remain.
Who may better sing and dance amongs us Ladies all,
Than she that does her lovers heart possess in bondage thrall!
This song delited the minds of many in yt company, and principally Dom Diego
and Gineura, who felt themselves tickled without laughing: notwithstanding, the
maiden reioysed to hear her self so greatly praised in so noble a company, and
specially in yt presence of her friend who had no less pleasure by hearing the
praises of his beloved, than if he had been made Lord of all Aragon. She for
all her dissembled countenance used openly, could not hide the alteration of
her mind, without sending forth a sudden change of color, yt increased yt
fair and goodly taint of her face. Dom Diego seeing yt mutation, was so joyful
as was possible, for thereby he knew and judged himself assured of the good
grace of his mistress and therefore wringing her finely by the hands, said unto
her very soberly (...). What greater pleasure my loving wench can there happen
unto your servant, than to see the accomplishme^t of this Prophetical (...)? I
assure you yt in all my life I never heard music, yt delited me so much as
this, and thereby do understand yt good will of the Gentlewoman, which so
courteously has discovered yours toward me, and the faithful service where of
you shall see me from hence forth so liberal, as neither goods nor life shall
be spared for your sake. Gineu^ra who loved him with all her heart, thanked him
very humbly, and prayed him to believe that the song was not un truly soong, and
yt without any fail, she had thereby manifested all the secrets of her mind. The
dance ended, they sat them down round about a clear fountain, which by
silent discourse, issued from an high and moisty rock, enuiro^ned with an
infinite number of Mapletrees, Poplers and Ashes. To which place a page brought
a lute to Dom Diego, whereupon he could play very well, and made it more
pleasa^tly to sound for that he accorded his fayning voice to the instrument,
singing this song that follows.

That I should love and serve also, good reason does require,
What though I suffer loathsome grief, my life in woe to wrappe?
The same be thonely instruments, of my good luck and hap,
The food and pray for hungry corpse, of rest th'assured hire.
By thought whereof (O heavy man) gush forth of tears great store
And by and by reioyst again, my driery tears do cease:
Which guerdon shall mine honor sure, in that triumpha^t peace,
The sum whereof I offer now, were it of price much more.
Which I do make withal my heart, unto that blessed wight,
My proper Goddess here on earth, and only mistress dear:
My goods and life, my brething ghost within this carcass here,
I vow unto that majesty, that heavenly star most bright.
Now since my willing vow is made, I humbly pray her grace,
To end th'accord between us pight, no longer time to tracte:
Which if it be by sured band, so happily brought to pass,
I must my self thrice happy count, for that most heavenly fact.
This song made the company to muse, who commided the trim invention of the
Knight, and above al Gineura praised him more than before, and could not so
well refrain her lokes from him, and he with country change rendering like
again, but that the two widows their mothers conceived great heed thereof,
rejoicing greatly to see the same, desirous in time to couple them together.
For at that present they deferred the same, in consideration they were both
very young. Notwithstanding it had been better that the same conjunction had
been made, before fortune had turned the wheel of her unstableness. And
truly delay and prolongation of time sometimes brings such and so great
missehaps, that one hundred times men curse their fortune, and little advise
in foresight of their unfortunate chances that commonly do come to pass. As
it chanced to these widows, one of them thinking to loose her son by the
vain behauior of the others daughter, who without yt help of God, or care
unto his will, disparaged her honor, and prepared a poison so dangerous for
her mothers age, that the food thereof prepared the way to the good Ladies
grave. Now whiles this love in this manner increased, and that desire of these
two Lovers, flamed forth ordinarily in fire and flames more violent, Dom Diego
all changed and transformed into a new man, received no delight, but in the
sight of his Gineura. And she thought that there could be no greater felicity,
or more to be wished for, than to have a friend so perfect, and so well
accomplished with all things requisite for the ornament and full furniture of a
Gentleman. This was the occasion that the young Knight let no week to pass
without visiting his mistress twice or thrice at the least, and she did unto
him the greatest courtesy and best entertainment, that virtue could suffer a
maiden to do, who is the diligent treasurer and careful tutor of her honor.
And this she did by consent of her mother. In like manne, rhonestie does not
permit yt chaste maidens should use long talk, or immoderate speech, with the
first that be suitors unto them: and much less seemly it is for them to be
over squeimishe nice, with that man which seeks (by way of marriage) to win
power and title of the body, which in very deed, is or ought to be the moitie
of their soul. Such was yt desires of these two Lovers, which notwithstanding
was impeeched by means, as hereafter you shall hear. For during the rebounding
joy of these fair couple of loyal lovers, it chanced that the daughter of a
noble man of the Country, named Ferrando de la Serre, which was fair, comely,
wise, and of very good behauior, by keeping daily company with Gineura, fell
extreemely in love with Dom Diego, and assayed by all means to do him to
understand what the puissance was of her love, which willingly she meant to
bestow upon him, if it would please him to honor her so much, as to love her with
like (...). But the Knight which was no more his own man, (...) rather
possessed of another, had lost with his liberty his wits, and mind to mark
the affection of this Gentlewoman of whom he made no account. The Maiden
nevertheless ceased not to love him, and to (...) al possible ways to make
him her own. And knowing how much Dom Diego loved Hawking, she bought a (...)
the best in all the Country, and sent the same to Dom Diego, who with all his
heart received the same, and effectuously gave her thanks for that desired
gift, praying the messanger to recommend him to the good grace of his
Mistress, and to assure her self of his faithful service, and that for her
sake he would keep the hauk so tenderly as ye balls of his eyes. This Hauk was
the cause of the ill fortune that afterward chanced to this pore lover. For
going many times to see Gineura with the Hawk on his fist, and bearing with
him the tokens of the goodness of his Hawk, it escaped his mouth to say,
that the same was one of the things that in all the world he loved best. Truly
this word was taken at the first bound contrary to his meaning, wherewith the
matter so fell out, as afterward by despair he was like to lose his life.
Certain days after, as in the absence of the Knight, talk rose of his virtue
and honest conditions, one prainsing his prowess and valiaunce, another his
great beauty and curtesy, another passing further, extolling the sincere (...)
and consta^cy which appeared in him touching matters of love, one envious
person named Gracian spoke his mind the^ in this wise: I will not deny but that
Dom Diego is one of the most excellent, honest and brauest Knights of
Catheloigne, but in matters of Love he seems to me so waltering and
inconstant, as in every place where he comes, by and by he falls in love,
and makes as though he were sick, and would die for the same. Gineura
maruelliing at those words, said unto him: I pray you my friend to use better
talk of the Lord Dom Diego. For I do think the love which the Knight does
bear to a Gentlewoman of this Country, is so firm and assured, that none
other can remove the same out of the siege of his mind: Lo how you be deceived
gentlewoman (quod Gracian,) for under color of (...) service, he and such as
he is do abuse the simplicity of young Gentlewomen. And to prove my saying
true, I am assured that he is extremely enamored with the daughter of Dom
Ferrando de la Serre, of whom he received an Hawk, yt he loves above all
other things. Gineura remembering the words which certain days before Dom
Diego spoke touching his Hawk, began to suspect and believe that which master
Gracian alleged, and not able to support the choler, which cold iealosie bred
in her stomach, went into her Chamber full of so great grief and heaviness, as
she was many times like to kill her self. In the end, hoping to be revenged of
the wrong which she believed to receive of Dom Diego, determined to endure her
fortune patiently. In ye mean time she conceived in her mind a despite and
hatred so great and extreme against the pore. Gentleman that thought little
hereof, as the former love was nothing in respect of the revenge by death,
which she then desired upon him. Who the next day after his wonted manner came
to see her, having (to his great damage) the Hawk on his fiste, which was the
cause of all that iealosse. Now as the Knight was in talk with the mother,
seeing that his beloved came not at all (according to her custom) to salute
him and bid him welcome, inquired how she did. One that loved him more than the
rest, said unto him: Sir, so soon as she knew of your coming, immediately
she withdrew her self into her Chamber. He that was wise and well trained up,
dissembled what he thought, imagining that it was for some little fantasy,
whereunto women willingly be subject. And therefore when he thought time to
depart, he took leave of the widow, and as he was going down the stairs
of the great Chamber, he met one of the maids of Gineura, whom he prayed to
commend him to her mistress.

Gineura during all this time took no rest, devising how she might cut of
clean her love entertained in Dom Diego, after she knew that he carried the
Hawke on his fist: which was the only cause that did put her into that frenzy.
And therefore thinking her self both despised and mocked of her Knight, and
that he had done it in despite of her, she entered into so great rage and
choler, as she was like to fall mad. She being then in this trouble of mind,
behold her Gentlewoman came unto her, and did the Knights message. Who hearing
the simple name of her supposed enemy, began to sigh so strangely, as a man
would have thought her soul presently would have departed her body. Afterward
when she had vanquished her raging fit which stayed her speech, she began very
tenderly to weep, saying: Ah traitor and unfaithful lover, is this the
recompense of the honest and firm amity which I have borne thee, so wickedly
to deceive me under the color of so faint and detestable a friendship? Ah
rash and arrant These, is it I upon whom thou ought to vende thy wicked
trumperies? Doste thou think that I am no better worth, but that thou
prodigally should wast mine honor to bear yt spoils thereof to her, that is
in nothing comparable unto me? Wherein have I deserved this discurtesie, if not
by loving thee more than thy beauty and fained love deserve? Did thou dare
to adventure upon me, having thy conscience wounded with such an abominable
and deadly treason? Durst thou to offer thy mouth to kiss my hand, by the
mouth of another, to whom thou had before dedicated thy lying lips in
thine own proper person? I praise God that it pleased him to let me see before
any other worse chance has happened, the poison by thee prepared for the
ruin of my life and honor. Ha fool, hope not to take me in thy trap, nor yet
to deceive me through thy sugared and deceitful words. For I swear by the
almighty God, that so long as I shall live, I will account thee none other, but
as ye most cruel and mortal enemy that I have in this world.

Then to accomplish the rest of her careful mind, she wrote a letter to give
her farewell to her old friend Dom Diego. And for that purpose instructed her
Page with this lesson, that when the Knight should come, he should be ready
before her lodging and say unto him in the behalf of her, that before he
passed any further, he should read the letter, and not to fail to do the
contents. The Page which was malicious, and ill affectioned to Dom Diego,
knowing the appointed day of his coming, waited for him a quarter of a mile
from the Castle, where he had not long tarried, but behold the innocent lover
came, against whom the Page went, bearing about him more hurtful and noisome
weapons, than all the Thieves and robbers had in all the Country of
Catheloigne. In this manner presenting his mistress letters, he said unto
him: My Lord, Madame Gineura my mistress has sent me unto you, and because
she knows how fearful you be to displease her, prays you not fail to
read this letter before you pass any further, and there withal accomplish
the effect of the same. The Knight abashed with that sudden message, answered
the Page: God forbid my friend (quod be) that I should disobey her by any
means, unto whom I have given a full authority and puissance over mine
affections. So receiving the letters, he kissed them three or four times, and
opening them, found that he hoped not for, and red that which he thought not
off. The co^tents whereof were these.

The Letters of fair Gineura, to the Knight Dom Diego.
THere shall pass no day of my life, from making complaints of thee disloyal
and perjured Lover, who being more esteemed and better beloved than (...)
did deserve, have made so small account of me, whereof I will be revenged
upon my self, for that I have thus lightly believed thy words so full of
craft and guile. I am in (...) that thou from hence for the shall fly, to
buzze and beat the bushes, where (...) suspectest to catch the pray: for
here thou art like to be deceived. Go varlet, (go I say,) to (...) her which
holds thee in her nets and snares, and whose Presents (although of small
value) have (...) thee more than the Honest, virtuous, and (...) Love, that
virtue her self began to knitte between us. And since a carrion Kite has made
thee (...) further off, than the wind of the air was able to bear thee, God
defend that Gineura should go about to hinder thy follies, and much less
to-suffer her self to be beguiled through thine excuses. (...) rather God
defend (except thou desire to see me die) that thou should ever be in
place where I am, assuring (...) of this my mind, never to be changed so long
as my soul shall rest within my body: which giving breath unto my panting
breast, shall never be other, but a mortal enemy to Dom Diego: and such one
as even to the Death will not fail to prosecute the (...) of the most
traitorous and unfaithful Knighte, that ever was girte with girdle, or armed
with sword. (...) behold the last favor that thou can, or ought to hope
of me, who lives not but only to martyr and (...) thee, and never shall be
other but

The greatest enemy that ever thou have, or shall have, Gineura the fair.


The miserable lover had no sooner red the contents of the letter, but lifting
up his (...) to the (...), he said: Alas, my God thou know well if ever I
have (...), that I ought to be banished from the place, where my contentation
is chiefly fixed, and from whence my heart shall never depart, chance what
missehappe and fortune so ever. Then tourning himself toward the Page, he
said: Sir Page my friend, say unto my Lady, most humbly commending me unto
her, that for this present I will not see her, but heareafter she shall hear
some news from me. The Page well lessoned for the purpose, made him answer,
saying: Sir she has willed me to say thus much by mouth, that ye cannot do
her greater pleasure, than never to come in place where she is: for so much as
the Daughter of Dom Ferrando de la Serre has so (...) you in her nets, that
loath she is your faithful heart should hang in balance, and expect the
uncertain love of two Ladies at once.

Dom Diego hearing the truth of his missehap, and the occasion of the same,
made light of the matter for that time, till at length the choler of his
mistress should begin to cool, that thereby she might know upon how brittle
ground she had planted a suspicion of her most faithful and loving
servant, and so retiring toward his house, altogether vexed and ill
contented, he went into his Chamber, where with his dagger he paunched the
gorge of the pore Bird, the cause of his Ladies (...), saying: Ha vile
carraine Kite, I swear by the blood of him, that thou shall never be the cause
again, to make her fret for such a trifling thing as thou art: I believe that
what so ever fury is hidden within the body of this curssed Kite, to engender
a Plague, the same now is seized on me, but I hope to do my mistress to
understand what Sacrifice I have made of the thing which was sent me, ready to
do the like upon mine own flesh, where it shall please her to command. So
taking ink and paper, he made answer to Gineura as follows.

The letters of Dom Diego to Gineura the fair.
BUt who would ever have thought (my Lady dear) that a light opinion could so
soon have divided and disparkled your good judgment, to condemn your Knight
before you had heard what he was able to say, for himself? truly I thought no
more to offend you, than the man which you never knew, although you have been
deceived by colored words, uttered by those that be envious of my hap, and
enemies of your joy, who have filled your mind full of false report. I swear
unto you (by God, my good Lady) that never thing entered into my fantasy more,
than a desire to serve you alone, and to avoid the acquaintance of all other,
to preserve for you a pure and entire heart. Whereof long agone I made you an
offer. In witness whereof I humbly (...) you to believe, that so soon as you
see this Bird (the cause of your anger and occasion of my mishap) torn and
pluckte in pieces, that my heart feels no less alteration or torment: for so
long as I shall understand your displeasure to endure against me, assure your
self my life shall abide in no less pain than my joy was great, when I
frankly possessed your presence. Be it sufficient (madame) for you to know,
that I never thought to offend you. Be contented I beseech you, with this
sacrifice which I send you, if not, that I do the (...) upon mine own body,
which without your good will and grace can not longer live. For my life
depending upon that only benefit, you ought not to be astoonned if the same
(...) his nourishmente does perish, as frustrate of that food, propre and
apt for his appetite: and by like means my said life shall revive, if it may
please you to spread your beams over mine obscure and base personage, and to
receive this (...) for a fault not committed. And so waiting a gentle answer
from your great (...), I humbly kiss your white (...) delicate hands with all
humility, praying God sweet lady, to let you se how much I suffer without
desert, and what puissaunce you have over him that (...) all your

Faithful and ever servant most obedient Dom Diego.


The letter closed and sealed, he delivered to one of his faithful and secret
servants, to bear (with the dead Hawk) unto Gineura, chargyng him
diligentely to take heed to her countenance, and above all, that faithfully
he should bear away that which she did say unto him for answer. His man
failed not to speed himself with diligence: and being come before Gineura, he
presented that which his master had sent her. She full of wrath and indignation,
would not once (...) to read the letter, and much less to accept the present
which was a witness of the contrary of that she did (...), and tournyng unto
the Messanger, she said: My friend, thou may go get thee back again,
with the self same charge which thou have brought, and say unto thy master,
that I have nothing to do with his Letters, his excuses, or any other things
that comes from his hands, as one having good expeperience of his sleightes
and deceipts. Tell him also, that I praise God, in good time I have taken heed
to the little faith and trust that is in him for a countergarde in time to
come, lightly never to be deceived. The seruyng man would feign have framed
an Oration to purge his master, but the fierce Gentlewoman brake of his talk,
saying unto him, that she was well resolved upon her intent, which was, that
Dom Diego should never recover place in her mind, and that she hated him as
much at that time as ever she loved him before. Upon which answer the
Messanger returned, so sorrowful for the misfortune of his master (knowing him
to be very innocent) as he knew full well into what despair his master would
(...), when he understood those pitiful and heavy news: not with standing
needs he must know them, and therefore when he was come before Dom Diego, he
recited unto him from point to point his embassage, and delivered him again
his letters. Whereof the unfortunate Gentleman was so sore assooned, as he was
like to have fallen down dead at that instant. Alas (said he) what ill luck
is this, that when I thought to enjoy the benefit of my attempt, Fortune
has revolted to bring me to the extremity of the most desperate man that
ever lived? Is it possible that my good service should be the cause of my
approached overthrow? Alas, what may true and faithful lovers henceforthe
hope for, if not the loss of their time, when after long deuoire and duty,
an Envious fool shall come to deprive them of their joy and gladness, and
they feeling the bitterness of their abandoned farewell, one that loves less
shall bear away the (...) (...) of such hope, and shall possess without
deserte the glory due to a good and faithful (...). Ah fair Gineura, that
thou see not the grief which I do (...), and the affection wherewith I
serve thee, and how much I would suffer to gain and recover thy good grace
and favor. Ha vain hope, which until now haste filled me, with myrthe and
gladness, altogether spente and powdered in the gaulle of operation of thy
bitter sauoure, and the taste of thy corrupted lycour: better it had been for
me at the beginning to have refused thee, than afterward received,
cherished, and sincerely beloved, to be banished for so light occasion, as I am
full sore ashamed to conceive the same within remembrance: but Fortune shall
not have her will over me: for so long as I shall live, I will continue the
servant of Gineura, and my life I will preserve, to let her understand the
force of Love: By continuance whereof, I will not stick to set my self on
fire with the lively flames of my passion, and then withdraw the (...) of my
joy, by the rigor and frowardness that shall proceed from her. When he had
finished his talk, he began to sigh and lament so straungely, as his man was
about to go to call the lady the mother of the Knighte his master: In whom
did appear such signs, as if Death had (...) at hand, or else that he
had been attached with the Spirit of phrenesie. But when he saw him about
to come again to himself, he said thus unto him: How now sir, will you cast
your self away for the foolish toy of an indiscreet girl, ill manered and
taught, and who perchance does all this, to prove how constant you would be?
No no sir, you must turn over an other leaf, and since you be determined to
love her, you must persevere in your pursuit. For at length it is impossible,
but that this diamont hardness, must needs be mollified, if she be not a
devil incarnate, more furious than the wildest beasts, which haunte the
deserts of Lybia. Dom Diego was comforted with that admonition, and purposed
to persist in his affection, and therefore sent many messages, gifts, letters,
and excuses to his angered mistress Gineura: But she made yet (...) account of
them than of the first, chargyng the messangers not to trouble them selves
about those (...), for she had rather die than to see him, or to receive any
thing from him, whom she hated above all things of the world. When news
hereof came to the knight, he was altogether impacient, and seeing the small
profit which he did gain by pursuing his foolish opinion, and not able to
bestow his love elsewhere, he determined to die: and yet unwilling to imbrue
his hands with his own blood, he purposed to wander as a varabunde into some
deserte, to perform the course of his unhappy and sorrowful days, hoping by
that means to quench the heat of (...) amorous rage, either by length of
time, or by (...), the last refuge of the miserable. For which purpose then,
he caused to be made two pilgrims weeds, ye one for himself, and the other
for his man, and prepared all their necessaries for his voyage. Then writing a
Letter to his Gineura, he called one of his men, to whom he said: I am going
about certain of mine affairs, whereof I will have no man to know, and
therefore when I am gone, thou shall tell my Lady mother what I say to thee,
and that within twenty days (God wyllyng) I mean to return. Moreover I
require thee, that four days after my departure, and not before, to bear
these letters to mistress Gineura, and if so be she refuse to receive them,
fail not to deliver them unto her mother: take heed therefore if thou love
me, to do all that which I have given thee in charge. Afterward he called his
servant unto him, which had done the first message unto Gineura, which was a
wise and gentle fellow, in whom the Knight reposed great affiance, to him he
declared al his enterprise, and the end whereunto his fierce determination did
extend. The good servant which loved his master, hearing his intent so
unreasonable, said unto him: Is it not enough for you sir to yield your self a
pray to the most fierce and cruel woman that lives, but thus to augment her
glory, by seeing her self so victorious over you? Are you ignorant what the
malice of women is, and how much they triumph in tormentyng the poor
blinded souls that become their servants, and what praise they attribute unto
(...), if by some misfortune they drive them to despair? Was it without cause
that the Sage in times paste did so greatly hate that sex and kind, as the
common ruin and overthrow of men? What moved the Greek Poet to sing these
verses, against all sorts of women?

A common woe though silly woman be to man,
Yet double joy again she does unto him bring:
The wedding night is one, as wedded folk tell can,
The other when the knell for her poor soul does ring.
If not for that he knew the happiness of man consisted more in avoiding the
acquaintance of that fury, than by embracing and cherishyng of the same, since
her nature is altogether like unto Aesops serpent, which being delivered from
peril and danger of death by the shephierd, for recompense thereof, (...) his
whole house with his venomous (...) and rammish breath. O how happy is he that
can master his own affections, and (...) a free man from that passion, can
rejoice in liberty, (...) from the sweet evil which (as I well (...)) is
the cause of your despair. But sir, your wisdom ought to vanquish those
light conceiptes, by setting so light of that your rebellious Gentle woman as
she is unworthy to be favored by so great a Lord as you be, who deserves a
better personage than hirs is, and a frendlier entertainemen than a farewell so
foolishly (...). Dom Diego, although that he took pleasure to hear those
discourses of his faithful servant, yet he showed so sour a countenance
unto him, as the other with this little word held his peace. Since then it is
so sir, that you be resolved in your missehappe, it may please you to accept me
to wait upon you, whither you are determined to go: for I mean not to live at
(...) ease, and suffer my master, in pain and in grief. I will be partaker of
that which Fortune shall prepare, until the heavens do mitigate their rage
upon you, and your predestinate mishappe. Dom Diego, who (...) no better
company, embraced him very lovingly, thanking him for the good will that he
bare him, and said: This present night about midnight, we will take our
(...), even that way whether our lotte and also Fortune shall guide us,
attending either the end of my passion, or the whole overthrow of my self.
Their intent they did put in proof: For at midnight yt Moon being clear when
all things were at rest, and the crickets chirping through the creauises of the
earth, they took their way unseen of any. And so soon as Aurora began to
garnish her mantle with the colors of red and white, and the morning star of
the Goddess of stealing love, appeared, Dom Diego began to sigh, saying: Ah ye
fresh and dewy mornings, that my hap is far from the contentation of others,
who after they have rested upon the cogitation of their ease and joy, do awake
by the pleasant chirpyng of the birds, to perform by effect that which the
shadow and fantasy of their mind, did present by dreaming in the night,
where I am constrained to separate by great distance exceeding vehement
continuation of my torments, to follow wild beasts, wandering from thence
where the greatest number of men do quietly sleep and take their rest. Ah
Venus, whose star now co^duceth me, and whose beams long ago did glowe
and kyndle my loving heart, how (...) it that I am not entreated according to
the desert of my constant mind and mening most sincere? Alas, I look not to
expect any thing certain from thee, since thou have thy course amongs the
wa^dring stars. Must the influence of one star yt rules over me, deface
that which yt (...) would to be accomplished, and that my cruel mistress,
deluding my languors and griefs triumphs over mina infirmity, and
ouerwhelmeth me with care and sorrow, that I live pining away, amongs the savage
beasts in yt wilderness? for somuche as (...) yt grace of my lady, all company
shall be so tedious and lothsom unto me, yt the (...) thought of a true (...) with
her, yt has the (...) of me, shall serve for yt comfort and true remedy of all
my troubles. Whiles he had with these pa^gs forgotten himself, he saw yt the
day began to wax clear, the Sun already spreading his golden beanies upon the
earth, and therefore began hastily to set forthwards, using byways, and far from
common used trades, so nere as he could, yt he might not by any means be
known. Thus they rode forth even until noone: but seeing their (...) to be
weary and faint, they lyghted at a village, sarre from the high way: where
they refreshed themselfes, and baited their horse until it was late. In this
sort by the space of three days they trauersed the (...), until they (...) to
the foot of a mountain, not frequented almost but by wild and savage
beasts. The country round about was very fair, pleasant, and fit for the
solitariness of the knight: for if shadow pleased him, he might be delighted
with the couerte of an infinite number of fruitful trees, where with only
nature had furnished those hideous and savage deserts. Next to the high and
well timbred forests, there were groves and bushes for exercise of hunting. A
man could desire no kind of veneson, but it was to be had in that wilderness:
there might be seen also a certain sharp and rude situation of craggy and
(...) rocks, which notwithstanding yielded some pleasure to yt eyes, to see them
tapissed with a pale moasure green, which disposed into a frizeled guise,
made the place pleasant and the rock soft, according to the fashion of (...).
There was also a very fair and wide cave, which liked him well, compassed round
about with fur (...), Cedre trees, pine apples, Cipres, and trees distillyng

sorts; and Maple trees; the leaves whereof felt into a lake or ponde, which
came by certain small gutters into a fresh and very clear fountain right

(...) that this place shall be yt monastery, to make yt (...) profession of

both the beauty and solitariness, which do rather commau^d us here to rest,
than any other place nere at band. The servant yielded to the pleasure of his

when they were a sleep. There the servant began to play the (...), and to

poollished and trimmed, as if he had been a carpenter well expert in yt

sometimes of the fruits of herbs, until they had devised to make a crosbow of

some stronger beast remained with the^ for gage: whose blood they pressed out

same in, as if it had been a right good dishe for the first course of their

knowing his masters sorrow and mishap, would never go out of his sight, but

uncomely for him that ought to be endued with good reason and judgment. But

sprake of such (...). (...) yt if it escaped the servant to be earnest and

see Dom Diego mount in choler against him, saying: Art you so hardy to speak

make thee feel how much the slander touches me at the heart yt thou vttrest
