that commit the wrong in co^plaining of her severity. Now sir said the servant,
I do in deed perceive what manner of thing the contagion of love is. For they
which once do feel the corruption of that air, think nothing good or sauory,

the world, to torment your self in this wise, and that she is the fondest

such talk again, either I will die, or thou shall depart out of my company,
for I cannot abide by any means to suffer one to despise her whom I do love and
honor, and shall so (...) during life. The servant loath to offend his master,
held his peace, heavy for all that in heart, to remember how the pore Gentleman
was resolved to finish there, (in the desert unknown to his friends) all the
remna^t of his life. And who as well for the evil order, and not (...)
nouriture, as for assiduall plaints and we(...), was become so pale and lean,
as he better resembled a dry chippe, than a man having feeling or life. His

of filth, altogether more like a wild and savage creature (such one as is
depainted in brutall form) than fair Dom Diego, so much commended and
esteemed through out the kingdom of Spain. Now leave we this amorous Hermit
to passionate and plain his misfortune, to see to what end the Letters came

Letters, his servant did his charge, and being come to the house of Gineura,
found her in the Hall with her mother, where kissing his masters letters, he
presented them with very great reverence to the Gentlewoman. Who so soon as
she knew that they came from Dom Diego, all changed into raging color and
foolish choler, threw them incontinently upon the ground, saying: Suffices it
not thy master, that already twice I have done him to understand, that I have
nothing to do with his letters nor Ambassades, and yet goes he about by such
assaults to increase my displeasure and agony, by the only remembrance of
his folly? The mother seeing that uncivil order, although she understood the
cause, and knew that there was some discord between the two Lovers, yet
thought it to be but light, since the Comike Poet does say:

The lovers often falling out,
And pretty wrangling rage:
Of pleasant love it is no dout,
The sure renewing gage.
She went unto her Daughter, saying: What great rage is this? Let me see that
letter that I may read it: For I have no fear yt Dom Diego can deceive me with
the sweetness of his honey words. And truly daughter you need not fear to
touch them, for if there were any poison in them, it proceaded from your
beauty that has bitten and stong the Knight, whereof if he assay to make you
a partaker, I see no cause why he ought to be thus rigorously rejected,
deserving by his honesty a better entertainment at your hands. In the mean
time one of the Serving men took up the letters, and gave them to the Lady,
who reading them, found written as follows.

The letters of Dom Diego to Mistress Gineura.
MY dearest and most wellbeloued Lady, since that mine innocence can find no
resting place within your tender corpse, what honest excuse or true reason so
ever I do allege, and since your heart declares it self to be implacable, and
not pleased with him yt never offended you, except it were for overmuch love,
which for guerdon of yt rare and incomparable amity, I perceive my self to be
hated deadly of you and in such wise contemned, as the only record of my name,
causes in you an insupportable grief and displeasure unspeakable. To avoid I
say your indignation, and by my mishap to render unto you some (...) and
contentment, I have meant to dislodge my self so far from this Country, as
neither you nor any other, shall ever hear by fame or true report, the place of
my abode, nor the grave wherein my bones shall rest. And although it be an (...)
hearts sorrow and torment, which by way of pen can not be declared, to be thus
misprised of you, whom alone I do love and shall, so long as mine afflicted
soul shall hang upon the feeble and brittle threede of life: yet for all that,
this grief falling upon me, is not so (...), as the punishment is grievous, by
imagining the passion of your mind, when it is (...) with (...) and wrath
against me, who lives not, but to wander upon the thoughts of your
perfections. And for so much as I do feel for the debilitie that is in me, that
I am not able any longer to bear the sour shockes of my bitter torments and
martyrdom that I presently do suffer, yet before my life do fail, and death
do sease upon my senses, I have written unto you this present letter for a
testimonial of your rigor, which is the mark that justifies my
vngyltinesse. And although I do complain of mine unhappy fortune, yet I mean
not to accuse you, only contented that each man do know, that firm affection
and eternal thraldom do deserve other recompense than a farewell so cruel.
And I am well assured, that when I am dead, you will pity our torment, knowing
then, although to late, that my loyalty was so sincere, as the report of those
was false, that made you believe, that I was very far in love with the
daughter of Dom Ferrande de la Serre. Alas, shall a noble Gentleman that has
been well trained up, be fordidden to receive the gifts that come from a
virtuous Gentlewoman? Ought you to be so incapable and void of humanity, that
the sacrifice which I have made of the poor bird, the cause of your
disdain, my repentance, my lawful excuses, are not able to let you see the
contrary of you persuation? Ah, ah, I see that the dark and obscure veil of
unjust disdain and (...) anger, has so blindfold your eyes, and (...) your
mind, as you can not judge the truth of my cause and the unrighteousness of
your quarrel. I will render unto you none other certificat of mine innocence,
but my languishing heart, which you clepe between your hands, feling such rude
intertainment there, of whom he looked for rejoice of his travels. But for
so much then as you do hate me, what rests for me to do, but to pro cure
destruction to my self? And since your pleasure consists in mine overthrow,
reason wills that I obey you, and by death to sacrifice my life in like manner
as by life you were the only mistress of my heart. (...) only thing chereth up
my heart, and makes my death more miserable, which is, that in dying so
innocent as I am, you shall remain faulty, the only cause of my ruin. My
life will depart like a puff, and soul shall vanish like a sweet so^mers
blast: whereby you shall be ever deemed for a cruel woman and bloody murderer
of your devout and faithful servants. I pray to God mine own sweet Lady, to
give you such contentation, joy, pleasure, and gladness, as you do cause
through your rigor, disco^tentation, grief and displeasure to the poor lan
guishing creature, and who for evermore shall be

Your most obedient and affected servant Dom Diego.


The good Lady having read the Letter, was so astoonned, as her words for a
long space stayed within her mouth, her heart panted, and spirit was full of
confusion, her mind was filled with sorrow, to consider the anguishes of the
poor vagabund and foster hermit. In the end before the household dissembling
her passion which moved her sense, she took her daughter aside, who^ very
sharply she rebuked, for that she was the cause of the loss of so notable and
perfect a Knight as Dom Diego was. Then she read the Letter unto her, and as
all her cloquence was not able to move that cruel damsel, more venomous than a
serpent against the knight who (as she thought) had not endured the one half
of that which his inconstancy and lightness and well deserved, whose
obstinate mind the mother perceiving, said unto her: I pray to God (dear
daughter) that for your (...), you be not blinded in your beauty, and for the
refusal of so great a benefit as is the allia^ce of Dom Diego, you be not
abused with such a one as shall dim the light of your renoume and glory,
which hitherto you have gained amongs the sobrest and modest maidens. Having
said so, the wise and sage widow, went toward the servant of Dom Diego, of who^
she demanded what (...) his master departed, which she knowing, and not igno
rant of the occasion, was more wroth than before: notwithsta^nding she
dissembled what she thought, and sending back his servant, she required him to
do her hearty commendations to the lady his mistress, which he did. The good
lady was joyful thereof, for not knowing yt co^tents of her sons letters, she
looked yt he had sent word unto his lady of the just hour of his return. But
when she saw that in. xx. days, nor yet within a month he came not, she could
not tell what to think, so dolorous was she for the absence of her son. The
time passing without hering any news from him she began to torment her self,
and be so pensive, as if she had heard certain news of his death. Alas (quod
she) and wherefore have the heue^s given me the possession of such an exquisite
fruit, to deprive me thereof before I do partake the goodness and
sweetness thereof, and enjoy the grifts proceeding from so goodly a stock. Ah
God, I fear that my immoderate love is the occasion of the loss of my (...),
and the whole ruin of the mother, with the demolition and wast of all our
goods. And I would that it had pleased God (my son) that hunters game had
never ben so dear, for thinkyng to catch the pray thou thy self was taken,
and thou wandering for thy better disport, missing the right way, so strangely
did (...), that hard it is to reduce thee into the right track again. At
least wise if I knew the place, whereunto thou art repaired to find again thy
loss, I would travail thither to bear (...) company, rather than to line
here void of a husband, betrayed by them whom I best trusted, and (...) from
the presence of thee my son, the staff and only comfort of mine old age,
and the certain hope of al our house and family. Now if the mother vered her
self, the son was eased with no great rejoice, being now a free citizen with
the beasts and fowls of the forestes, dens and caves, leaving not the
profunditie of the wooddes, the craggednesse of the rocks, or beauty of the
valey, without some sign or token of his grief. Sometime with a puncheon well
sharpened, serving him in steed of a penknife, he graued the success of his
love upon on hard stone. Other times the soft bark of some tender and new
grown spraye served him in place of paper or parchement. For there he carved
in (...) proprely combined with a knotte (not easily to be known) the name of
his Lady, interlaced so proprely with his own, that the finest (...) might be
deceived, to disciphre the right interpretation. Upon a day then, as he passed
his time (according to his custom) to muse upon his myssehaps, and to frame
his success of love in the air, he ingraued these verses on a stone by a
fountain side, adjoining to his savage and rusticall house.

If any forest Pan, does haunt here in this place,
Or Wandering Nymphe, has heard my woeful plaint:
The one may well behold, and view what drop of grace,
I have deseru'de, and eke what griefs my heart does taint,
The other lend to me some broke or shoure of rain,
To moist mine heart and eyes, the gutters of my brain.
Somewhat further of many times at the rising of the Sun, he mounted the
top of an high and green Mountain to solace himself upon the fresh and
green grass where four pillars were erected, (either naturally done by dame
Nature her self, or wrought by the industry of man,) which bore a stone in
form four square, well hewed, made and trimmed in manner of an Altar, upon
which Altar he dedicated these verses to the posterity.

Upon this holy squared stone, which Altar men do call,
To some one of the Gods above, that consecrated is,
This doleful verse I consecrate, in token of my thrall,
And deadly griefs that do my silly heart oppress.
And vex with endless pains, which never quiet is.
This woeful verse (I say) as surest gage of my distress,
I grave on Altar stone for ever to remain,
To show the heart of truest wight, that ever lived in pain.
And upon the brims of yt table, he carved these words:

This Mason work erected here, shall not so long abide,
As shall the common name of two, that now uncoupled be,
Who after froward fortune past, knit each in one degree,
Shall render for right earnest love, reward on either side.
And before his lodging in that wild and stony (...) upon the bark of a
goodly and lofty Beeche tree, feeling in himself an unaccustomed lustiness,
thus he wrote:

The increasing beauty of thy shape, extending far thy name,
By like increase I hope to see, so stretched forth my fame.
His man seeing him to begin to be merrily disposed, one day said unto him: And
wherefore sir serves yt lute, which I brought amongs our males, if you do not
assay thereby to recreate your self, and sing thereupon yt praises of her whom
you love so well: yea and if I may so say, by worshipping her, you do commit
Idolatry in your mind. Is it not your pleasure that I fetch the same unto you,
that by imitation of Orpheus, you may move the trees, rocks, and wild beasts
to bewail your misfortune, and witness the penance that you do for her sake,
without cause of so heinous punishment: I see well ((...) the Knight) yt thou
would I should be merry, but mirth is so far from me, as I am estraunged from
her yt holds me in this misery. Notwithstanding I will perform thy request,
and will awake that instrument in this desert place, wherewith sometime I
witnessed yt greatest part of my passions. Then the Knight receiving the Lute,
sounded thereupon this song ensuing.

The waves and troubled (...), that moves the seas aloft,
Which runs and roares against the rocks, and threatens dangers often,
Resembles lo the fits of love,
That daily do my fancy move.
My heart it is the ship, that drives on salt sea (...),
And reason sails with senseless wit, and never looks home,
For love is guide, and leads the dance,
That brings good hap, or bredes mischaunce.
The furious flames of love, that never cease sure,
Are loc the busy sails and oars, that would my rest procure,
And as in Skies, great winds do blo,
My swift desires runs, fleting so.
As sweet Zephyrus breath, in spring time fedes the flowers,
My mistress voice would joy my wits, by her most heavenly powers,
And would exchau^ge my state I say,
As Summer changes Winters day.
She is the Artique star, the gracious Goddess to,
She has the might to make and mar, to help or else vnde,
Both death and life, she has at call,
My war, my peace, my ruin and all.
She makes me live in woe, and guids my sighs and lokes,
She holds my fredome by a lace, as fish is held with hokes,
Thus by despair, in this concaite,
I swallow up both hoke and bait.
And in the deserts lo I live, among the savage kind,
And spend my time in woeful sighs, raisde up by care of mind,
All hopeless to, in pains I pine,
And joys for ever do resine.
I dread but Charons boat, if she no mercy give,
In darkness then my soul shall dwell, in Plutos reign to live,
But I believe, she has no care,
On him that caught is in her snare.
If she release my woe, a thousand thanks therefore,
I shall her give, and make the world to honor her the more,
The Gods in Skies will praise the same,
And (...) bear of her good name.
O happy is that life, that after torment (...),
And earthly sorrows on this mould, for better life shall (...),
And live amongs the Gods on high,
Where love and lovers never die.
O life that here I lead, I freely give thee now,
Unto the fair where ere she rests, and look thou show her (...)
I linger forth my years and days,
To win of her a crown of praise.
And thou my pleasant lute, cease not my songs to sound,
And show the torments of my mind, that I through love (...) found,
And always tell my Mistress still,
Her worthy virtues rules my will.
The Foster Lover.
The Foster lover singing this song, sighing (...) times between, the trickling
tears ran down his face: who thereby was so disfigured, as searse could they
have known him, which had all the days of their life frequented his company.
Such was the state of this miserable young gentleman, who dronk with his own
wine, balanced himself down to despair rather than (...) the hope of that which
he durst not look for. Howbeit like as the mischiefs of men be not always
durable, and that all things have their proper season, eue^ so fortune
repenting her evil entreaty, which wrongfully she had caused this pore
penetenciarie of Gineura to endure, prepared a means to readuaunce him aloft
upon her wheel, even when he thought least of it. And certes, herein appeared
the mercy of God, who causes things difficult and almost impossible to be so
easy, as those that ordinarily be brought to pass. How may it hereby be
perceived, that they which were plu^ged in the bottom (...) defiance, deeming
their life utterly forlorn, be sone exalted even to the top of all glory and
felicity? Has not our age seen that man which was by authority of his
enemy judged to die, ready to be carried forth to the scaffold miraculously
delivered from that danger, and (wherein the works of God are to be marvelled)
yt same man to be called to the dignity of a prince, and preferred above all
the rest of the people. Now Dom Diego attending his fieldish Philosophy in the
solitary valeis of the rich Mountain Pyrene, was helped with help unlooked
for, as you shall hear.

You have hard how he had a neighbor and singular fre^d, (...) Noble gentleman
named Dom Roderico. This ge^tleman amongs al his faithful companions, did most
lament the hard fortune of Dom Diego. It came to pass. (...), months after yt
the pore wild penitent person was gone on his pilgrimage, yt Dom (...) took his
journey into Gascoine for diverse his vrge^t affairs, which after he had
dispatched, were it yt he was gone out of his way, or that God (as it is most
likely) did drive him thither, he approached toward yt coast of the Pyrene
mountains, where yt time his good friend Dom Diego did inhabit, who daily grew
so weak and feeble, as if God had not sent him sudden succor, he had gained yt
he most desired, which was death yt should have been the end of his trauails and
afflictions. The train of Dom Roderico being the^ a bow shot off from the
savage caben of Dom Diego, they espied the tracts of men's feet newly (...),
and began to marvel what he should be yt dwelled there, considering ye solitude
and (...) of the place, and also that ye same was far of (...) or house. And as
they devised hereupon, they saw a man going into a Cave, which was Dom Diego,
coming from making his complaints upon the rock (...) (...) before. From which
having (...) his face toward that part of the world where he thought ye
lodging was of that saint, whereunto he addressed his deuotio^s, Dom Diego
hearing the noise of the horse, was retired because he would not be seen. The
knight which rode that way, seeing that, and knowing how far he was out of the
way, commanded one of his men to gallop toward the Rock, to learn what
people they were yt dwelled (...), and to demand how they might coast to the
high way yt led to Barcelone. The servant approaching near the cave, perceived
the same so well empaled and fortified (...) beastres skins before, fearing
also yt they were thieves and robbers yt dwelled there, durst not approach, and
less enquire the way, and therefore returned toward his master to whom he told
what he saw. The Knight of another manner of metal and hardiness than yt
rascal and coward servant, like a stout, courageous and valiant man, (...) to
the cave, and demanding who was within, he saw a man come forth so
disfigured, horrible to look upon, pale with staring hair upright, that
pitiful it was to behold him, which was the servant of the foster hermit. Of
him Roderico demanded what he was, and which was yt way to Barcelone. (...)
answered yt disguised person: I know not how to answer your demand, and much
less I know the country where we now presently be. But sir said he sighing,
true it is yt we be two pore co^panio^s whom fortune has sent hither, by what
il adventure I know not, to do penance for our trespasses and offenses.
Roderico hearing him say so, began to call to his remembrance his friend Dom
Diego, although he never besore yt time suspected the place of his above. He
lighted then from his horse, desirous to see the singularities of yt (...),
and the magnificence of yt cauish lodging, where be entered and saw him whom he
sought for, and yet for all that did not know him: he co^moned with him a long
time of the pleasure of yt solitary life in respect of them that lived
entangled with the co^bresome follies of this world. For So Much quod he as yt
sprite distracted and withdrawn from worldly troubles is eleuable to the
conte^plation of heavenly things, and sooner attends to the knowledge and
reverence of his God, than those yt be conuersa^t amongs me^, and to conclude,
the complaints, yt delites, ambitions, covetousness, vanities and
superfluities yt abou^d in ye co^fused maze of worldly troup, do cause a
misknowledge of our selves, a forgetfulness of our creator, and many times a
negligence of piety and pureness of religion.

Whiles ye unknown Hermit and the Knight Roderico talked of these things, the
servant of To. visiting all the corners of the deep and stony cel of those
penite^ts, by fortune espied two saddles, one of the^ richly wrought and armed
with plates of steel, yt had been meet for some goodly Ienet. And upon the
plate well wrought, graven and enameled, the gold for all the rust cankring
the plate, did yet appear. For which purpose one of the^ said to yt servant of
Dom Diego. Good father hitherto I see neither Mule nor horse, for whom these
saddles ca^ serve, I pray (...) to sell them unto us, for they will do us more
pleasure, than presently they do you. Masters (quod the Hermit,) if they like
you, they be at your commandment. In the mean time Roderico having ended his
talk with the other Hermit, without knowing of any thing that he desired, said
unto his me^. Now sirs to horse, and leave we these pore people to rest in
peace, and let us go seek for the right way which we so well as they have
lost. Sir (quod one of his me^,) there be. y. saddles, and one of them is so
exceeding fair, so well garnished and wrought as ever you saw. The knight feling
in himself an unaccustomed motion, caused the^ to be brought before him, and as
he viewed and marked the rich harness and trappings of the same, he stays to
look upon the hinder part minonly wrought, and in the mids of the engrauing he
red this devise in the Spanish tongue.

Que brantare la fe, es causa muy fea. That is to say. To violate or break
faith, is a thing detestable. That only inscription made him to pause a little
more. For it was the Poesy yt Dom Diego bore ordinarily about his arms, which
moved him to think yt without doubt one of those Pilgrims was the very same
man to whom yt saddle did appertain. And therefore he bent himself very
attentively afterward to behold first the one, and then the other of those
desert Citizens. But they were so altered, as he was not able to know the^
again. Dom Diego seeing his friend so near him, and the desire yt he had to
know him, chafed very much in (...) mind and the more his rage began to ware,
when he saw Roderico approach near unto him more advisedly to look upon him,
for he had not his own affections so much at commandment, but his blood
moved his entrails, and mounting into the evident place, caused outwardly the
alteration which he endured, to appear. Roderico seeing him to change color,
was assured of that which before he durst not suspect: and that which made him
yt (...) believe yt he was not deceived, was a little tuft of hair, so yelow as
gold, which Dom Diego had upon his neck, whereof Don't Roderico taking heed,
gave over al suspicion, and was well assured of yt he doubted. And therefore
displaying himself we his arms opened upon the (...) of his friend, and
embracing him very lovingly, bedewing his face with tears, said unto him: Alas
my Lord (...) Diego, what evil luck from heaven has departed you (...) yt good
company of the^ which die for sorrow, to see themselves be reued of yt beuty,
light and orname^t of their fellowship: What be they that have given you
occasion thus to eclipse the brightness of your name, when it ought most
clearly to shine, both for your present pleasure, and for the honor of your
age? Is it from me sir, that you ought thus to hide your self? Do you think
how I am so blind, that I know not right well, you to be that Dom Diego, that
is so renoumed for virtue and prowess? I would not have tarried here so long,
but to bear away a power to rejoice two persons, you being the one, by
withdrawing you from this heavy and unseemly wilderness, and my self the
other, by enjoying your company, and by bearing news to your friends, who
since your departure, do bewail and lament the same. Dom Diego seeing that he
was not able to conceyle the truth of that which was evidently seen, and
feeling the loving imbracements of his best friend, began to feel a certain
tenderness of heart like unto that which the mother conceiueth, when she has
recovered her son that was long absent, or the chaste wife, the presence of
her dear husband, when she clepeth him between her arms, and frankely
culleth and cherishes him at her pleasure. For which cause not able to refrain
any longer for joy and sorrow together, weping and sighing began to embrace him
with so good and hearty affection, as with good will the other had sought for
his knowledge And being come again to him self, he said to his faithful and
most loving friend: Oh God, how uneasy and difficult be thy judgments to
comprehend? I had thought to live here miserably, unknown to all the world, and
behold, I am here discovered, when I thought lest of it: I am (...) deed (quod
he to Roderico) that wretched and vnfortuante Dom Diego, even that your very
great and loving friend, who werie of his life, afflicted with his unhap, and
tormented by fortune, is retired into these deserts, to accomplish the
overplus of the rest of his ill luck. Now since that I have satisfied you
herein, I beseech you that being content with my sight, ye will get you hence and
leave me here to perform that little remna^t which I have to live, without
telling to any person that I am alive, or yet to manifest (...) place of my
abode. What is that you say sir (said Roderico) are you so far straught out
of your right wits, to have a mind to continue this brutal life, to deprive al
your friends from the joy which they receive by inioying your company? Think I
pray you, that God has caused us to be borne noble men, and having power and
authority not to live in corners, and buried amid the slave rye of the popular
fort, or remain idle within great palaces or privy places, but rather to
illustrat and give light with the example of our virtue to them which apply
themselves to our manner of good behauior, and do live as depending upon our
(...) and commau^dements: I appele to your faith, what good shall succeed to
your subjects, who have both heard and also known the benefit bestowed upon
them by god, for that he gave them a lord so modest and virtuous, and before
they have experimented the goodness and virtue, be deprived of him, that is
adorned and garnished with such perfections? What comfort, contentation and
(...) shall my lady your mother receive, seeing the loss of you to be so
sudden, after your good and delicate bringing up, instructed with such great
diligence to be utterly bereued of yt fruit of that educatio^? It is you sir,
yt may command obedience to parents, succor yt afflicted, and do justice to
the^ that crave it: Alas, they be your poor subjects yt make complaints, even
of you, for denying the^ your due presence. It is you of who^ my good madame
does complain, as of him yt has broken and violated his faith, for not
coming at yt promised day. Now as he was about to to continue his oration, Dom
Diego unwilling to hear him, brake his talk saying: Ah sir, and my great
friend: It is an easy matter for you to judge of mine affairs, and to blame
mine absence, not knowing peradventure ye occasion ye same. But I esteem you a
man of so good judgment, and so great a fre^d of things honest, and of the same
(...), as by understanding my hard luck when you be advertised of yt cause of
my withdrawing into this solitarieplace, you will right ly confess, and plainly
see that the wisest and most constant have committed more vain folies than
these done by me, forced with like spirit yt now moves and torme^teth my
mind. Having said, he took aside Roderico, where he did tell unto him the whole
discourse both of his love and also of the rigor of his Lady, not without
weeping, in such abundance and with such frequent sighs and (...), as
interrupted his spech, that Roderico was constrained to keep him company, by
remembering yt obstinacy of her yt was the mistress of his heart, and thinking
yt alredie he had seen the effect of like missehap to fall upon his own head,
or nere unto yt like, or greater distress tha^ that which he saw his dear and
perfect friend to endure. Notwithstanding he assayed to remove him from that
desperate mind and opinion of continuance in yt desert. But the froward
penitent swore unto him, that so long as he lived (without place recovered in
the good graces of his Gineura, he would not return home to his house, but
rather change his being, to seek more savage abode, and less freque^ted tha^
yt was. For (said he) to what purpose shall my return serve, where continuing
mine affection, I shall feel like cruelty yt I did in time past, which will be
more painful and (...) for me to suffer than voluntary exile and banishement,
or bring me to that end wherein presently I am. Content your self, I beseech
you, and suffer me to be but one unhappy, and do not persuade me to prove a
second affliction, woorsse than the (...) (...).

Roderico hearing his reasons so lively and well applied, would not reply,
only content that he would make him promise to (...) there two months, and
in that time should attempt to (...) him self. And for (...) own part, he
swore unto him, that he would be a means to reconcile Gineura, and bring them
to talk together. Moreover, he gave him assurance by oath, that he should not
be discovered by him, nor by any in his company. Wherewith the Knight somewhat
recomforted, thanked him very affectuously. And so leuing with him a field
bed, two servants, and money for his (...), Roderico took his leave, telling
him that shortly he would visit him again, to his so great contentation, as
ever he was left and forsaken with grief and sorrow, himself making great moan
for the unseemly state, and miserable plighte of Dom Diego. And God knows
whether by the way, he (...) the (...) of pitilesse Gineura, blaspheming a
million of times the whole sex of womankind, peradventure not without just
cause. For there lies hidden (I know not what) in the breasts of women, which
at times like the wane and increase of the Moon, does change and alter a
(...) can not tell on what foot to stand to conceive the (...) of the same:
which fickle fragillitie of theirs (I dare not say mobilitie) is such, as the
subtillest (...) of them al, best skilled in Turners Art, can not (I say not
deface) so much as hide or color that natural imperfection.

Roderico arrived at his house, frequented many times the lodging of Gineura,
to epsy her fashions, and to see if any other had conquered that place, that
was so well assailed and besieged by Dom Diego. And this wise and sage knight
used the matter so well, that he fell in acquaintance with one of the
Gentlewomans pages, in whom she had so great trust, as she conceyled from him
very few of her greatest secrets, not well observing the precept of the wise
man, who counsels us not to tell the secrets of the mind to those, whose
judgment is but weak, and (...) tongue very frank of speech. The knight (...)
familiar with this page, dandled him so with fair words, as by little and
little he wrong the worms out of his nose, and understood that when Gineura
began once to take pepper in snuff, agoinst Dom Diego, she fell in love with a
Gentleman of Biskaye, very poor, but beautiful, young, and lusty, which was
the steward of the house: and the page added further, that he was not then
there, but would return within three days, as he had sent word to his
mistress, and that two other Gentlemen would accompany him to carry away
Gineura into Biskaye, for that was their last conclusion: and I hope (quod he)
that she will take me with her, because I am made privy to their whole intent.
Roderico hering the treason of this flight and departure of the unfaithful
daughter, was at the first brunt astoonned, but desirous that the page should
not mark his alteration, said unto him: In very deed mete it is, that the
Gentlewoman should make her own choice of husband, since her mother so little
cares to pronide one for her. And albeit that the Gentleman be not so rich
and noble, as her estate deserves, her affection in that behalf ought to
(...), and the honesty of his person: for the rest Gineura has (thanks be to
God) wherewith to intertaine the state of them both. These words he spoke,
far from the thought of his heart. For being by himself, thus he said: O
blessed God, how blind is that love, which is unruled, and out of order: and
what despair to recline to them, which (void of reason) (...) feed so
foolishly of vain thoughts and fond desires, that two commodities, presented
unto them, by what ill luck I know not, they forsake the best, and make
choice of the worst. Ah Gineura, the fairest Lady in all this country, and
the most unfaithful woman of our time, where be thine eyes and judgment?
whither is thy mind strayed and wandered, to acquit thy self from a great
lord, fair, rich, noble, and virtuous, to be given to one that is poor, whose
parents be unknown, his prowess obscure, and birth of no aparant reputation.
Behold, what makes me believe, that (...) (so well as Fortune) is not only
blind, but also dazeleth the syghte of them that he imbraceth and captiuateth
under his power and bondage. But I make (...) vow (false woman) that it shall
never come to pass, and that this master Biskaye shall never enjoy the
spoils which justly be due unto the trauaple and faithful service of the
valiant and virtuous (...) Dom Diego. It shall be he, or else I will dye for
it, which shall have the recompense of his troubles, and shall feel the caulme
of that tempest, which presently holds him at anchor, amydde the most
dangerous rocks that ever were.

By this means Roderico knew the way how to keep promise with his friend,
which lived in expectation of the same. The two days paste, whereof the Page
had spoken, the beloved of Gineura, sailed not to come, and with him two
Gallauntes of Biskaye, valiant Gentlemen, and well exercised in arms. That
night Roderico went to see the old wydowe Lady, the mother of the maiden,
and syndyng opportunity to speak to the Page, he said unto him: I see my
friend, accordingly as you told me, that you (...) upon departing, the
Steward of the house being now returned. I pray thee tell me, if thou have
need of me, or of any thing that I am able do for thee, assuryng thee, that
thou shalt obtain and have what so ever thou requirest. And therewithal I
have thought good to tell thee, and give thee warnyng (for thine own sake
specially) that thou keep all things close and secret, that no (...) or (...)
do follow, to blotte and deface the fame and praise of thy Mistress. And for
my self I had rather dye, than once to open my mouth, to discover the least
intent of this enterprise. But tell me, I pray thee, when do you depart? Sir
(quod the page) As my mystresse says, to morrow about ten or eleven of the
clock in the euenyng, when the Lady her mother shall be in the sound of her
first sleep. The knight hearing that, and desirous of no better time, took
his leave of the Page, and went home, where he caused to be sent for ten
or twelve Gentlemen, his neighbors and tenauntes, whom he made privy of his
secrets, and partakers of that he went about, to deliver out of captivity
and miscrie, the chiefest of all his friends. The night of those two lovers
departure, being come, Dom Roderico, which knew the way where they should
pass, be stowed him self and his company in Ambushe, in a little grove,
almost three miles off the lodgyng of this fugitive Gentlewoman: where they
had not long tarried but they heard the trampling of horse, and a certain
whispring noise of people rydyng before them. Now the night was somewhat
clear, which was the cause, that the Knight amongs the throng, knew the
Gentlewoman, besides whom rode the miserable wretch that had (...) her
away. Whom so soon as Roderico perceived, full of despite, moved with extreme
passion, welding his lance into his rest, brake in the nerest way upon the
infortunat lover, with (...) vehemency, as neither coat of maile or placard
was able to save his life, or warraunt him to keep company with that troop
which banded under loves Enseigne, was miserably slain, by the guide of a
blind, naked, and thieuish little boy. And when he saw he had done that he
came for, he said to the rest of the company: My friends, this man was
careless to make invasion upon other men's ground. These poor Biskayes
surprised upon the sudden, and seeing the ambushment to multiply, put spurs
to their horse to the best advantage they could for expedition, leaving their
(...) or gaping for breath, and gyuing a sign that he was dead. Whiles the
other were making them selves ready to run away, two of Roderico his men,
covered with skarfes, armed, and unknown, came to sease upon sorrowful
Gineura, who beholding her friend dead, began to weep and cry so straungely,
as it was marvel that her breath failed not. Ah traitorous theenes (said she)
and bloody murderers, why do ye not address your selves to execute cruelty
upon the rest, (...) you have done to death him, that is of greater value than
you all? (...) my dear friend, what crooked and grievous fortune have I, to see
thee groueling dead on the ground, and I abiding in life, to be the pray of
murderous thieves, and thou so cowardly bereued of life? Roderico with his face
covered, drew nere unto her, and said: I beseech you gentlewoman, to forget
these strange fashions of complaint, since by them ye be not able to revive the
dead, ne yet make your end of griefs. The maide^ knowing the voice of him
that had bereued her freinde, began to cry out more fiercely than before. For
which cause one of the Gentlemen a companion of Roderico, having a black
counterfeit bearde with two lunets, in manner of spectacles, very large and
great, that covered the most part of his face, approached nere the basheful
maiden, and with big voice and terrible talk, holdyng his dagger upon her
white and delicate breast, said unto her: I swear by the Almighty God, if I
hear thee speak one word more, I will sacrifice thee unto the ghost of that
varlet, for whom thou make thy moan, who deserved to end his days upon a
gallowe tree, rather than by the hands of a gentleman. Hold thy peace therefore
thou foolish girl, for greater honor and more ample benefit is meant to
thee, than thou (...) deserved. Ingratitude only has so overwhelmed thy good
nature, that thou art not able to judge who be thy friends. The Gentlewoman
fearing death, which as she thought was present, held her peace, down alongs
whose eyes a river of tears did run, and the passion of whose heart,
appeared by (...) sighs, and never ceassing sobbes, which in end so
qualified her cheer, that the exterior sadness was wholly enclosed in the
mind and thought of the afflicted Gentlewoman. Then Roderico caused the body
of the dead to be buried in a little Country chapel, not far out of their
way. Thus they travailed two days before Gineura knew any of them, that had
taken her away from her lover: even so they permitted none to speak unto her,
nor to any of her company, which was none else but a waytyng maid, and the
page that had discovered all the secrets to Dom Roderico.

A notable example surely for stolen and secret marriages, whereby the honor
of the contraded parts, is most commonly blemyshed, the commandment of God
violated, who enioyneth obedience to our parents in all rightful causes, who
(...) for any light (...), they have power to take from us the (...) which
otherwise natural law would give us, (...) ought they of duty to do,
where rebellious (...) abusing their goodness, do consume without fear of
(...) bertie, the thing which is in the hand and will (...) their fathers. In
like manner diverse indiscreet (...) foolyshe mothers are to be accused, which
suffer their daughters of tender and chyldishe age, to be (...) red of their
servants, not remembryng (...) (...) the flesh is, how prone and ready men be
to do evil, and how the seducing spirit waiting still upon us, is procliue
and prone to surprise and catch us within his snares, to the intent he may
rejoice in the ruin of souls washed and redeemed with the blood of the son of
God. This troop drawyng nere to the cave of Dom Diego, Roderico sent one of
his men to (...) him of their coming, who in the absence of his friend, (...)
and (...) with hope, shortly to see the only Lady of his heart, accompanied
with a merry (...) joyful train, so soon as he had somewhat (...) his wild
manner of life, he also by little and little (...) a good part of his lusty and
fresh color, and almost had recovered that beauty, which he had when
he first became a Citizen of those deserts. Now having understood the
message sent unto him by Roderico, God knows if with that (...) tydyngs he
felt a motion of blood, such as made all his members to leap and dance,
which rendered his mind astoonned, for the only memory of the thing, that
poysed his mind up and down, not able to stand with equal balaunce, which
rather he ought to have made rejoice than complain, being assured to see her,
of whom he demanded only grace and pardon, but for recovery thereof, he
durst not repose any certain Judgment. In the end hoystyng up his head like
one risen from a long and sonnd sleep, he said: Praise be to God, who yet
before I dye, has done me that pleasure, to suffer me to have a sight of her,
that by causing my martyrdom, continues this disordered life, which shall
procure in like sort mine utter ruin and decay: Upon the approach where of, I
shall go more joyful, charged with incomparable love, to visit the ghostes
beneath dead, in the presence of that cruel sweet, and who tormenting me with
ticklish tentation, has made me taste honey sugared with (...) gall, more
dangerouse than the suck of poison, and under the vermilion rudde of a new
sprouted rose (...) blown forth, has hidden secret thorns, the pricks
whereof has me so lively touched, as my wound can not well be cured, with any
baulme that may be thereunto applied, without enjoying of that mine own
happy missehap, or without that remedy, which almost I feel the same only
resting in death, that so long and oftenymes I have desired, as the true
remedy of my pains and grief. In the mean while Dom Roderico, which till
that time was not known unto Gineura, drew near unto her by the way as he
rode, and talked with her in this sort: I doubt not (Gentlewoman) but that
you think your self not well contented to see me in this place, in such
company, and for occasion so unseemly for my degree and state: and moreover
knowing what injury I seem to do unto you, that ever was, and am so
affectionate and friendly to yt whole stock of your race and lineage, and am not
ignorant that upon yt first bru^t you may judge my cause unjust to carry you
away from the hands of your friend, to bring you into these (...), wild, and
solitary places. But if ye considered the force of that true amity, which by
virtue shows the common bonds of hearts and minds of men, and shall measure
to what end this act is done, without to much staying (...) the light
apprehension of choler, for a beginning somewhat troublesome, I am assured then
(that if you be not wholly deprived of reason) I shall not be altogether
blamed, nor you quite of fault. And bycanse (...) draw near unto the place,
whether (by the help of God) I mean to conduct you, I beseech you to
consider, that the true servant which by all service and duty studieth to
execute the comaundementes of him that has (...) over him, does not deserve
to be beaten or driven away from the house of his master, but to be favored
and cherished, and ought to receive equal recompense for his service. I speak
not this for my self, my devotion being (...) elsewhere, and not to you,
saving for that honest affection which I ought to bear to all virtuous and
chaste persons. The (...) whereof I will not deny unto you in time and place,
where I shall use such (...) toward you, as is mete for a maiden of your age
and state. For the gretnesse of noble men and puisant, does most appear and
show forthit self, when they use mildness and gentleness unto those, to who^
by reason of their authority they might do (...) tie and malice. Now to yt end
yt I do not make you doutful long. Al yt which I have done and yet do mean to
do, is for none other purpose, but to ease the grievous pains of yt most
faithful lover that lives at this day under yt circle of the Moon. It is for
the good Knight Dom Diego, yt loves you so derely and still worshippeth your
noble fame who because he will not! show him self disobedic^t, lives miserably
among brute beasts, amid ye craggy rocks and mountains and in the deep
solitudes of comfortless dales and valleis. It is to him I say that I do
bring you, protesting unto you by oath (Gentlewoman) that yt misery wherein I
saw him, little more than. vj. wekes past, touches me so near the heart, as
if the Sacrifice of my life sufficed alone, (and without letting you to feel
this painful voyage) for the solace of his (...) I would spare it no more,
than I do mine own endeavor and honor, besides the hazarding of yt loss of
your good grace and favor. And albeit I well perceive, that I do grieve you,
by causing you to enter this painful journey, yet I beseech you that yt whole
displeasure of this (...) may be imputed unto my charge, and that it would
please you lovingly to deal with him, who for your sake uses such cruel
misdemeanor against himself. Gineura as a woman half in despair for the
death of her friend, behaved her self like a mad woman void of wit and sense,
and the simple remembrance of Dom Diego his name so astonned her, (which name
she hated far more than the pa^gs of death) that she staide a long time, her
mouth not able to shape one word to speak. In the end vanquished with
impacience, burning with choler, and trembling for sorrow, looked upon Dom
Roderico with an eye no less furious, than a Tigresse caught within the net,
and sees before her face her young Fawnes murdered, wringing her hands, and
beating her delicate breast, she used these or such like words: Ah bloody
traitor and no more Knight, is it of thee that I ought to look for so
detestable a villainy and treason? (...) dare thou be so hardy to entreat
me for an o there that have in mine own presence killed him, whose death I will
pursue upon thee, so long as I shall have life within this body? Is it to thee
false thief and murderer, that I ought to render account of that which I
meant to do? who has appointed thee to be arbitrator, or who gave thee
commission to capitulate the articles of my marriage? Is it by force then, that
thou would I should love that unfaithful Knight, for whom thou have committed
and done this act, that so long as thou live shall blot and blemish thy
renoume, and shall be so well fixed in my mind, and the wounds shall cleave so
near my heart, until at my pleasure I be revenged of this wrong? No, no, I
assure thee that any force done unto me, shall never make me otherwise disposed,
tha^ a mortal enemy both to thee which art a Thief and rauisher of an other
man's wife, and also to thy desperate friend Dom Diego, which is the cause of
this my loss: And now not satisfied with the former wrong done unto me, thou
go about to deceive me under the color of good and pure amity. But since
wicked Fortune has made me thy prisoner, do with me what thou will, and yet
before I suffer and endure that that traitor Dom Diego do enjoy my virginity,
I will offer up my life to the shadows and ghosts of my faithful friend and
husband, whom thou have so traitorously murdered. And therefore (if honestly I
may or ought entreat mine enemy,) I pray thee yt by doing thy duty, thou
suffer us in peace, and give license to me, this Page, and my two pore maidens,
to depart whether we list. God (...) (quod Roderico) that I should do a
trespass so shameful, as to deprive my dearest friend of his joy and
contentation, and by falsifiing my faith be an occasion of his death, and of
your loss, by leaving you without company, wa^dring amids this wilderness.
And he continued thus his former discourse and talk, to reclaim this cruel
Damsel to have pity upon her pore penitent, but he gained as much by his
talk, as if he had gone about to number the sands alongs the sea coasts of
the maine Ocean. Thus devising from one talk to an other, they arrived near
the Cave, which was the stately house of Dom Diego: where Gineura lighted, and
saw the pore amorous Knight, humbly falling down at her feet, all forworne,
pale, and disfigured, weeping with warm tears, he said unto her: Alas my
dear Lady, the alone and only mistress of my heart, do you not think that
my penance is long inoughe for the sin which ignorauntly I have committed,
if ever I have done any fault at all? Behold I beseech you (good Lady dear)
what joy I have conceived in your absence, what pleasures have nursed mine
hope, and what consolation has entertained my life: which truly had it not
been for the continual remembrance of your divine beauty, I had of long time
abreuiated to shorten the pains which do renew in me so many times the pangs
of death: as oftentimes I think upon the unkindness showed unto me by making
so little account of my fealty: which can, nor shall receive the same in good
part, were it so perfect as any assurance were able to make it. Gineura
swelling with sorrow, and full of feminine rage, blushing with fury, her eyes
sparckling forth her cholerike conceiptes, vouchsafed not so much as to give
him one word for answer, and because she would not look upon him, she turned
her face on the other side. The pore and afflicted lover, seeing the great
cruelty of his felonious mistress still kneeling upon his knees, redoubling
his arms, fetching his sighs with a voice, that seemed to be drawn by force
from the bottom of his heart, said unto her: Since the sincerity of (...)
faith, and my long service (...) Gineura, cannot persuade you that I have been
a most obedient, faithful, and very loyal servant toward you, as (...) any
man that has served Lady or (...), and that without your favor and grace it
is (...) possible for me any longer to live, yet I do very humbly beseech
you, for that all other comfort is denied me, if there be any ge^tlenesse and
courtesy in you, that I may receive this only grace at your hands for the last
that ever I hope to crave: which is, that you being thus grievously offended
with me, would do justice to that unfortunate man, which upon his knees does
instantly crave the same. Grant (cruel mistress) this my request, do
vengeance at your pleasure upon him, which willingly yeldeth him self to death
with the effusion of his pore innocent blood to satisfy you, and verily far
more expedient it is for him thus to die, by appeasing your will, than to rest
on live to your coffeehouse or anoyance. Alas, shall I be so unfortunate,
that both life and death should be denied me by one person of the world, whom I
hope to content and please by any sort or means what so ever resting in mine
humble obedience? Alas Gentlewoman rid me from this torment, and dispatch your
self from the grief which you have to see this unhappy Knight, who would say
and esteem himself to be happy (his life being loathsome unto you) if he may
content you, by death done by your own hands, since other favor he cannot
expect or hope for. The maiden hardened in her opinion, stood still immovable,
much like unto a rock in the midst of the sea, (...) with a tempest of
billows and fomie (...), in such wise as one word could not be procured from
her mouth. Which unlucky Dom Diego perceiving, attached with the fear of
present death, and failing his natural force fell down to the ground, and
fainting said: Ah, what a recompense do I receive for this so faithful Love?
Roderico beholding that hideous (...), whilst the others went about to (...)
Dom Diego, repaired to Gineura, and full of heaviness mingled with (...),
said unto her: By God (false (...) woman) if so be that I do change my mind,
I will make thee feel the smarte, no less than thou show thy self
dishonorable to them that do thee honor: Art thou so careless of so great
a Lord as this is, that humbles himself so low to such a strumpet as thou
art? who without regard either to his renoume, or the honor of his house, is
content to be abandoned from his noble state, to become a fugitive and
stranger? What cruelty is this for thee to misprise the greatest humility
that man can imagine? What greater amends (...) thou wish to have although the
(...) which thou presupposest had been true? Now (if thou be wise) change this
opinion, except thou would have me do into so many pieces, thy cruel
(...) and unfaithful heart, as once this poor knight did in parts the
unhappy hawk, which through thy folly did breed unto him this distress,
and to thy self the name of the most cruel and disloyal woman that ever
lived. But what greater benefit can happen unto thee, than to see this
Gentleman utterly to forget the fault, to conceive no sinister suspicion of thy
running away, craving thine acquaintance, and is contented to sacrifice him
self unto thine anger to appease and mitigate thy rage? Now to speak no more
hereof, but to proceed in that which I began to say, I offer unto thee then
both death and love, choose whether thou list. For I swear again by him
that sees and hears al things, that if thou play the fool, thou shall feel
and prove me to be the cruellest enemy that ever thou had: and such a one as
shall not fear to imbrue (...) hands with the blood of her that is the
death of the chiefest of all my friends. Gineura hearing that resolute
answer, (...) her self to be nothing afraid, nor declared any token of
fear, but rather (...) to have encouraged Roderico, in brave and mannish sort,
far diverse from the simplicity of a young and tender maide^, as a man would
say, such a one as had never felt the assault es and troubles of adverse
fortune. Wherefore frouncing her brows, and grinning her teeth with closed
(...), and (...) very bold, she made him answer: Ah thou knight, which once
gave assault to commit a villainy and treason, think thou now without
remorse of conseience to continue thy mischief? I speak it to thee villain,
which (...) shed the blood of an honester man tha^ thou art, fear not now
to make me a companion of his death. Which thing spare not hardily to (...),
to the intent that I living, may not be such a one as thou falsely iudgest me to
be: for never man hitherto (...), and never shall, that he has had the
spoil of my virginity: from the fruit whereof, like an arrant thief, thou
have deprived my loyal spouse. Now do what thou list: for I am far better
content to suffer death, be it as cruel as thou art mischeuous, and borne for
the (...) and vexation of honest maide^s: not withstanding I humbly beseech
almighty God, to give (...) so much pleasure, contentation and joy in thy
love, (...) thou have done to me, by hastening the death of my dear husband. O
God, if thou be a just God, such a one, as from whom we thy poor creatures
do believe, all (...) to proceed, thou I say, which art the rampire and refuge
of all justice, pour down thy vengeance and plague upon these pestiferous
thieues and murderers, which have prepared a worldely plague upon me thine
innocent damsel. Ah wicked Roderico, think not that death can be so fearful
unto me, but that with good heart, I am able to accept the same, trusting
verily that one day it shall be the cause of thy ruin, and overthrow of him,
for whom thou take all these pains. Dom Roderico maruellously rapte in sense,
imagined the woman to be fully bent against him, who then had puissaunce (as he
thought,) over her own heart: and thynkyng, that he saw her moved with like
rage against him, as she was against Dom Diego, stood still so perplered and
void of right mind, that he was constrained to sit down, so feeble he
felt him self for the only remembrance of her evil demeanor. And whilst this
was a doing, the handemayde of Gineura, and her Page, enforced to persuade
their mystresse to have compassion upon the knight that had suffered so much
for her sake, and that she would consent to the honest requests and good
counsel of Roderico. But she which was stubbornly bente in her foolish
persuasions, said unto them: What fools? are you so much be witched, either
with yt fained tears of this disloyal knight, which colorably thus does
torment himself, or else ar ye incha^ted with the venomous honey and tira^nical
bravery of the thief which murdered my husband and your master? Ah unhappy
caytife maiden, is it my chance to endure the (...) of such Fortune, when I
thought to live at my best case, and thus cruelly to tomble into the hands
of him, whom I hate so much as he fayneth love unto me? And morcouer my
unlucky fate is not herewith content, but redoubleth my sorrow, even by those
that be of my frayn, who ought rather to encourage me to die, than consent to
so vureasonable requests. Ah love, love, how evil be they recompensed which
faithfully do homage unto thee? and why should not I forget al (...), never
hereafter to have mind on man to prove beginning of a pleasure, which tasted
and (...) brings more displeasure than ever joy engendered (...). Alas, I
never knew what was the fruit of that which so straungely did attache me, and
thou O (...) and thieuishe Love, haste ordained a banquet (...) with such bitter
dishes, as forced I am perforce to taste of their egre sweetes: Auaunt sweet
folly, auant, I do henceforth for ever let thee (...), to embrace the death,
wherein I hope to find my greatest rest, for in thee I find naught else but
heaps of straynyng (...). Avoid from me all my myssehap, (...) from me ye
furious ghostes and (...) most unkind, whose gaudes and toys dame love has
wrought to keep occupied my loving mind, and suffer me to take end in thee,
that I may live in an other life without thee, being now charged with cup of
grief, which I shall (...) in venomous drink soaked in the soppes of (...).
Sharpen thou thy self, (O death unkind) prepare thy darte, to strike the
corpse of her, that she may void the quarrels shot against her by her
adversary. Ah pore heart strip thy self from hope, and qualify thy desires.
Cease henceforth to wish thy life, seeing and feeling the appointed fight of
love and life, combattyng within my mind, elsewhere to seek my peace in an
other world, with him to joy, which for my sake was sacrificed to the treason
of varlets hands, who for the persite (...) of his desires, naught else did
seek but to soil his (...) (...) with the purest blood of my loyal friend.
And I this abundance of tears do sheade to saciate his felonous mood, which
shall be the just shortenyng of my doleful days. When she had thus
complained, she began horribly to torment her self, and in furious guise, that
the cruellest of the company were moved with compassion, seeing her thus
strangely straught of wits: (...) they did not discontinue by duty to
solicit her to have regard to that which poor fayntyng Dom Diego did
endure. Who so sone as with fresh (...) water he was revived, (...) still the
heaviness of his Lady, and her incresed disdain and choler against him,
vanished in diverse soundings: which moved Roderico from study (...) wherein he
was to rise, whereunto yt rage of Gineura had cast him down, because forgetting
all imaginary affection of his Lady, and proposing his duty before his eyes,
which each Gentleman owes to gentle damsels and women kind, still beholding
with honorable respect the grief of the martyred wilderness Knight, sighyng
yet by reason of former thought, he said unto Gincura. Alas, is it possible,
that in the heart of so young and delicate a maiden, there may be harbored so
strange fury and unreasonable rage? O God, the effect of the cruelty
resting in this woman, paintyng it self in the imaginatiue force of my mind,
has made me fear the like missehappe to come to the cruel state of this
disauenturous gentleman: Notwithstanding (O thou cruel beast) think not that
this thy fury shall stay me from doing thee to death, to ryd thee from folly
and disdain, and this unfortunate lover from despair and trouble, verily
believing, that in time it shall be known what profit the world shall gain by
purging the same of such an infected plague as is an unkind and arrogant
heart: and it shall feel what utility ryseth by thine, overthrow. And I do
hope besides that, in time to come, men shall praise this deed of mins, who for
preserving the honor of one house, have chosen rather to do to death two
offenders, than to leave one of them alive, to obscure the glory and
brightness of the other. And therefore (said he) tourning his face to those of
his train) Cut the throat of this (...) and froward beast, and do the like to
them that be come with her, show no more favor unto them all, than that
curssed strumpet does mercy to the life of that miserable Gentleman, who dies
there for love of her.

The maiden hearing the cruel sentence of her death, cried out so loud as she
could, thinking reskue would have come, but the pore wenche was deceived: for
the desert knew none other, but those that were abiding in that troop. The
Page and the woman servant exclamed upon Roderico for mercy, but he made as
though he heard them not, and rather made sign to his men to do what he
commanded. When Gineura saw that their death was purposed in deed,
confirmed in opinion rather to die, tha^ to obey, she said unto the
executioners: My friends, I beseech you let not these innocents abide the
penance of that which they never committed. And you Dom Roderico, be (...) on
me, by whom the fault, (if a woman's faith to her husband may be termed a
fault) is done. And let these (...) depart, yt be God knows, innocent of any
crime. And thou my friend, which live amongs the shadows of faithful lovers,
if you have any feeling, as in deed thou prouest being in another world,
behold yt pureness of mine heart and sidelitie of my love: who to keep the
same inviolable, do offer my self voluntarily to the death, which this cruel
tyrant prepares for me. And you hangman the executioner of my joys, and
murderer of the immortal pleasures of my love (said she to Roderico) glut thy
gluttonous desire of blood, make drunk thy mind with murder, and (...) of thy
little triu^phe, which for all thy threats or persuasible words, thou (...) not
get from the heart of a simple maiden, ne carry away the victory for all ye
battred breach made into the ra^pare of her honor. When she had so said, a
man would have thought that the memory of death had cooled her heat, but yt
same served her as an assured solace of her pains. Dom Diego come to himself
seeing the discourse of that tragedy, being now addressed to the last (...)
and end of yt life and stage of fair and golden locked Gincura, making a
virtue of necessity, recovered a little courage to save, (if it were possible)
the life of her, that had put his own in hazard miserably to end. Having
stayed them that held the maide^, he repaired to Dom Roderico, to whom he spoke
in this wise: I see well my good Lord and great friend, that the good will you
bear me, causes you to use this honest order for my behalf, whereof I doubt if
I should live a whole hundred years, I shall not be able to satisfy the least
of the bonds wherein I am bound, the same surpassing all mine ability and
power. Yet for all that (dear friend) since you (...) the fault of this
missehap to arise of my predestinate ill luck, and that man cannot avoid
things once ordained, I beseech you do me yet this good pleasure (for all the
benefits yt ever I have received) to send back again this gentlewoman with her
train, to the place from whence you took her, with like assurau^ce and (...),
as if she were your sister. For I am pleased with your endeavor, and contented
with my misfortune, assuring you sir besides, yt the trouble which she endures,
does far more grieve my heart than al yt pain which for her sake I suffer. That
her sorrow then may decrease, and mine may renew again, yt she may line in
peace, and I in war for her cruel beauty sake, I will wait upon Clotho, the
spinner of the threden life of man until she break the twisted lace that
holds the fatal course of my doleful years. And you Gentlewoma^ live in
rest, as your pore supplia^t, wretched Dom Diego shall be citizen of these wild
places, and vaunt you (...) that you were yt best beloved maiden yt ever lived.
Marvelous truly be the forces of Love, when they discover their perfection:
for by their means things otherwise impossible be reduced to such facility,
as a man would judge that they had never been so hard to obtain, and so
painful to pursue. As appeared by this damsel, in whom the wrath of
fortune, the pinche of iealosie, the intolerable rage of her friends loss,
(...) engendered a contempt of Dom Diego, an extreme desire to be revenged on
Dom Roderico, and a (...) of longer life. And now putting of the (...) of
blind appetite, for the esclarishyng of her understanding eyes, and breaking
the Adamant rock planted in the mids of her breast, she beheld in open (...)
the steadfastness, patience and perseueration of her great friend. For that
supplication of the Knight had greater force in Gineura, than all his former
services. And full well (...) showed the same, when throwing her self upon yt
neck of the desperate Gentleman, and embracing him very lovingly she said unto
him: Ah sir, that your felicity is the beginning of my great joy of mind,
which (...) now of sweetness in the very same, in whom I imagined to be the
welspring of bitterness. The diminution of one grief is, and shall be the
increase of (...) bond, such as for ever I will call my self the most humble
slave of your worship, lowly beseeching you nevertheless to pardon my follies,
wherewith full fondely I have abused your patience. Consider a while sir, I
beseech you, the nature and secrecy of love. For those that be blinded in that
passion, think them selves to be perfect seers, and yet be the first that
commit most (...) faults. I do not deny any committed wrong and trespass,
and do not refuse therefore the honest and gentle correction that you shall
appointe me, for expiation of mine offense. Ah my noble Lady (answered ye
knight) all rapt with pleasure, and half way out of his wits for joy, I humbly
beseech you inflicte upon my pore wretched body no further pangs of death by
remembering the glory of my thought since the recital brings with it a taste of
the trauails which you have suffered for my joy and contentation. It is therefore
(quod she) that I think my self happy: for by that means I have known the
perfect qualities that be in you, and have proved two extremities of virtue.
One consists in your constancy and loyalty whereby you may vaunt your self
above him yt sacrificed his life upon the bloody body of his Lady, who for
dying so, finished his trauails. Where you have chosen a life worse than death,
no less painful a hundred times a day, than very death it self. The other
consists in the clemency wherewith you calm and appease the rage of your
greatest adversaries. As my self which before hated you to death, vanquished by
your courtesy do confess that I am double bound unto you, both for my life and
honor: and hearty thanks do I render to the Lord Roderico for yt violence he
did unto me, by which means I was induced to acknowledge my wrong, and the
right which you had to complain of my folish resistance. All is well, said
Roderico, since without peril of honor we may return home to our houses: I
intend therefore (said he) to send word before to my Ladies your mothers of
your return, for I know how so well to cover and excuse this our enterprise and
secret iorneis, as by Gods assistance no blame or displeasure shall ensue
thereof. And like as (said he smiling) I have builded the fortress which shot
into your camp, and made you fly, even so I hope (Gentlewoman) that I shall
be the occasion of your victory, when you combat in close ca^pe, with your
sweet cruel enemy. Thus they passed the journey in pleasant talk, recompe^sing
the. (...). lovers with all honest and virtuous intertainme^t for their (...)
and troubles past. In the mean while they sent one (...) their servants to the
two widow ladies, which were (...) great care for their children, to advertise
them yt Gineura was gone to visit Dom Diego, then being in one of the castles
of Roderico, where they were determined if it were their good pleasure, to
consu^mate their marriage, having given faith and affiance one to the other. The
mother of Gineura, could not here tell of more pleasant news: for she had
understood of the folish flight and escape of her daughter, with yt steward
of her house, whereof she was very sorrowful, and for grief was like to die, but
assured and reco^forted with those news, she (...) not to mete the mother of
Dom Diego, at ye appointed place whither the y. lovers were arrived two days
before. There the marriage of that fair couple (so long desired) was (...) with
such magnificence as was requisite for the state of those two noble houses.
Thus the torment (...), made the joy to savor of some other taste than they do
feel, which without pain in yt exercise of loves pursuit, attain the top of
their desires: And truly their pleasure was altogether like to him that
nourished in superfluous delicacie of meats can not aptely so well judge of
pleasure, as he which sometimes lacks that abundance. And verily Love without
bitterness, is almost a cause without effects: for he that shall take away
griefs and troubled fancies from lovers, depriueth them of the praise of their
steadfastness, and makes baine the glory of their perseverance: for he is
unworthy to bear away the price and garlande of triumph in the conflict, that
behaueth himself like a coward, and does not observe the laws of arms and
manlike duties in the combat. This history then is a mirror for loyal
lovers, and chaste suitors, and makes them detest the unshamefastness of
those, which upon the first view do follow with might and maine, the
Gentlewoman or Lady that gives them good face or countenance whereof any
gentle heart or mind, noursed in the scholehouse of virtuous education, will
not be squeymish to those that shall by chaste salutation or other incountrie,
do their courteous reverence. This history also yeldeth contempt of them,
which in their affection forget them selves, abasting the generositie of their
courages, to be reputed of fools, the true champions of Love, whose like they
be that desire such regard. For the perfection of true Love consists not in
passions, in sorrows, griefs, martirdomes, or cares, and much less arriueth
he to his desire, by sighs, exclamations, wepings, and childish playnts: for
so much as virtue ought to be the band of that indissoluble amity, which
makes the union of the two severed bodies of that woman man, which Plato
describes, and causes man to travel for his whole accomplishment in yt true
pursuit of chaste loueIn which labor truly fondly walked Dom Diego, thinkyng to
find the same by his despair amidde the sharp solitary deserts of those
Pyrene mountains. And truly the duty of his perfect friend, did more lively
disclose the same (what fault so ever he did) than all his countenances,
eloquent letters or amorous messages. In like manner a man does not know what a
treasure a true friend is, until he has proved his excellency, specially
where necessity makes him to taste ye swetnesse of such delicate meat. For a
friend being a second himself, agrees by a certain natural (...) and
atonement to the affections of him who^ he loves, both to participate his
joys and pleasures, and to sorrow his adversity, where Fortune shall use by
some misaduentures, to show her accustomed moblitie.

Salimbene and Angelica
A Gentleman of SISNA, called ANSELMO SALIMBENE, courteously and gently
delivers his (...) from death. The condemned party seeing the kind part of
SALIMBENE, renders into his hands his sister ANGELICA, with whom he was in
love, which gratitude and courtesy, SALIMBENE well marking, moved in
conscience, would not abuse her, but for recompense took her to his wife.

The. xxx. Nouel.
WE do not mean here to discover the sumptuositie and magnificence of Palaces,
stately and won derfull to the view of me^, ne yet to reduce to memory yt
marvelous effects of ma^s industry to build and lay foudations in the deepest
chanel of the maine sea, ne to describe their ingenious industry, in breking
the craggy mountains, and hardest rocks, to ease the crooked passages of
weary ways, for armies to march through inaccessible places. Only now do we
pretend to show the effects of love, which surmount all opinion of common
things, and appear so miraculous as the founding and erecting of the Collisaei,
Colossaei, Theaters, Amphitheatres, Pyramides, and other works wonderful to
the world, for that the hard endured path of hatred and displeasure long time
begoon, and obstinately pursued with strange cruelty, was converted into
love, by theffect of love and concord, such as I know none, but is so much
astoonned, as he may have good cause to wonder, considering the stately
foundations, upon which kings and great monarchs have employed the chiefest
revenues of their provinces. Now like as Ingratitude is a vice of greatest
blame and disco^mendation amongs men, even so gentleness and kindness ought
to bear yt title of a most co^me^dable virtue. And as ye Thebans were accused
of that crime, for their great captains Epaminondas and Pelopidas. The
Plateens (contrariwise) were praised for their solemn observation of the Greeks
benefits, which delivered them out of the Persians bondage. And the Sicyonians
bear away the price of eternal praise, for acknowledging the good turns
received of Aratus, that delivered them fra^ the cruelty of the tyrants. And
if Philippo Maria, duke of Milan, deserved eternal reproach for his ingratitude
to his wife Beatrix, for the secret killing of her, he being enriched with her
goods and treasures: a barbarous turk borne in Arabia, shall carry the praise
from him, who being vanquished in Arabia by Baldouine, king of Jerusalem, and
he and his wife taken prisoners, and his treasures fallen into the hands of
that good king, issued of the Loraine blood. Nevertheless seeing that the
Christian had delivered him, and restored again his wife, would not be
vanquished in magnificence and (...), and much less bear the name of an
unkind prince, but rather when Baldouine was overcome of yt infidels, and
being retired within a certain city, that Admiral of Arabie, came to him in
the night, and telling him the devise of his companions, conveyed him out of
the (...), and was his guide until he saw him free peril. I (...) alleged yt
premises, because ye history which I purpose to recite, aduoucheth two
examples not vulgar or common, the one of very great love, and the other of
such (...) ceptacio^ and knowledging thereof, as I thought it pity the same
should lurk from the acquaintance of (...) English men. And that they alone
should have the (...) thereof which understand the Italian tongue, supposing
that it shall bring some fruit and commodity to this our English soil, that
each wight may frame their life on those which in strange Countries far from
us, have lived virtuously without reproach that might soil or spot their name.

In Siena then (an ancient and very noble City of Toscane, which no long time
past was governed by her Magistrates, and lived in her own laws and liberties,
as the Lucquois, Pisans, and Florentines do) were two families very rich,
noble, and the chief of the City called the Salimbenes and Montanines, of the
race and stock whereof, excellent men in their common wealth have descended,
very good and expert soldiers for (...) of armies. Those two houses in the
beginning were so great friends, and frequented such love and (...), as it
seemed they had been but one house and (...), daily using each others company,
and banketting one another. But Italy in all times being as it were a store
house of troubles and a very mart of sedition, bands and parcialities,
specially of civil wars in every City, it could not be that Siena should
alone enjoy her liberty in peace, and accord of Citizens, and vaunt her self
to be free from knowledge of particular debate. For of wars she had good
experience against ye Florentines, who by long remembrance have done what they
could to make her subject unto them. Now the cause of that discord rose even
by them which kept the Citizens in unity and concord and was occasioned by
those. y. houses the noblest and most puissant of their common wealth. It is
not unknown to any man, that antiquity ordained it to be peculiar for
nobility, to train up the children of noble houses in hunting, as well to
bolden and nosel them in dangers, as to make them strong and accustomed in
trauail, and to force them shun the delicate life and great idleness which
accompany honorable houses, and those of gentle blood, for so much as by the
pursuit of beasts, sleights of war be observed: the hounds be the square
battle, the greihoundes be the flanquarts and wings to follow the enemy, the
horsman serves to give the chase when the game speedeth to covert, the horns
be the trumpets to sound the chase and retire, and for encouragement of the
dogs that run. To be short, it seems a very camp in battle, ordained for
the pleasure and passetyme of noble youth. Nevertheless, by huntyng diverse
missefortunes do arise, and sundry dangers have happened by the same.
Meleager lost his life for the (...) of the wild bore of Callydonia. Cephalus
lost his life for killyng his dear beloved Procris, and Acastus was accursed
for murderyng the Kings son of whom he was the Tutour. William Rufus, one
of our English Kings, the son of the Conqueroure, was slain with an arrowe
in the New forest by a French gentleman called Walter Tyrel, as he was
pursuing the heart. Other histories report diverse perils chanced in hunting,
but yet the same worthy to be cherished, frequented and used by good advise
and moderate passetyme. So the hunting of the wild Bore defiled the City of
Siena, with the blood of her own Citizens, when the Salimbenes and Montanines
upon a day in an assembled company, incountring upon a great and fierce
bore, took him by force of men and beasts, When they had done, as they were
banketting and (...) of the nimblenesse of their dogs, each man praising his
own, as having done best, there rose great (...) amongs them upon that matter,
and proceeded so far, as foudly they began to revile one another with words,
and from taunting terms to earnest blows, wherewith diverse in that skirmish
were hurt on both sides. In the end the Salimbenes had the worsse, and one of
the principal (...) in the place, which appalled the rest, not that they were
discoraged, but attending time and season of revenge. This hatred so strangly
kindled between both parts, that by little and little, after many combats and
