overthrows of either side, the loss lighted upon the Montanines, who with
their wealth and richesse were almost brought to nothing, and thereby the rigor
and choler of the Salimbenes appeased, none being able to resist them, and in
space of time forgot al injuries. The Montanines also that remained at Siena,
lived in quiet, without challenge or quarrel of their (...) uersaries, howbeit
(...) talk and haunt of others company utterly surceased. And to say the
truth, there were almost none to quarrel withal, for the whole blood and name
of the Montanines rested in one alone, called Charles the son of Thomas
Montanine, a young ina^ so honest and wet brought up, as any then in Siena, who
had a sister, that for beauty, grace, curtesy and honesty, was comparable
with the best in all Thoscame. This pore young Gentleman had no great revenue,
for that the patrimony of his predecessors was wasted in charges for
entertainment of soldiers in the time of the hurly burly and debates
aforesaid. A good part also was confiseate to the chamber of Siena for
trespasses and forfaitures committed: with the remain he sustained his
family, and indisserently maintained his port soberly within his own house,
keeping his sister in vecent and moderate order. The maiden was called
Ange^lica, a name of troth, without offense to other, due to her. For in very
deed in her were harbored the virtue of curtesy and gentleness, and was so
well instructed and nobly brought up, as they which loved not the name or race
of her, could not forbear to commend her, and wish that their daughter were
her like. In such wise as one of her chiefest foes was so sharply beset with
her virtue and beauty, as he lost his quiet sleep, and lust to eat and
drink. His name was Anselmo Salimbene, who would willingly have made suit to
marry her, but the discord past, quite mortified his desire, so sone as he had
devised the plot within his brain and fancy. Notwithstanding it was
impossible that the love so lively graven and (...) in his mind, could easily
be defaced. For if once in a day he had not seen her, his heart did feel the
torments of tosting flames, and wished that the Hunting of the Bore, had never
decayed a family so excellent, to the intent he might have matched himself
with her, whom none other could displace out of his remembrance, which was
one of the richest Gentlemen, and of greatest power in Siena. Now for that he
ourst not discover his amorous grief to any person, was the chiefest cause that
martired most his heart, and for the ancient festred malice of those two
families, he despaired for ever, to gather either flower or fruit of that
affection, presupposing that Angelica would never fire her love on him, for
that his Parents were the cause of the defaite and overthrow of the Montanine
house. But what? There is nothing durable under the heavens. Both good and
evil (...) their revolution in the government of humane affairs. The amities
and hatreds of Kings and Princes, be they so hardened, as commonly in a moment
he is not (...) to be a hearty friend, that lately was a (...) foe, and spired
naught else but the ruin of his aduer farie? We see the variety of humane
chances, and then (...) judge at eye what great simplicity it is to stay and
settle certain and infallible iudgemit upon (...) unstayed doings. He that erst
governed a king, and made all things to tremble at his word, is suddenly
thrown down, and dies a shameful death. In like sort, another which looks
for his own undoing, sees himself advanced to his estate again, and
vengeance taken of his enemies. Calir Bassa governed whilom yt great Mahomet,
that wan the Empire of Constantinople, who attempted nothing without the advice
of that Bassa. But upon the sudden he saw himself rejected, and the next day
strangled by commandment of him, which so greatly honored him, and without
just cause did him to a death so cruel. Contrariwise Argon the T artarian,
entering arms against his uncle Tangodor Caui, when he was upon the point to
lose his life for his rebellion, and was conveyed into. Armenia to be executed
there, was rescued by certain T artarians the household servants of his dead
uncle, and afterward proclaimed king of T artarie about the year. 1285. The
example of the Empress Adaleda is of no less credit than the former, who
being fallen into the hands of Beranger the usurper of yt Empire, escaped his
fury and cruelty by flight, and in the end married to Otho the first, saw her
wrong revenged upon Beranger and al his race by her son Otho the second. I
aduouch these histories to prove ye mobility of fortune, and the change of
worldly chances, to the end you may see that the very same misery which
followed Charles Montanine, hoisted him aloft again, and when he looked for
least succor, he saw deliverance at hand. Now to prosecute our history, know
ye yt while Salimbenc by little and little pined for love of Angelica, whereof
she was ignorant and careless, and albeit she courteously rendered health to
him, when sometime in his amorous fit he beheld her at a window, yet for all yt
she never gessed the thoughts of her loving enemy. During these haps it
chanced yt a rich citizen of Siena, having a ferme adjoining to the lands of
Montanine, desirous to increase his patrimony, and annere the same unto his
own, and knowing yt the young gentleman wanted many things, moved him to sell
his inheritance, offering him for it in ready money, a M. Ducates, Charles which
of all the wealth and substance left him by his auncester, had no more
remaining but that country ferme, and a Palace in the City (so ye rich
Italians of each city, term their houses,) and with yt little lived honestly,
and maintained his sister so well as he could, refused flatly to dispossess
himself of yt portion, which renewed unto him yt happy memory of those yt had been the chief of all the common wealth. The covetous wretch seeing himself
frustrate of his pray, conceived such rancor against Montanine, as he purposed
by right or wrong to make him not only to for fait ye same, but also to lose
his life, following ye wicked desire of tirannous Iesabel, that made Naboth to
be stoned to death, to extorte and wrongfully get his vineyarde. About that
time for the quarrels and common discordes reigning throughout Italy, yt
nobility were not assured of safety in their countries, but rather the common
sort, and rascal number, were yt chief rulers and gouerners of the common
wealth, whereby ye greatest part of the nobility or those of best authority
being banished, the villainous band, and grosest kind of common people made a
law (like to the Athenians in ye time of Solon) that all persons of what degree
and co^ditio^ so ever they were, which practiced by himself or other means
the restablishing or reuocation of such as were banished out of their City,
should lose and forfaite the sum of M. Florens, and having not wherewith to pay
the condempnation, their head should remain for gage. A law no dout very just
and righteous, scenting rather of the barbarous cruelty of the Goths and
(...), tha^ of true christians, stopping the retire of innocents exiled for
particular quarrels of Citizens incited one against another, and rigorously
rewarding mercy and courtesy, with execution of cruelty incomparable.

This citizen then purposed to accuse Montanine for offending against the law,
because otherwise he could not purchase his intent, and the same was easy
enough for him to compass, by reason of his authority and estimation in the
City: for the enditement and plea was no sooner red and given, but a number of
post knights appeared to depose against ye pore gentleman, to bear witness
that he had trespassed the laws of the Country, and had sought means to
introduce the banished, with intent to kill the gouerners, and to place in
state those (...), that were the cause of the Italian troubles. The miserable
gentleman knew not what to do, ne how to defend himself. There were against him
the Moon and the. vy. stars, the state of the City the Proctor and Judge of
the court, the witnesses that gave evidence, and the law which condemned him.
He was sent to prison, sentence was pronounced against him with such
expedition, as he had no leisure to consider his affairs. There was no man,
for fear to incur the displeasures of the Magistrates, that durst open his
mouth to speak or make suit for his deliverance. Like as yt most part of
friends in these days resembling yt crow, that flies not but after carrion to
gorge his ravenous (...), and such friends do visit the house of the friend
but for profit, reuerencing him so long as he is in prosperity, according to
the Poets complaint.

Like as the purest gold in fiery flame is tried,
Even so is faith of friends in hard estate descried
If hard mischap does thee affray,
Each of thy friends do flee away,
And he which erst full friendly semde to thee,
A friend no more to thy pore state is he.
And simple wights ought not to be afraid, and think amiss if friends do flee
away, since Princes and great Lords incur such hap and fortune. The great
leader of the Roman armies, Pompeius, the honor of the people and senate of
Rome, what companion had he to flee with him? Which of his ancient friends
took pain to rescue and deliver him from his enemies hands which did pursue
him? A king of Egypt which had known and found this good Roman Prince a kind
and gentle friend, was he that killed him, and sent his head to his (...) and
insatiable gredie gutte Julius Caesar, falsifying his promised faith, and
forgetting his received pleasures. Amongs all the comfortes which this pore
Siena Gentleman found, although but a curssed traitor, was this unfaithful and
pestiferous Camaeleon, who came and offered him all the pleasure and kindness
he was able to do. But ye varlet attended convenient time to make him taste his
poison, and to let him see by (...), how dangerous a thing it is to be ill
neighbored, hoping after the condempnation of Montanine, he should at pleasure
purchase the Lordship, after which with so open mouth he gaped. Over whom he
had his will: for two or (...) days after the recital of the enditement, and
giving of the evidence, Charles was condemned, and his fine sessed at M.
Florins to be paid within. xv. days, until which (...) to remain in prison.
And for default of such payment to lose his head, because he had infringed the
laws, and broken the statutes of the Senate. This sentence was very difficult
for pore Montanine to digest, who saw all his goods like to be despoiled and
confiscate, co^plaining specially the fortune of fair Angelica his sister,
which all the time of the imprisonment of her dear brother, never went out of
ye house, ne ceased to weep and lament the hard fortune wherinto their family
was like to fall by yt new mischau^ce: Alas (said yt fair courteous damsel) will
ye heavens never be appeased but continually exte^d their wrath upon yt
deplored family, and shall our missehaps never cease? Had it not been more
tolerable for our consumed blood, yt the dissentio^s past, had been tried by
dent of sword, than to see yt present innocence of ye young gentleman my brother
in danger to be guiltlesly accused and put to death, through yt injustice of
those, which bear mortal malice to noble blood, and glory in deprivation of the
whole remembrance of the same? O dampnable state yt must hale the guiltless
to the gibet and irreuocable judgment of those judges remaining in a city,
which men call free, albeit a co^sused multitude has ye upper hand, and may so
be, yt nature has produced them to tread under foot noble wights for their
offenses. Ah dear brother, I see well what is ye cause, if thou had not that
little Lordship in the Country, and stately house in the city, no man would
have envied thine estate, or could have charged thee with any crime, which I would
to God, thou had not only enterprised, but also brought to pass, to the
intent thou might have been revenged of ye wrong, which these cankred carles
ordinarily do unto thy Noble blood. But what reason is it that merchants and
artificers, or the sons of villains should rule a common wealth? O happy
Countries where kings give laws, and Princes see by proved sight, those
persons which resemble them, and in their places bear ye sway. And O unhappy
we, yt be ye slaves of a waiwarde state, perverted by corruption. Why did our
predecessors mind to stablish any liberty at al, to thrust ye same into the
confused government of the commons of our country? We have still the Frenchmen
at our tail, or yt people of our highest bishop, or else those crafty
Florentines, we be the common pray of al those yt list to follow the haunt, and
that which is our extremest misery, we make our selves ye very (...) of them,
yt of right ought to be reputed yt (...) amongs us all. Ah dear brother, yt thy
wretched time is come, the only hope of our decayed family. Thou had never
been committed to ward, had not thy false assured foes been sure of witness
to condemn thee. Ah yt my life might ransom thine, and redeem again thine
estate and succor, thou should be sure yt forthwith Angelica would prepare
hirself to be ye pray of those hungry ravening wolves, which bleat and bellow
after thy lands and life. While this fair damsel of Siena in this sort did
torment her self, pore Montanine seeing yt he was brought to the last
extremity of his desired hope, as each man naturally does seek means to
prolong his life, knowing yt all other help failed for his deliverance, except
he sold his land, as well to satisfy ye fine, as to prevail in the rest of his
affairs, sent one of the gailers to yt worshipful usurer the cause of his
calamity, to offer him his land for yt price and sum of a M. Ducates. The
pernicious and (...) villain seeing yt Montanine was at his mercy, and stood in
the water up to the very throat, and knew no more what to do, as if already he
had triumphed of his life and land so greatly coueted, answered him in this
manner: My friend, thou shall say to Charles Montanine, that not long ago I
would willingly have given him a good sum of money for his ferme, but since
that time I have employed my money to some better profit: and albeit I was in
mind to buy it, I would be loath to give above. (...). (...). Florins, being
assured yt it can not be (...) (...), as my money is able to bring yearly gain
into my (...).

See how Avarice is the pickpurse of secret and (...) gain, and the very
whirlepoole of honesty and (...), coveting naught else but by unrighteous pray
(...) other men's goods, to accumulate and heap together. The abundance
whereof brings no greater good (...) unto the gluttonous owner, but rather the
mind (...) such is more miserable, and carries there withal more decrease of
quiet, than increase of filthy muck. The covetous man bears no love but to
his treasure, nor exercises charity but upon his coafers, who tha^ he would be
dispossessed thereof, had rather sell the life of his natural father. This
detestable villain having sometimes offered M. Ducates to Charles for his
enheritaunce, will now do so no more, aspiring the total ruin of ye Montanine
family. Charles advertised of his mind, and amazed for the Counsels decree,
well saw that all things contraried his hope and expectation, and that he must
needs die to satisfy the excessive and covetous lust of that Cormerant, whose
malice he knew to be so vehement, as none durst offer him money, by reason of
the unhappy desire of this never contented varlet: for which consideration
thoroughly resolved to die, rather than to leave his pore sister helpless, and
without relief, and rather than he would agree to the bargain tending to his
so great loss and disaduauntage, and to the tirannous dealing of the wicked
tormentor of his life, seeing also that all means to purge and auerre his
innocence, was taken from him, the (...) decree of the judges being alre ady
passed, he began to dispose himself to repentance and salvation of his soul,
making complaint of his missehapsin this manner.

TO what has not the heavens hateful bin,
Since for the ease of man they weaue such woe?
By diverse toiles they lap our corsses in
With cares and griefs, whereon our mischiefs groe:
The bloody hands and sword of mortal foe,
Do search mine evil, and would destroy me quite,
Through heinous hate, and hateful heaped spite.
Wherefore come not the fatal sisters three,
That draw the line of life and death by right?
Come (...) all, and make an end of me,
For from the world, my sprite would take his flight.
Why comes not now foul Gorgon full in sight,
And Typhons head, that deep in hell remains?
For to torment the silly souls in pains?
It better were for me to feel your force,
Than this missehap of murdring enuies rage,
By curssed means and fall upon my corse,
And work my (...) amid my flouring age:
For if I were dispatchde in this desire,
The fear were gone, of black infernal fire.
O Gods of seas, and cause of blustering wind,
Thou Aeolus and Neptune to I say,
Why did you let my Bark such fortune find
That safe to shore I came by any way?
Why brake ye not, against some rock or bay,
The kele, the stern, or else blew down the mast,
By whose large sails, through surging seas I past?
Had those things hapt, I had not seen this hour,
The house of dole, where woeful sprites complain,
Nor vserers on me had used such power,
Nor I had seen depainted in disdain,
The God of care, with whom dead Ghosts remain,
Who howles and skrekes in holow trees and holes,
Where Charon reigns, among condemned souls.
Ah, ah, since hap will work my wretched end,
And that my ruin by judgment is decreed:
Why does not hap such happy fortune send,
That I may lead with me the man in deed,
That staind his faith, and faild me at my need,
For gain of gold, as usurers do God knows,
Who cannot spare the dropping of their nose?
I should have slain the slave that served me so,
Oh God forbid, my hands were brued in blood.
Should I desire the harm of friend or foe?
Nay better were to wish mine en'my good:
For if my death I thoroughly understood,
I should make short the course I have to run,
Since rest is got, when worldly toil is done.
Alas, alas, my chiefest way is this,
Aguiltlesse death to susfer as I can,
So shall my soul be sure of heavens bliss,
And good renoume shall rest behind me than,
And body shall take end where it began,
And fame shall fly before me, ere I flit
Unto the Gods, where Jove in throne does sit.
O God convert, from vice to virtue now,
The heart of him that falseth faith with me,
And change his mind, and mend his manners throw,
That he his fault and foul offense may see,
For death shall make my fame immortal be:
And whiles the Sun which in the heavens does shine,
The shame is his, and honor shall be mine.
Alas I mourn not for my self alone,
Nor for the same of my forefuthers old,
Tys Angelike, that carseth me to moan,
Tys she that filles my breast with sansies cold,
Tys she more worth, than was the slice of gold,
That moves my mind, and bredes such passions strange,
As in my self I feel a wondrous chaknge.
Have pity Lord of her and me this day,
Since destny thus has sundred us in (...),
O suffer not (...) virtues to decay,
But let her take in friendship such delight,
That from her breast all vice be banished quite.
And let her like, as did her noble race
When I poor man (...) dead, and out of place.
Alas my hand would write these woeful lines,
That feeble sprite denies for want of might,
Wherefore my heart in breast consumes and pines,
With deep desires, that far is from man's sight,
But God he sees mine innocence and right,
And knows the cause of mine accuser still,
Who sekes my blood to have on me his will.
When Charles thus complained himself, and thoroughly was determined to die,
great pity it was to see how fair Angelica did rent her face, and tear her
golden locks, when she saw how impossible it was to save her obstinate brother
from the cruel sentence pronounced upon him, for whom she had employed all her
wits and fair speech, to persuade the nearest of her kin to make suit. Thus
rested she alone full of such heaviness and veration as they ca^ think which
see themselves deprived of things yt they esteem most dear. But of one thing I
ca^ well assure you, yt if ill fortune had permitted yt Charles should have been
put to death, the gentle damsel also had breathed forth the final gasp of
her sorrowful life, yelding therwithal the last end of the Montanine race and
family. What booteth it to hold process of long discourse? Behold the last
day is come deferred by the judges, whereupon he must either satisfy the fine,
or die the next day after like a rebel and traitor against the state, without
any of his kin making suit or mean for his deliverance: albeit they visited the
fair maiden, and comforted her in that her wretched state, instructing her
how she should govern her self patiently to suffer things remediless.
Angelica accompanied with her kin, and the maidens dwelling by that were her
companio^s, made the air to sound with outcries and waime^tings, and she her
self exclamed like a woman destraught of wits, whose plaints ye multitude
assisted with like eiulations and outcries, wailing the fortune of the young
gentleman, and sorrowful to see ye maiden in danger to fall into some
missehap. As these things were thus bewailed, it chanced about. ix. of the
clock at night, that Anselmo Salimbene, he whom we have said to be surprised
with the love of Angelica, returning out of the Country, where he had remained
for a certain time, and passing before the house of his Lady, according to
his custom, heard the voice of women and maidens which mourned for Montanine,
and therwithal stayed: the chiefest cause of his stay was, for that he saw go
forth out of the palace of his Angelica, diverse women making moan and
lamentation: wherefore he demanded of yt neighbors what noise that was, and
whether any in those quarters were dead or no. To whom they declared at length,
all that which ye have heard before. Salimbene hearing this story, went home to
his house, and being secretly entered into his chamber, began to discourse with
himself upon that accident, and (...) a thousand things in his head, in the
end thought that Charles should not so be cast away, were he justly or
innocently condemned, and for the only respect of his sister, that she might
not be left destitute of all the goods and inheritance. Thus discoursing
diverse things, at length he said: I were a very simple person now to rest in
dout, since Fortune is more curious of my felicity than I could wish, and
seeks the effect of my desires, when lest of all I thought upon them. For
behold, Montanine alone is left of al ye mortal enemies of our house, which to
morrow openly shall lose his head like a rebel and seditious person, upon whose
auncesters in him shall I be revenged, and the quarrel between our two
families, shall take end, having no more cause to fear renewing of discord,
by any that can descend from him. And who shall let me then from inioying her,
whom I do love, her (...) being dead, and his goods confiscate to the
segniorie and she without all maintenance and relief, except the aid of her
only beauty and courtesy? What maintenance shall she have, if not by the love
of some honest Gentleman, that for his pleasure may support her, and have pity
upon the loss of so excellent beauty? Ah Salimbene, what have thou said? Have
thou already forgotten that a Gentleman for that only cause is esteemed above
all other, whose glorious factes ought to shine before the brightness of
those that force themselves to follow virtue? Art not thou a Gentleman borne and
bredde in noble house, ssued from the loins of gentle and noble parents? Is it
ignorant unto thee, that it pertains unto a noble and gentle heart, to
revenge received injuries himself, without seeking aid of other, or else to
pardon them by using clemency and princely courtesy, burying all desire of
vengeance under the tomb of eternal oblivion? And what greater glory can
man acquire, than by vanquishing himself, and chastising his affections and
rage, to bind him which never thought to receive pleasure or benefit at his
hand? It is a thing which excedeth the common order of nature, and so it is
mete and requisite, that the most excellent do make the effects of their
excellency appear, and seek means for the immortality of their remembrance.
The great Dictator Caesar was more praised for pardoning his (...), and for
showing him self courteous and easy to be spoken to, than for subduing the
brave and valiant Galls and Britons, or vanquishing the mighty Pompee. Dom
Roderico Viuario, the Spaniard, although he might have been revenged upon Dom
Pietro, king of Aragon, for his infidelity, because he went about to hinder
his voyange against the Saracens at Grenado, yet would not punish or raunsom
him, but taking him prisoner in the wars, suffered him to go without any
tribute, or any exaction of him and his (...). The more I follow the example of
mighty personages in things that be good, the more notorious and wonderful
shall I make my self in their rare and noble deeds. And not willing to forget a
wrong done unto me, whereof may I co^plain of Montanine? what thing has he
ever done against me or mine? And albeit his predecessors were enemies to our
family, they have therefore borne the penance, more hard than the sin deserved.
And truly I should be afraid, that God would suffer me to (...) into some mishap,
if seeing one afflicted, I should rejoice in his affliction, and take by his
decay an argument of joy and pleasure. No no, Salimbene is not of mind, that
such fond imagination should bereue good will to make himself a friend, and to
gain by liberality and courtesy her, which for her only virtue deserves a
greater lord than I. Being asiured, that there is no man (except he were (...)
of al good nature and humanity) specially bering the love to Angelica, that I
do, but he would be sorry to see her in such heaviness and despair, and would
attempt to deliver her from such dolorous grief. For if I love her as I do in
deed, must not I likewise love all that which she earnest ly loves, as him that
is now in danger of death for a simple fine of a thousand Florens. That my
heart do make appear what the love is, which makes me tributarie and subject
to fair Angelica, and that each man may know, that furious love has vanquished
kings and great monarchs, it behooves not me to be abashed, if I which am a
man and subject tapassio^s, so well as other, do submit my self to the service
of her, who I am assured is so virtuous as eue^ very necessity cannot force
her to forget ye house, whereof she took her original. Uaunt thy self then (...)
Angclica to have forced a heart of it self impregnable, and given him a wound
which the stoutest lads, might sooner have deprived of life, than put him out
of ye way of his gentle kind: And (...) Montanine, think, that if thou will
thy self, thou wynnest to day so hearty a friend, as only death shall
separate the union of us twain, and of all our posterity. It is I, nay it is
I my self, that shall excel thee in duty, poynting the way for the wysest,
to get honor, and violently compel the moved minds of those that be our
adversaries, desiring rather vainly to forgo mine own life, than to give over
the virtuous conceits, which be already grifted in my mind. After this long
discourse seeing that the time required diligence, he took a thousand
Ducates, and went to the Treasurer of the fines, deputed by the state, whom he
fonnd in his office, and said unto him: I have brought you sir, the Thousand
Ducates, which Charles Montanine is bound to pay for his deliverance. Tell
them, and give him an acquittance that presently he may come forth. The
Treasorer would have given him the rest, that exceeded the sum of a Thousand
Florens: but Salimbene refused the same, and receiving a letter for his
discharge, he sent one of his servants therwithall to the chief Gailer, who
seeing that the sum of his condemnation was paid, immediately delivered
Montanine out of the prison where he was fast shut, and fettred with great
and weighty gives. Charles thinkyng that some Friar had been come to confess
him, and that they had showed him (...) mercy to do him to death in prison,
that abroad in open shame of the world he might not deface the noble house
whereof he came, was at the first sight astoonned, but having prepared himself
to die, praised God, and besought him to vouchsafe not to forget him in yt
sorrowful passage, wherein the stoutest and coragious many times be faint and
inconstant. He reco^mended his soul, he prayed forgiveness of his sins: and
above all, he humbly besought the goodness of God, that it would please him
to have pity upon his sister, and to deliver her from all infamy and
dishonor. When he was carried out of the Gayle, and brought before the chief
Gailer, suddenly his gives were discharged from his legs, and every of the
standers by looked merrily upon him, without speaking any word that might
asfray him. That Courtesy (...) for, made him attend some better thing, and
(...) him of that which before by any means he durst not think. And his
expectation was not deceived. For the Gailer said unto him: Be of good cheer
sir, for behold the letters of your discharge, wherefore you may go at liberty
whether you list. In saying so, he opened the pri son, and licensed Montanine
to depart, praying him not to take in ill part his entreaty and hard
imprisonment, for that he durst do none other, the State of the City having
so enjoined him. May not each wight now behold how that the events of love be
diverse from other passions of mind? How could Salimbene have so charitably
delivered Montanine, the hatred being so long time rooted between the two
houses, if some great occasion which has no name in Love, had not altered his
nature, and extinguished his affection? It is meritorious to succor them whom
we never saw before, since nature moves us to do well to them that be like our
selves. But faith surmounteth there, where the very natural inclination
feels it self constrained, and sees that to be broken, which obstinately
was purposed to be kept in mind. The graces, gentleness, beauty, mild
behauior and allurement of Angelica, had greater force over Salimbene, than the
humility of her brother, although he had kneeled a hundred times before him.
But what heart is so brute, but may be made tractable and mylde, by the
contemplation of a thing so rare, as the excellent beauty of that Siena
maiden, and would not humble it selse to acquire the good graces of so perfect
a damsel? I will never accuse man for being in love with a fair and virtuous
woman, nor esteem him a slave, which painefully serves a sobre maiden, whose
heart is fraught with honest affections, and mind with desire tending to good
end. Well worthy of blame is he to be demed which is in love with the outward
hew, and praises the tree only laden with flowers, without regard to the
fruict, which makes it worthy of co^menbation. The young maiden must needs
resemble the flower of the Spring time, until by her constancy, modesty, and
chastity, she has vanquished the concupiscence of the slesh, and brought
forth the hoped fruit of a virtue and chastity not common. Otherwise, (...)
shall be like the enrolled soldier, whose valiance his only mind does
witness, and the offer which he makes to him that does register his name in
yt muster books. But when the efsect of (...) is joined with his (...), and
proof belieth not his promise, then the (...) imbraceth him, and aduanceth
him, as a glass for his affairs from that time forth. The like of dames
having passed the assaults and resisted the attempts of their assaylants which
be honest, not by force being not required, but inclined by their own nature,
and the diligence of their chaste and invincible heart. But return we again
unto our purpose, Montanine, when he was delivered, forthwith went home to his
house, to comfort her, who^ he was more than sure to be in great distress and
heaviness for his sake, and which had so much need of comfort as he had, to
take his rest. He came to yt gate of his palace (where being known that it
was Montanine) his sister by any means could not be made to believe the same:
so impossible seem things unto us, which we most desire. They were all in
doubt like as we read that they were, when S. Peter escaped Herod's prison by
the Angels means.

When Angelica was assured that it was her brother, sobbes were laid aside,
sighs were cast away, and heuie weepings converted into tears of joy, she
went to embrace and kiss her brother, praising God for his deliverance, and
making account that he had been raised from death to life, considering his
stoutnesse of mind, rather bent to die than to forgo his land, for so small a
price. The dames that were kin unto him, and tarried there in company of the
maiden half in despair, lest by despair and fury she might fall into
outrage, thereby to put her life in peril, with all expedition advertised their
husbands of Montanines liberty, not looked for, who repaired thither, as well
to rejoice with him in his joy and good fortune, as to make their excuse, for
that they had not travailed to ryd him from that misery. Charles which cared
nothing at all for those mouth blessings, dissembled what he thought, thanking
them nevertheless for their visitation and good remembrance they had of him,
for visiting and co^forting his sister, which honor he esteemed no less than if
they had employed the same upon his own person. Their friends and kinsfolk
being departed, and assured yt none of them had paid his ransom, he was
wonderfully astoonned, and the greater was his grief for that he could not tell
what he was, which without request, had made so gentle a proof of his
liberality: if he knew nothing, far more ignorant was his sister, for so much
as she did think, that he had changed his mind, and that the horror of
death had made him sell his country inheritance, to him which made the first
offer to buie the same: but either of them deceived of their thought went to
bed. Montanine rested not all the night, having still before his eyes, the
unknown image of him that had delivered him. His bed served his turn to none
other purpose, but as a large field or some long alley within a woodde, for
walks to make discourse of his minds conceits, sometimes remembering one,
sometimes another, without hitting the blanke and namyng of him that was his
deliverer, unto whom he confessed him self to owe his service and duty so
long as he lived. And because he saw the day begin to appear, and that the
morning, the Uauntcurrour of the day, summoned Appollo to harness his horse
to begin his course in our Hemisphere, he rose and went to the Chamberlain
or treasurer, such as was deputed for receipt, of the Fines, sessed by the
State, whom he saluted, and receiving like salutation, he prayed him to show
him so much pleasure, as to tell him the parties name, that was so liberal to
satisfy his fine due in the (...) of the State. To whom the other answered:
None other has caused thy deliverance (O Montanine) but a certain person of
the world, whose name thou may easily guess, to whom I gave an acquittance
of thine imprisonment, but not of the just sum, because he gave me a
thousand Ducates for a thousand Florens, and would not receive the overplus
of the debt, which I am ready to deliver thee with thine acquittaunce. I have
not to doc with the money (said Charles) only I pray you to tell me the name of
him yt has done me this great courtesy, that hereafter I may acknowledge him
to be my friend. It is said the Chamberlain) Anselmo Salimbene, who is to be
commended and praised above all thy parents and kin, and came hither very
late to bring the money, the surplusage whereof, behold here it is. God forbid
(said Montanine) that I should take away that, which so happily was brought
hither to rid me out of pain: and so went away with his acquitta^ce, his mind
charged with a nu^bre of fancies for the fact done by Salimbene. Being at home
at his house, he was long time stayed in a deep consideration, desirous to
know the cause of that gentle part, proceeding from him whose whose parents
and auncesters were the capital enemies of his race. In the end like one
risyng from a sound sleep, he called to mind, that very many times he had
seen Anselmo with attentive eye and fired look to behold Angelica, and in
eying her very lovingly, he passed every day (before their gate) not showing
other countenance, but of good will, and with friendely gessure, rather than
enemies face, saluting Angelica at all times when he met her. Wherefore
Montanine was assured, that the only love of Salimbene toward his sister had
caused that deliverance, concluding that when the passion does proceed of
good love, seized in gentle heart and of noble enterprise, it is impossible but
it must bring forth the marvelous effects of virtues gallantise, of honesty
and courtesy, and that the spirit well borue, can not so much hide his gentle
nourture, but the fire must flame abroad, and that which seems difficult to
be brought to pass, is facility, and made possible by the conceits and
endeavors so well employed, and not common to a mind that is not severed from
villainy: wherefore in the end not to be surmounted in honesty, ne yet to
bear the mark of one, that unthankfully accepted good turns, he determined
to use a great prodigality upon him, that under the name of foe, had showed
himself a more faithful friend, than those that bare good face, and at need
were furthest off from afflic ted Montanine, who not knowing what present to
make to Salimbene, but of himself and his sister, purposed to (...) his mind
to Angelica, and then upon knowledge of her will to perform his intent. For
which cause understanding that his gracious enemy was gone into the country,
he thought well to consider of his determination, and to break with her in his
absence, the better to execute the same upon his next return to the city. No
called Angelica aside, and being both alone together, he used these or such
like words: You know dear sister, that the higher is the fall, the more
dangerous it is, and greater grief he feels that does fall from high than
he that tumbleth down from place more low and of lesser steepness. I speak
this, because I call to mind the condition, nobilite, and excellency of our
ancesters, the glory of our race, and riches of all our house, which
constrains me many times to sigh, and sheade a stream of tears, when I see
the sumptuous palaces that were the homes and resting places of our fathers,
and grand fathers, when I see on al parts of this City, the Arms, and
scutcheons painted and imbossed, bearing the mark of the antiquity of our
house, and when I behold the stately marble tombs and brazen monumentes, in
diverse our temples erected for perpetual memory of many knights and generals
of wars, that sorted forth the Montanine race: and chiefly I never enter this
great palace, the remnant of our inheritance and patrimony, but the
remembrance of our auncesters, so glaunceth over mine heart, as an hundred
hundred times, I (...) for death, to think that I am the post alone of the
misery and decay fallen upon the name and famous family of the Montanines,
which makes me think our life to be unhappy, being down fallen from such
felicity, to feel a misery most extreme. But one thing alone ought to
content us, that amid so great poverty, ill luck, ruin and abasement, none is
able to lay unto our charge any thing unworthy of the nobility and the house,
whereof we be descended, our life being conformable to the generositie of our
predecessors, whereby it chances, yt although our poor estate be generally
known, yet none can affirm, that we have forligned yt virtue of them, which
virtuously have lived in our race. If so be (...) have received pleasure or
benefit of any man, never disdained I with all duty to acknowledge a good
turn, still shunning ye vice of ingratitude, to soil the reputation, wherein
hitherto I have passed my life. Is there any blot which more spotteth the
renoume of man, than not confessing received benefits and pleasures performed
in our necessity? You know in what peril of death I was, these few days
past, through their false surmise which never (...) me, and home almost
miraculously I was redeemed out of the hangma^s hands, and the cruel sentence of
ye unrighteous magistrate, not one of our kyn offering themselves in deed or
word for my defense, which forces me to say, yt I have felt of my kin, which
I never thought, and have tasted, such commodity at his hands, of who^ I never
durst expect or hope for pleasure, relief, aid or any comfort. I atte^ded my
deliverance by suit of those, who^ I counted for kin and friends, but ye same
so soon vanished, as the necessity and peril were present. So pressed with
woe, and forsaken of friends, I was affrayde that our adversaries (to remove all
fear and suspicion in time to come) would have purchased my total ruin, and
procured the overthrow of the Montanines name, by my death, and approached end.
But good God, from the place whereof I feared the danger, the calm arose, which
has brought my bark to ye haue^ of health, and at his hands where I attended
ruin, I have tasted affia^ce and sustentation of mine honor and life. And
plainly to proceed, it is Anselmo Salimbene, the son of our ancient and capital
enimes, that has showed himself the very loyal and faithful friend of our
family, and has delivered your brother by paime^t to ye State, the sum not
of a thousand Flore^s, but of a thousand ducats to rau^som ye life of him, who
thought him to be his most cruel adversary. O Ge^tlema^s heart in deed, and
gentle mind, whose rare virtues do surpass all human understanding.
Friends united together in band of amity, amaze the world by yt effects not
vulgar in things which they do one for an other. But this surmounteth all, a
mortal enemy, not reconciled or required, without demand of assurance for yt
pleasure, which he does, pays the debts of his adversary: which fact
excedeth al consideration to them, that discover the factes of men. I can not
tell what name to attribute to the deed of Salimbene, and what I ought to call
that his courtesy, but this must I needs protest, that the example of his
honesty and gentleness is of such force, and so much has vanquished me, as
whether I shall die in pain, or live at case, never am I able to exceed his
liberality. Now my life being engaged for that which he has done to me, and
he having delivered the same from infamous death, it is in your hands (dear
sister) to do the devise imagined in my mind, to the intent that I may be
only bound to you for satisfiyng the liberality of Salimbene, by means
whereof, you which wept the death and wailed the lost liberty of your
brother, do see me free, and in safety, having none other care but to be
acquitted of him, to whom both you and I be derely bound. Angelica hearing her
brother speak those words, and knowing that Salimbene was he, that had
surpassed all their kin in amity and comfort of their family, answered her
brother, saying: I would never have thought (good brother) that your
deliuerannce had come to pass by him whose name even now you fold, and that
our enemies breaking all remembrance of ancient quarrels, had care of the
health and conservation of the Montanines. Wherefore if it were in my power I
would satisfy the courtesy and gentleness of Ansehno, but I know not which
way to begin ye same, I being a maid that knows not how to recompense a good
turn, but by acknowledging the same in heart: and to go to render thanks, it
is neither lawful or comely for me, and much less to offer him any thing, for
the little access I have to his house, and the small familiarity I have with
the Gentlewomen of his kin. Notwithstanding brother, consider you wherein my
power rests to aid and help you, and be assured (mine honor saved) I will
spare nothing for your contentation. Sister (said Montanine) I have of long
time debated with my self what is to be (...), and devised what might be the
occasion that moved this young Gentleman to use so great kindness toward me,
and having diligently pondred and wayed what I have seen and known, at length
I found yt it was the only force of love, which constrained his affection, and
altered the ancient hatred that he bare us, into new love, that by no means
can be quenched. It is the covert fire which love has kindled in his
intrailes, it is love which has raised the true effects of gentleness, and
has consumed the conceits of displeased mind. O the great force of that
amorous alteration, which upon the sudden exchange, seems impossible to
receive any more change or mutacion. The only beauty and good grace of you
sister, has induced our gracious enemy, the servant of your perfections, to
deliver the pore Gentleman forlorn of all good fortune. It is the honest life
and commendable behauioure of Angelica Montanine, which have incited Anselmo to
do an act so praise worthy, and a deed so kind, to procure the deliverance
of one, which looked not for a chance of so great consequence. Ah Gentle young
Gentleman, Ah Princely mind, and heart noble and magnanunous. Alas how shall
it be possible that ever I can approach the honest liberality wherewith thou
haste bound me for ever? My life is thine, mine honor depends of thee, my
goods be tied to thee. What rests then? if not that you (sister) void of
cruelty do use no unkindness to him that loves you and who for love of you
has prodigally offered his own goods to rid me from pain and dishonor? If so
be, my life and (...) have been acceptable unto thee, and the sight of me
discharged from prison was joyful unto thee, if thou gave thy willing consent
that I should sell my (...), grant presently that I may with a great, rare, and
precious present, requite the goodness, pleasure and courtesy that Salimbene
has done for your sake: And since I am not able with goods of fortune to
satisfy his bounty, it is your person which may supply yt default, to the
intent that you and I may be quitted of the (...), wherein we stand bound unto
him. It behooves that for the offer and reward of money which he has
employed, we make present of your beauty, not selling the price of your
chastity, but delivering the same in exchange of courtesy, being assured for
his gentleness and good nouriture sake, he will use you none otherwise, or
usurp any greater authority over you, than vertus permits in each gentle
and noble heart. I have none other mean of fatisfaction, ne larger raunsom to
render free my head from the tribute which Salimbene has given for my life and
liberty. Think (dear sister) what determinate answer you will make me, and
consider if my request be meet to be denied. It is in your choice and pleasure
to deny or consent to my demand. If so be that I be refused and lose the
means by your refuse to be acquitted of my defender, I had rather forsake my
City and Country, than to live here with ye name of ingratitude, for not
acknowledging so great a pleasure. But alas, with what eye shall I dare behold
the Nobility of Siena, if by great unkindness I pass under silence the
rarest friendship that ever was devised? What hearts sorrow shall I conceive to
be pointed at with the finger, like one that has forgotten in acknowledging by
effect, the received pleasure of my deliverance? No (sister) either you must
be the quiet of my mind, and the acquittaunce of us (...), or else must I die,
or wander like a vagabonde into strange Countries, and never put foot again
into Italy. At those words Angelica stood so astonned and confused, and so
besides her self, like as we see one distraught of sense that feels himself
attached with some amaze of the Palsy. In the end recovering her sprites, and
beblubbered all with tears, her stomach panting like the Bellows of a forge,
she answered her brother in this manner: I know not loving brother by reason
of my troubled mind how to answer your demand, which seems to be both
right and wrong, right (...) respect of the (...), not so, in consideration of
the request. But how I prove the same, and what reason I can allege and
discover for that proof, hearken me so patiently, as I have reason to
complain and dispute upon this chance more hard and difficult to avoid, than
by reply able to be defended, since that life and the hazarding thereof is
nothing, in regard of that which you will have (...) to present with too
exceeding prodigal liberality, and I would to God that life might satisfy
the same, then be sure it should so soon be employed, as the promise made
thereof. Alas good God, I thought that when I (...) my brother out of prison,
the near distress of death, whereunto unjustly he was thrown, I thought (I
say) and firmly did believe, that fortune the enemy of our joy, had vomited al
her poison, and being despoiled of her fury and crabbed nature had broken the
bloody and venomous arowes, wherewith so long time she has plaged our family,
and that by resting of her self: she had given some rest to the Montanine house
of al their troubles and misadue^tures. But I (O miserable wight) do see and
feel how far I am divided from my hope, and deceived of mine opinion, since yt
furious stepdame, appears before me with a face more fierce and thretning, then
ever she did, sharpening her self against my youth in other sort, than ever
against any of our race. If ever she persecuted our auncesters, if she brought
them to ruin and decay, she now does purpose wholly to subvert the same, and
throw us headlong into yt bottomless pit of all misery, exterminating for all
together, the remnaunt of our consumed house. Be it either by loss of thee
(good brother,) or the violent death of me which cannot hazard my chastity for
the price of mine unhappy life: Ah good God, into what anguishe is my mind
exponed, and how do I feel the force and violence of froward fortune? But
what speak I of fortune? How does hard luck ensue, that is predestined by
the heavens upon our race? Must I at so tender years, and of so feeble kind
make choice of a thing, which would put the wisest upon earth unto their
shifts? My heart does fail me, reason wants and judgment hangs in
ballaunce by continual agitations, to see how I am driven to the extremity of
two dangerous straits, and enuironned with fearful ieoperdies, forcibly
compelled either to be divided and separated from thee (my brother,) whom I
love above mine own life, and in whom next after God I have sixed and put my
hope and trust, having none other solace, comfort and help, but thee, or else
by keeping thee, am forced to give unto another, and know not how, yt precious
treasure which being once lost, cannot be recovered by any means, and for the
guard and conservation whereof, every woman of good judgment that loves
virtue, ought a thousand times to offer her self to death (if so many ways she
could) rather than to blot or soil that inestimable jewel of chastity,
wherewith our life is a true life: contrariwise she which fondly suffers her
self to be disseazed and spoiled of the same, and loses it without honest
title, albeit she be a live, yet is she buried in the most obscure cave of
death, having lost the honor which makes Maidens march with head upright.
But what goodness has a Lady, gentlewoman, maiden or wife, wherein she can
glory, her honor being in doubt, and reputation darkened with infamy? Whereto
served the imperial house of Augustus, in those Ladies that were entitled
with the Emperors daughters, when for their vilany, their were unworthy of the
title of chaste and virtuous? What profited Faustina the Imperial crown upon
her head, her chastity through her abominable life, being rapt and despoiled?
What wrong has been done to many simple women, for being buried in the tomb
of dark oblivion, which for their virtue and pudique life, merited eternal
praise? Ah Charles my brother dear, where have thou bestowed the eye of thy
fore seeing mind, that without foresight and care of the fame due to the
honest dames, and chaste damsels of our family, having lost the goods and
fathers inheritance, wilt have me in like sort sorgoe my chastity, which
hitherto I have kept with heedeful diligence. Will thou dear brother by the
price of my virginity, that Anselmo shall have greater victory over us, than he
has gotten by fight of sword upon the allied remnaunt of our house? Art thou
ignorant that the wounds and diseases of the mind, be more vehement than those
which afflicte the body? Ah I unhappy maiden and what ill luck is reserved for
me, what destiny has kept me till this day to be presented for Venus
Sacrifice, to satissie a young man's lust, which coueteth (peradventure) but
the spoil of my virginity? O happy the Roman maid, slain by the proper hands
of her woeful father Virginius, that she might not be soiled with infamy, by
the lecherous embracements of ravenous Appius, which desired her acquaintance.
Alas that my brother do not so, rather I would to God of his own accord he be
the (...) minister of my life, ready to be violated, if God by (...) grace take
not my cause in hand? Alas death, why (...) thou not throw against my heart
thy most pearcing darte, that I may go wait upon the shadows of my thrice
happy parents, who knowing this my grief, will not be void of passion to help me
wail my woeful state. O God why was not I choked and strangled, so sone as I
was taken forth the secret imbracements of my mothers womb, rather tha^ to
arrive into this mishap, that either must I lose the thing I deem most dear,
or die with the violence of my proper hands? Come death, come, and cut the
unhappy threede of my woeful life, stop the pace of tears with thy trenchant
darte that stream outragiously down my face, and close the brething wind of
sighs, which hinder thee from doing thine office upon my heart, by suffocation
of my life and it. When she had ended those words, her speech did fail, and
waxing pale and faint, (sitting upon bir stool) she fared as though that very
death had sitten in her place. Charles thinking that his sister had been dead,
(...) with sorrow, and desirous to live no longer after her, seeing he was the
cause of that sowning, fell down dead upon the ground, moving neither hand nor
foot, as though the soul had been departed from the body. At the noise which
Montanine made by reason of his fall, Angelica revived out of her sown, and
seeing her brother in so pitiful plight, and supposing he had been dead for
care of his request, for being berieued of her brother, was so moved, as a
little thing would have made her do, as (...) did, when she viewed Pyramus to be
slain. But conceiving hope, she threw her self upon her brother, cursing her
fortune, banning the stars of cruelty, and her lauash speech, and her self
for her little love to her brother, who made no refusal to die to save his land
for relief of her: where she denied to yield her self to him yt loved her with so
goodaffection. In the end she applied so many remedies unto her brother,
sometimes casting cold water upon his face, sometimes pinching and rubbing the
temples and pulses of his arms, and his mouth with vinegar, that she made him
to come again: and seeing that his eyes were open, beholding her intentiuely
with yt countenance of a man half in despair, she said unto him: For so much
brother as I see fortune to be so froward, that by no means thou can avoid
the cruel lot, which lau^cheth me into the bottom of mortal misery, and that
I must adventure to follow the endeavors of thy mind, and obey thy will, which
is more gentle and noble, than fraught with reason, I am content to satisfy the
same, and the love which hitherto thou have born me. Be of good cheer, and do
with me and my body what thou list, give and present the same to whom thou
please. Well be thou sure, that so soon as I shall be out of thy hands and
power, I will be called or esteemed thine no more, and thou shall have less
authority to stay me from doing the devises of my fantasy, swearing and
protesting by the almighty God, that never man shall touch Angelica, except it
be in marriage, and that if he assay to pass any further, I have a heart that
shall incorage my hands to sacrifice my life to the chastity of noble dames
which had rather die than live in (...) of dishonesty. I will die a body
without (...), and the mind void of consent, shall receive no shame or filth
that can soil or spot ye same. In saying so, she began again to weep in
such abundance, as the humor of her brain ran down by the issue of both
her eyes. Montanine albeit sorrowful beyond measure to see his gentle and chaste
sister in such vexation and heaviness, reioysed yet in his mind, that she had
agreed to his (...), which presaged the good luck that afterward chanced
unto him, for his liberal offer. Wherefore said he to Angelica, I was never in
my life so desirous to live, but yt I rather choose to die, than procure a
thing that should turn thee to displeasure and grief, or to hazard thine honor
and reputation in danger or peril of damage, which thou have ever known, and
should have still perceived by effect, or more properly to speak, touched
with thy finger, if that incomparable and rare courtesy and liberality of
Salimbene had not provoked me to require that, which honestly thou can not
give, nor I demand without wrong to thee, and prejudice to mine own
estimation and honor. But what? the sear I have to be deemed ingrate, has
(...) me forget thee, and the great honesty of Anselmo makes me hope, yea and
steadfastly believe, that thou shall receive none other displeasure, but to be
presented unto him, whom at other times we have thought to be our mortal
enemy. And I think it impossible that he will use any villainy to her, whom he
so fervently loves, for whose sake he fears not the hatred of his (...), and
disdained not to save him whom he hated, and on whom he might have been
revenged. And for so much sister, as the face commonly she weth the sign and
token of the hearts affections, I pray (...) by any means declare no sad
countenance in the presence of Salimbene, but rather cheer (...) thy face.
dry up the abundance of thy tears, that he by seeing thee joyful and merry,
may be moved to (...) his courtesy and use thee honestly, being satisfied with
thy liberality, and the offer which I will make of our service.

Here may be seen the (...) of two diverse things, duty combating with shame,
reason being in contention with himself. Angelica knew and confessed that her
brother did but his duty, and that she was bound by yt same very bond. On the
other side, her estate and virginal chastity, brake the endeavors of her duty,
and denied to do that which she esteemed right. Nevertheless she prepared her
self to follow both the one and the other: and by acquiling the duty to her
brother, she ordained the mean, to discharge him of that, which he was bound
to his benefactor, determining nevertheless rather to die, than shamefully to
suffer her self to be abused, or to make her lose the flower, which made her
glister amongs ye maidens of the city, and to deface her good fault by an act
so villainous. But that special rare virtue was more singular in her, than was
ye continency of Cyrus the Persian King, who fearing to be forced by the
allurements of the excellent beauty of chaste Panthea, would not suffer her to
be brought into his presence, for fear that he being surmounted with folish
lusts, should force her, that by other means could not be persuaded to break
the holy laws of marriage, and promised Faith to her husband. For Salimbene
having in his presence, and at his commandment her, whom above all things he
loved, would by no means abuse his power, but declared his Gentle nature to be
of other force and effect, than that of the before said king, by reading ye
success of this history you shall perceive.

After that Montanine and his sister had uttered many other words upon their
determination, and that ye fair maiden was appeased of her sorrow, attending
the issue of that which they went about to begin: Anselmo was come home out of
the Country, whereof Charles having intelligence, about the second hour of ye
night, be caused his sister to make her ready, and in company of one of their
servant that carried light before them, they came to the lodging of Salimbene,
whose servant seeing Montanine so accompanied to knock at the gate, if he did
marvel I leave for you to think, by reason of yt displeasure and hatred which
he knew to be between the two families, not knowing that which had already
passed for ye beginning of a final peace of so many controversies: for which
cause so astonned as he was, he went to tell his master that Montanine was at
the gate, desirous secretly to talk unto him. (...) knowing what company
Charles had with him, was not unwilling to go down, and (...) two torches to
be lighted, came to his gate to entertain them, and to welcome ye brother and
the sister, with so great courtesy and friendship as he was surprised with
love, seeing before his eyes ye sight of her, that burned his heart
incessa^tly, not discovering as yet the secrets of his thought, by making her
to understand the good will he bare her, and how much he was her servant. He
could not tell well whether he was incharmed, or his eyes daselled, or not well
wakened from (...) when he saw Angelica, so amazed was he with the
strangeness of the fact, and arrival of the maiden to his house. Charles
seeing him so confused, and knowing that the great affection he bare unto his
sister, made him so perplexed and besides himself, said unto him: Sir we would
gladly speak with you in one of your chambers, yt there might be none other
witness of our discourse, but we. (...). together. Salimbene which was (...)
with joy, was able to make none other answer, but, Go we whether you please.
So taking his Angelica by the hand, they went into yt hall, and from thence
into his chamber, which was furnished according to yt state and riches of a
Lord, he being one of the welthiest and chief of the city of Siena. When they
were set down, and all the (...) gone (...), Charles began to say to
Salimbene, these words: You may not think it strange (sir Salimbene) if
against the laws and customs of our common wealth, I presently do call you,
for knowing the band wherewith I am bound unto you, I must for ever confess and
count my self to be your slave and bo^dman, you having done a thing in my
behalf yt deserves ye name of Lord and master. But what ungrateful man is he
yt will forget so great a benefit, as that which I have received of you, holding
of you, life, goods, honor, and this mine own sister yt enjoys by your means
the presence of her brother and her rest of mind, not losing our noble
reputation by ye loss prepared for me through unrighteous judgment, you
having staid the ruin both of her and me, and the rest of our house and kin. I
am right glad sir, yt this my duty and service is bounden to so virtuous a
gentleman as you be, but exceeding sorry, yt fortune is so froward and contrary
unto me, that I am not able to accomplish my good will, and if ingratitude may
lodge in mind of a needy Gentleman, who has no help but of himself, and in
ye will of his chaste sister, and mind united in two persons only saved by
you, duty does require to present the rest, and to submit all that is left,
to be disposed at your good pleasure. And because that I am well assured, that
it is Angelica alone which has kindled ye fire of desire, and has caused you
to love that which your predecessors have deadly hated, yt same spark of
knowledge, which our misery could not quench with all his force, has made the
way, and showed the path whereby we, shall avoid the name of ingrate and
forgetful persons, and that same which has made you liberal toward me,
shall be bountifully bestowed upon you. It is Angelica sir which you see present
here, who to discharge my band, has willingly rendered to be your own,
submitting her self to your good will, for ever to be youres. And I which am
her brother, and have received that great good will of her, as in my power to
have her will, do present the same, and leave her in your hands, to use as you
would your own, praying you to accept the same, and to consider whose is the
gift, and from wheuce it comes, and how it ought to be regarded. When he had
said so, Montanine rose up, and without further talk, went home unto his
house. If Anselmo were abashed at the Montanines arrival, and (...) at the
Oration of Charles, his sudden departure was more to be marvelled at, and
therwithall to see the effect of a thing which he never hoped, nor thought
upon. He was exceeding glad and joyful to see himself in the company of her,
whom he desired above all things of the world, but sorry to see her heavy and
sorrowful for such chance. He supposed her being there, to proceed rather of
the young man's good and gentle nature, than of the maidens will and liking. For
which cause taking her by ye hand, and holding her between his arms, he used
these or such like words: Gentlewoma^, if ever I had felt and known with what
wing yt variety and lightness of worldly things do fly, and the gains of
inco^stant fortune, at this present I have seen one of yt most manifest profes
which seems to me so (...), as almost I dare not believe that, which I see
before mine eyes. I know well that it is for you, and for the service that I
bear you, yt I have broken the effect of yt hatred, which by inheritance I
have received against your house, and for yt devotion have delivered your
brother. But I see that fortune will not let me to have the upper hand, to be
the conqueror of her sudden pangs. But you your self shall see, and every man
shall know, yt my heart is none other tha^ noble, and my devises tend, but to
the exploit of all virtue and gentleness: wherefore I pray you (said he kissing
her lovingly) be not sad, and doubt not that your servant is any other now,
having you in his power, than he was when he durst not discover the arde^t love
that vexed him, and held him in feeble state, full of (...) and thought, you
also may be sure, that he has not had the better hand over me, ne yet for his
courtesy has obtained victory, nor you for obeying him. For since that you be
mine, and for such yielded and given to me, I will keep you, as her whom I love
and esteem above al things of the world, making you my companion, and the only
mistress of my goods, heart, and will. Think not that I am the friend of
Fortune, and practice pleasure alone without virtue. It is modesty which
commands me, and honesty is the guide of my conceits. Assure you then, and
repose your comfort on me: for none other tha^ Angelica Montanine, shall be the
wife of Anselmo Salimbene: and during my life, I will be the friend, the
defender and supporter of your house. At those good news, the drousie and
wandering spirit of the fair Siena maid awaked, who ending her tears, and
appeasing her sorrow, rose up, and made a very low reverence unto her courteous
friend, thanking him for his great and incomparable liberality, promising
all service, duty, and amity, that a Gentlewoman ought to bear unto him,
who^ God had reserved for her spouse and husband. After an infinite number of
honest imbracements and pleasant kisses given and received on both parts,
Anselmo called unto him one of his Auntes that dwelled within him, to whom he
delivered his new conquest to keep, and spedily without delay he sent for
the next of his kin and dearest friends: and being come, he entreated them to
keep him company, in a very urgent and weighty business he had to do,
wherein if they showed them selves diligent in his request, doubtful it is not,
but he addressed speed for accomplishme^t of his enterprise. Then causing his
Aunt and well-beloved Angelica to come forth, he carried them (not without their
great admiration) to the palace of Montanine, whither being arrived, he and
his company were well entertained of the said Montanine, the brother of fair
Angelica. When they were in the hall, Salimbene said to his brother in law that
should be: Senior Montanine, it is not long since, that you in company of my
fair Gentlewoman here, came home to speak with me, desirous to have no man
privy to the effect of your conference. But I am come to you with this troop
to disclose my mind before you al, and to manifest what I purpose to do, to the
intent the whole world may know your good and honest nature, and understand how
I can be requited on them, which endeavor to gratify me in any thing. Having
said so, and every man being set down, he turned his talk to the rest of the
company in this wise: I doubt not my (...) and noble dames, but that ye much
muse and marvel to see me in this house so late, and in your company, and am
sure, that a great desire moves your minds to know for what purpose, yt cause,
and why I have gathered this assembly in a time unlooked for, and in place
where none of our race and kynne of long time did enter, and less did mean
to make hither their repair. But when you do consider what virtue and
goodness rests in the hearts of those men, that shun and avoid the (...)
of mind, to follow the reasonable part, and which proprely is called
spiritual, you shall thereby perceive, that when gentle kind and noble heart,
by the great mistress (...) Nature, be grifted in the minds of men, they
cease not to make appear the effect of their doings, sometime producyng one
virtue, sometimes another, which cease not to cause the fruict of such
industry both to blow and bear: In such wise, as the more those virtuous
acts and commendable works, do appear abroad, the greater dyligence is
employed to search the matter wherein she (...) cause to appear the force of
virtue and excellency, conceiuyng singular delighte in that her good and holy
delyuerie, which brings forth a fruict worthy of such a stock. And that
force of mind and generositie of noble heart is so firm and sure in
operation, as although humane things be unstable and subject to change, yet
they can not be severed or disparcled. And albeit it be the butte and white,
whereat Fortune discharges all her darts and shaftes, threatening shooting and
assailing the same round, yet it continues stable and firm like a rock and
cliffe beaten with the violent fury of waves rising by wind or tempest.
Whereby it chances, that riches and dignity can no more advance the heart of a
slave and villain, than poverty make vile and abase the greatness of courage
in them that be procreated of other stuff than of common sort, which daily
keep the majesty of their original, and live after the instincte of good and
noble blood, wherewith their auncesters were made noble, and sucked that same
virtue out of the teates of Noursses breasts, who in the mids of
troublesome (...) of Fortune that do assail them, and depresse their
modesty, their face and countenance, and their factes full well declare their
condition, and do to understand, that under such a misery, a mind is
hid, which deserves greater guerdon than the eigre taste of calamity. In
that did glowe and shine the youth of the Persian and Median Monarch, being
nurssed amongs the stalles and stables of his grandfather, and the gentle kind
of the founder of stately Rome, suckeled in the shepecoates of Princes
shephierds. Thus much have I said, my good lords and dames, in consideration
of the noble courage and gentle mind of Charles Montanine, and of his sister,
who without prejudice to any other, I dare to say, is the paragon and mirror
of all chaste and courteous maidens, well trained up, amongs the whole troop of
those that live this day in Siena, who being brought to the end and last
point of their ruin, as every of you does know, and their race so sore decayed,
as there remains but the only name of Montanine: notwithstanding they never
lost the heart, desire, ne yet the effect of the courtesy, and natural
bounty, which ever does accompany the mind of those that be (...) in deed,
Which is the cause that I am constrained to accuse our auncesters, of to much
cruelty, and of the little respect which for a controversy occurred by chance,
have pursued them with such mortal revenge, as without ceassing, with all their
force, they have assayed to ruinate, abolishe, and for ever (...) that a right
noble and illustre race of the Montanines, amongs who^ if never any goodness
appeared to the world, but the honesty, gentleness, courtesy and virtuous
manners of these twain here present, the brother and sister, yet they ought to
be accounted amongs the rank of the noblest and chiefest of our City, to the
intent in time to come it may not be reported, that we have esteemed and
cherished riches and drossie mucke, more than virtue and modesty. But
imitating those excellent gouerners of Italy, which held the Roman Empire,
let us rather reverence the virtuous poor, than praise or prise the rich,
given to vice and wickedness. And for so much as I do see you all to be
desirous to know yt cause and argument, which makes me to use this talk, and
forces me to praise the (...) and goodness of the Montanines, pleases you
to stay a little with patience, and not think the time tedious, I mean to
declare the same. Plainly to confess unto you (for that it is no crime of
death, or heinous offense) the gifts of nature, the beauty and comeliness of
fair Angelica here present, have so captiuate my mind, and deprived my heart of
liberty, as night and day travailing how I might discover unto her my
martirdom, I did consume in such wise, as losing lust of sleep and meat, I
feared ere long to be either dead of sorrow, or (...) of my right wits, seeing
no means how I might avoid the same, because our two houses and families were
at continual debate: and albeit (...) were ceased, and quarelles forgotten,
yet there rested (as I thought) a certain desire both in the one and the
other of offense when time and occasion did serve. And yet mine affection for all that was not decreased, but rather more tormented, and my grief increased,
hopeless of help, which now is chanced to me as you shall hear. You do
know, and so do all men, how within these few days past, the Lord
Montanine here present, was accused before the Seniorie, for trespasses against
the statutes and Edicts of the same, and being prisoner, having not wherewith to
satisfy the condemnation, ye law affirmed that his life should recompense and
supply default of money. I not able to suffer the want of him, which is the
brother of the dearest thing I esteem in the world, and having not her in
possession, nor like without him to attain her, paid that sum, and
delivered him. He, by what means I know not, or how he coniectured the
benevolence of my deed, thinkyng that it proceeded of the honest (...) and
affection which I bare to gracious and amiable Angelica, well considering of my
curteste, has overcome me in prodigalitle he this night came unto me, with
his sister my mystresse, yeldyng her my slave and bondwoman, leaving her with
me, to do with her as I would with any thing I had. Behold my good Lords, and
ye noble Ladies and cousins, and consider how I may recompense this benefit,
and be able to satisfy a present so precious, and of such value and regard,
as both of them be, such, as a right puissant prince and lord, may be contented
with a duty so liberal and jewel in estimable of two offered things. The
assistants that were there, could not tell what to say, the discourse had so
much drawn their minds into diverse fantasies and contrary opinions, seeing
that the same required by deliberation to be considered, before lightly they
vttred their minds. But they knew not the intent of him, which had called them
thither, more to testify his fact, than to judge of the thing he went about,
or able to hinder and let the same. True it is, that the Ladies viewyng and
marking the amiable countenance of the (...) (...), would have judged for her,
if they feared not to be refused of him, whom the thing did touch most
near. Who without longer stay, opened to them all, what he was purposed to
do, saying: Since ye do spend time so long upon a matter already meant and
determined, I will ye to know, that having (...) of mine honor, and desirous to
satisfy the honesty of the brother and sister I mind to take Angelica to my
wife and lawful spouse, uniting that which so long time has been divided, and
making in two bodies, whilom not well accorded and agreed, one like and uniform
will, praying you each one, joyfully to joy with me, and your selves to rejoice
in that alliance, which seems rather a work from heaven, than a deed
concluded by the counsel and industry of men. So likewise all wedded feeres
in holy Wedlock (by reason of the effect and the Author of the same, even G
O D him self, which did ordain it first) be written in the infallible Book
of his own prescience, to the intent that nothing may decay, which is
sustained with the myghtie hand of that Almighty God, the God of wonders,
which verily he has displayed over thee (dear brother) by making thee to
fall into distress and danger of death, that mine Angelica, being the mean
of thy dyliueraunce, might also be cause of the atonement which I do hope
henceforth shall be, between so noble houses as ours be. This final decree
reveled in open audience, as it was, against their expectation, and the end
that the kynred of Anselmo looked for, so was the same no less strange and
bathful, as joyful and pleasant, feelyng a sudden joy, not accustomed in
their mind, for that union and alliance. And albeit that their riches was
unequal, and the Dowry of Angelica nothing near the great wealth of
Salimbene, yet all men did deem him happy, that he had chanced upon so
virtuous a maiden, the only modesty and integrity of whom, deserved to be
coupled with the most honorable. For when a man has respect only to the
beauty or riches of her, whom he means to take to wise, he most commonly
does incur the mischief, that the spirit of dissension intermeddleth
amydde their householde, whereby pleasure vanishing with age, makes the
riueled face (beset with a thousand wrinkeled furrows) to grow pale and dry.
The wife likewise when she sees her goods to surmou^t, the substance of her
wedded husband, she aduaunceth her heart, she swells to make himself a
conqueror by marriage, but she diminyshing no jot of her noble mind, he must
seek else where his price of victory. To her a desire to kill her self (if
things succeeded contrary to her mind) might have stopped the way to her great
glory, had she not regarded her virginity, more than her own life. The
second seems to go half constrained, and by manner of acquitall, and had his
affection been to render himself (...) to his foe, his patron and preserver,
it would have diminished his praise.

But since enough we have hereof discoursed, and ben large in treaty of
Tragicomicall matters, intermixed and suaged (in some part) with the
enteruiews of dolor, modesty, and indifferent good hap, and in some wholly
imparted the dreadful ends like to terrible beginnings, I mean for a
relief, and after such sour sweet bankettes, to interlarde a licorous
refection for sweeting the mouths of the delicate: And do purpose in this
Novel ensuing, to manifest a pleasant disporte between a Widow and a
Scholar, a passing practice of a crafty dame, not well schooled in the
discipline of Academicall rules, a surmountyng science to trade the nouices of
that form, by ware foresight, to incountre those that by laborsome travail
and nightly watch, have studied the rare knowledge of Mathematicalls, and other
hydden and secret Arts.

Wishing them so well to beware, as I am desirous to let them know by this
(...), the success of such attemptes.

Mistress Helena of Florence
